If only the script had more attention given to details, then The Identical wouldn't have ended up looking like a pale imitation of what could have been a better movie.
Dolphin Tale 2 is a safe family film but that doesn't make up for it being a lackluster attempt to generate a few more bucks for the franchise.
Ball has created balance between a thin but solid script and first-rate action -- and he doesn't waste a frame doing it.
Tusk is the kind of movie you can't get out of your head. Try as you might, it goes to the top of the list of images you wish you had not seen.
Words and Pictures resonates with a clever and endearing energy that harkens back to the days when Doris Day and Rock Hudson dominated the box office.
What sets this film apart from the less effective summer movies is that director James Gunn has put together a cast that can handle the action and the humor.
When the film turns to new material and characters, it's fun to watch. There's just not enough of those new comic moments.
Wallace has created a movie that has a message that goes beyond preaching to the choir. That's when the work is at its best.
Eubank's directing style jumps around as he goes from shaky hand-held shots to sequences filmed with so little movement they play as being very cold.
With the newness gone, all of the bloody battles in Rise of an Empire come across as gratuitous and boring.
Sparks shows plenty of cinematic muscle. It deserves a place among the legion of superhero movies.
Despite being saddled with all of the demands that come with directing, Fiennes turns in one of the best performances of his career.

Thomas Wolfe professed you can't go home again. Veronica Mars proves him wrong. This trip back to her old mystery-solving stomping ground is pleasantly entertaining for the uniformed and a perfect thank you to all of the loyal fans.

Perry tosses in comedic moments when the tension gets too intense, but he doesn't do it at the sake of any of the characters. This is a movie about five interesting -- and funny -- women dealing with real world problems.
It's nice to have the Muppets back, but the euphoria of their return gets wiped away by this disappointing sequel. The movie proves its not easy earning green again.
Honestly, this is a film that will please fans of the book. It's not bad, but it feels too familiar and lacks the on-screen chemistry for it to win over those who haven't read the book.
It's time to break out the thesaurus to find enough accolade adjectives to describe this comedy, which has an adult competing in a spelling bee for elementary school students.
Even with a few flaws, Cesar Chavez beautifully reflects the political and personal power of a man who showed it was possible to change the world from a dusty field.
A film that shows great muscle through a fresh perspective but remains loyal to the elements that have made past films a hit.
Draft Day shouldn't be your No. 1 pick if you are looking for a great movie. But it does have enough talent to make it worth taking a chance on.
A film that pulls us in with a sweet and powerful story where major tent poles of religion and politics are presented in a strong but subtle way.

The brutal emotions of the script mixed with the untethered performances make Dom Hemingway the kind of movie that viewers will either deeply hate or passionately love. Shepard leaves no room for a middle ground.
This Spider-Man doesn't end up amazing, but it still weaves enough of an action film web to please rabid readers of the comics and those who aren't as mad about the books.
What could have been a smart comedy about the battle of the ages too often finds itself in such a loss for anything funny that it resorts to an endless string of jokes about male sex organs.
The big problem is that none of the moms are interesting.
The Legends of Oz: Dorothy's Return has some smart writing and heart-touching moments, making it a brave addition to a familiar franchise.

Gareth Edwards, director of the new Godzilla, tries to deal with some character development and the franchise mythology, but in the end the film is 123 minutes of Godzilla smashing anything that gets in his way.
The money matters dilute the sports angle so much it keeps the film from being the home run it should have been. But it still drives home some entertaining and sweet moments.
If you can get through the first 20 minutes of Blended - a nonstop regurgitation of old jokes, annoying characters and unfunny ideas -- don't relax. It gets worse.
It's good, but it never reaches the dark political and emotional tones of a movie like 12 Years a Slave.
If only the script had been as good as Jolie's performance and the beautiful visuals from Stromberg, this would have been a summer sleeper beauty.
If Seth MacFarlane ever corrects the bad habits he's developed as a director, he could become the Mel Brooks of the 21st century.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There are some very good moments, especially a powerful eulogy scene. But, fans of the book don't have any surprises that would help spark an emotional connection.
Edge of Tomorrow is the kind of film that can be enjoyed time after time.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The sequel -- even with its flaws -- is full of enough fun and action to entertain youngsters and has enough emotional moments to hold the attention of adults.
Despite the problems, Washington's performance is compelling enough to hold the story together.

It's a shame there isn't some magic golden tablet that can bring dead scripts to life. A dose of energy and originality would have gone a long way toward making this tired and dusty story a little richer.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Dracula Untold is entertaining, just not memorable. It eventually will become the kind of heavily repeated feature film that cable channels use to fill weekend afternoons when there's nothing original to air.

Vaughn has transformed the original comic book story into one with enough sharp edges that this could be the next big spy series. To accomplish that task, it will take a little more consistency with the future films.

Even the best runners occasionally stumble. It's the finish that truly matters. Overall, McFarland, USA finds the perfect pacing on the strength of family and the power of hope presented against a sports backdrop.
The movie ends up being like Frankenstein's monster before the lightning shock -- it's a lot of pieces sewn together that are lifeless.
Smith's smooth approach -- coupled with the smoldering stylings of Robbie -- gives "Focus" an odd combination of coolness and heat.
It uses the same phenomenal cast, sweet writing and beautiful appreciation of the Indian culture to create a film that may be "second best" but is still a winner.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Run All Night sports enough high-caliber performances, memorable camera work and top-notch action scenes that if this had been Taken 3, it would have certainly been a far better way to end that franchise.

Tackling the fairytale in such a direct manner could have been Branagh's undoing. Instead, he presents the tale with such joy and passion that it becomes a nostalgic journey to a time of childhood dreams.
Star Trek is such a well-written, superbly acted and amazingly staged film that it sets a new standard for summer action films.
The Gunman is well-meaning, but it lacks the spark that made Taken such a compelling tale.
The action scenes aren't enough to distract from a script that is full of holes, illogical actions and a story that takes almost two hours to complete yet only moves things forward a few baby steps.
Juggling so many story lines is a major task, but director Jonathan M. Gunn manages to service all the stories while holding true to the movie's main message.
Weighed down by endless jokes about prison rape, relentless homophobia and a bevy of absurd stereotypes, this Will Ferrell and Kevin Hart film sinks into an abyss of failure.
This low-budget, faith-based film -- with a cast of mostly unknowns -- is little more than a made-for-cable movie. But it offers an endearing look at what it's like to fall in love -- not lust.
The combination of a feeble script, unnecessary music montages, unlikable characters and so-so animation leave Home a close encounter of the dull kind.
Those actors are good. But the movie survives and thrives on big explosions and even bigger explosions.
Scott Eastwood's good ol' boy Southern gentleman is sweetly charming. He's perfectly matched with Britt Robertson, who has grown since the under-appreciated CW Network series Life Unexpected.
This is a tale of delusion, illusion and confusion given life through a powerful performance by Rinko Kikuchi.

It will be interesting after Unfriended ends its theatrical run and it can be viewed on a home computer. That will create the unsettling situation where the viewer is almost a new participant in this online game of supernatural cyberstalking.
There is plenty of potential for turns and twists, but nothing ever happens.
Huisman is charming, but it's Ford who makes this movie. Ford's been involved with so many action movies, it's easy to forget his acting talent.

Little Boy is guilty of trying too hard. Had it just focused on a youngster's heartbreaking efforts to get his father home from the war, it would have been a touching tale.Sadly, that story gets bogged down by overly sentimental plot lines.

Ex Machina is one of the smartest horror movies to come along in years. It doesn't count on big scares and excessive violence to make its points but shows that intellect left unchecked can be equally as frightening.
Crowe shows great skill in staging scenes. He finds the right pacing to get the most out of the scenes without letting them become contrived.
The action scenes are spectacular. But the slightly jumbled story and mob of new characters pulls focus from what makes the film work the best -- the original group of costumed characters.

Fury Road is a feast of explosions, fights and crashes that come at break-neck speed... The worst thing about the movie moving at such a rapid pace is that there is little time to appreciate the craftsmanship that went into the modified rides.
The Barden Bellas have found their harmony again to make Pitch Perfect 2 nearly as much fun as the original.
It Follows builds terror that finds its scares through all the earmarks of a very vivid nightmare.
The scariest thing about Annabelle is that a film studio would release such a lazy attempt at making a horror movie without any sign of shame.
No one said the masochism part of the story in Fifty Shades of Grey had to do with what the audience would be put through.
It's taken 15 years, but the bloated and pitiful Battlefield Earth no longer has to carry the mantle of being the worst big budget science-fiction film of all time.
Fury shows that war is brutal in the way it strips away the human spirit and leaves the participants reacting with a kind of prehistoric instinct for survival.
Reeves brings just the right amount of killing tenacity, tempered by a five-year absence from the job, to make Wick formidable yet slightly vulnerable.
Like the ending or not, the film finds strength in the performances by Gyllenhaal and Russo. Their work is as captivating to watch as a police chase on a Los Angeles freeway.
It's hard to talk about certain elements without giving away some of the film's secrets. Let's just say the ending would be laughable if it wasn't so incredibly bad.

It's a bonus that these are not only interesting characters because of the physical aspects of their new found powers, but they are also smart. It's not often when the central figures of this kind of action-heavy story are the smartest people in the room.
It's the acting strength of Moretz and Knightley that helps slowly melt the awkwardness of the age gap and lets the story settle into a sweet and moving tale of personal discovery.
One of the most compellingly acted and intellectually stimulating movies of the year.
This movie has earned the tag of stinker in more ways than one.
A powerful and painful tale of the Old West.
Lawrence shines. It's the rare actor who can show so much rage, hate, pain and hope in a single look. But she does.
Horrible Bosses 2" is the latest example of how Hollywood executives are so convinced moviegoers will blindly see a sequel that there is no reason to make the follow-up product good.
As if the great animation and first-rate writing weren't enough, the film offers a sweet lesson about how everyone has a purpose, no matter how small.
Director Paul Tibbitt takes all of the visual humor and presents it in both sparkling traditional animation and stunning computer-generated sequences for dry land.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a captivating story about one of the most fascinating people on the planet, punctuated by Redmayne's special performance.
The film soars through a plot that grows to preposterous heights.

The only saving grace is Foxx, who handles both the small moments and big musical numbers with ease. It's too bad he's surrounded by supporting cast members that dance like they are wearing lead shoes and sing with all the passion of a wet sponge.
his is a movie that starts with a strong performance by Witherspoon that only gets better through the movie.
Into the Woods is a musical journey full of strong performances, a beautiful fairytale landscape and a story that is emotionally haunting. Climb up a beanstalk to see this movie musical.
"The Grand Budapest Hotel" is Anderson's finest attempt at film whimsy. He's created a movie that is as visually stunning as it is smartly written.

With a lesser actor, The Imitation Game would have collapsed on its good intentions. Cumberbatch brings such a raw personal passion to his work, he elevates the better parts to a superb level and keeps the miscues to a minimum.
It's films like Selma that remind us that behind every massive pivotal moment there are a thousands of smaller stories that come together like raindrops forming a ground-shaking thunderstorm.

Even repeated readings of Pynchon's books don't guarantee a complete enlightenment. That means it's the chase that is more fascinating than the discovery, an approach that Andesron used in writing his screenplay and making the movie.
A film that isn't merely a war movie -- it's a story of courage, conviction, camaraderie and caring.
It is a perfect storm of a worn-out idea, shot with a lack of originality and played out by wooden actors. The Boy Next Door couldn't be any worse if they tried.
A Most Violent Year never feels rushed. Chandor sets a tempo that allows Isaac to play his character with control while giving Chastain the time she needs to manipulate behind the throne.
Binder's ability to make smart arguments for both sides of the issue, without becoming overly sentimental, gives Black or White a solid foundation.

It's not a bad ending to the Hobbit's unexpected journey, but it does not reach the standard set by the other films. But even with all its flaws, there is a brave cinematic heart at the core that makes even this weaker Jackson film better than most.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A master craftsman and an average artist may start with the same tools, but they end up with work that is completely different in quality. In the world of animation, Hayao Miyazaki is one of the all-time master craftsmen.
Out of the Furnace is a masterfully crafted tale of people and a place pushed to the edge where their only hope seems to be an abyss of despair.
Winter's Tale combines a superb cast with an even more impressive story to make a film that is easy to love.
It's hard to get past the unintentionally funny way the close encounters of the body-sharing kind are portrayed.
The plot is not as important as the action that follows. Director Jon M. Chu shows great skill, whether the fights are on city streets or on the sides of mountains.
The world could use a few more movies like Camp.

Fede Alvarez hits the majority of the terror beats of the original movie, from the creepy-looking cabin to rivers of blood. Because he had a larger budget, Alvarez cranks up the special effects. But the results are not as much fun.

If releasing the film in 3-D is the only way to get it back in theaters, then the gimmick is an acceptable addition. The 3-D is good. But when a movie is this near flawless, nothing is needed to make it better.
Helgeland shows a deep respect for the game and for what Robinson accomplished by telling this baseball story through the human drama.
All three parts come together to make "The Place Beyond the Pines" a beautifully shot film... It's the story that fades, and no amount of photography can create enough distraction to overlook those.
The writing is crisp and the acting on target.

Even with its flaws, The Dark Knight Rises is a solid film. It just fails to live up to the magnificent legacy created by the first two movies in the trilogy. To be fair, they were incredibly hard acts to follow.
The movie is fun and colorful, but it doesn't have that creative explosion needed to bring Tintin to life.

Jeff Nichols' script for Mud is a lot like the Mississippi River that serves as a backdrop for the tale of unrequited love. There are times it is big and powerful and other times when it becomes so serene it's easy to forget the depths that hide below.
At least when Moe hit Curly in the head with a hammer it wasn't the re-creation of a real crime.
Firth's performance alone would have been enough to hail this film by director Dante Ariola. Toss in an equally powerful performance by Blunt, and the film turns to a masterwork of acting.
[Redford] still manages to tell an interesting story of family painted against a political backdrop. It's not going to spark any great movements, but it is worth a sit in at the local theater.

Those who enjoy comic-book-inspired films merely for the action will find this latest attempt a solid effort. But comic book purists will have to deal with seeing less Iron Man and some twists that defy the accepted mythology of Marvel Comics.
There's no way to see this film and not be concerned each time an electronic device is used. That kind of visceral reaction is what makes the film so disturbingly brilliant.
Strip away the commentary Fitzgerald made on the era and all you have is a love story with the depth of a Nicholas Sparks romance novel.
Don't let this film's faith-based themes keep you from going to see the movie. Even if you ignore the message, the movie stands up simply as a good family-based drama.
As long as Abrams is in charge, the new Star Trek movies will live long and prosper.
Fast & Furious 6 is a fun summer thrill ride as long as director Justin Lin keeps the pedal to the metal in the action scenes.
A fine line exists between forgivable drug-induced actions and just being unforgivingly mean.
Any tension is lost in the director's achingly slow pacing.
The key to any good piece of entertainment is to be as entertaining at the end as in the beginning. Now You See Me is more like Now You Don't when it comes to a big finish.
DeMonaco strikes a nice balance between the message and the mayhem as he bounces between the philosophical demons inside the Sandin home and the sadistic demons waiting outside.
Man of Steel isn't a flop. Nor does it go up, up and away. As far as movie relaunches go, this one's OK.
Olympus Has Fallen may be opening in the spring, but it's such a blast that it could still be in theaters when the summer films hit.
Buried under all the comedy misdirection and emotional sleight of hand is the potential for a good movie. It's a potential that's never fulfilled.
The last third of the movie is where it turns into a complete wrong number.
Did we need another Die Hard? No. But as long as the action is this intense and superficially fun, then keep them coming.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: What elevates the movie is the solid performances by Kristoffer Polaha and David DeSanctis.
A muddled story.
The natural adrenaline rush of auto racing is replaced by sputtering melodrama.
Unfortunately, the script is bad compared to the technology.
Stiller attempts to turn bikini-size material into a maxi-length coat. All that does is create a product full of holes.
The Hughes brothers have managed to make a period film that has such a modern feel, the terror seems all too real.
13 Ghosts never plays fair with the audience.
Out Cold is destined to live on as a constant of late-night cable film.
Save yourself a few dollars. Stay home and watch reruns of Home Improvement.
This is a not a celebration of the boxing champ's life but a kind of gloomy eulogy that seems to have been compiled by strangers.
[Reynolds] takes a classic story, casts attractive and talented actors and uses a magnificent landscape to create a feature film that is wickedly fun to watch.
So putrid it is not worth the price of the match that should be used to burn every print of the film.
Before Midnight is a beautiful reminder that a movie with nothing more than two people talking can have just as many explosions and fireworks as any high-tech summer blockbuster.
Strives for mediocrity and unfortunately succeeds in reaching that less-than-lofty goal.

If your measure of the success of a film is how high the body count goes, then Blade II stacks up to other films in this genre. Those who require more should drive a stake through the heart of any plans to see this sequel.
Sinks so low in a poorly played game of absurd plot twists, idiotic court maneuvers and stupid characters that even Freeman can't save it.
An interesting psychological game of cat-and-mouse, three-dimensional characters and believable performances all add up to a satisfying crime drama.
Unfaithful starts strong, but Lyne's inability to bring the movie to a proper conclusion leaves Unfaithful unresolved, unredeemable and unforgivable.
Hollywood's answer to an air ball.
The film works because it is about a man on a journey who discovers that a strong heart can do more damage than a pair of fists.

Gooding would rather mug for the camera than actually act. The film's young stars don't have the talent to be cast in a fifth grade Christmas pageant. And the script is uninspired and lacking a single bit of humor.
It is a fascinating snapshot of the efforts of those who devoted their lives to solving this haunting mystery.
When it comes to the vehicle of an action movie, Statham is a first-rate mechanic.
The real hero of The Avengers is not Iron Man, Thor or even Nick Fury. It's Joss Whedon.
Lisecki's turned that short into a feature film with the same storyline and actors. Although it's a sweet movie, it's a case of more is not always better.
This all-star cast -- coupled with the crisp and creative script -- makes Seven Psychopaths a film you would be crazy not to see.
A rather average action film that benefits from several funny moments supplied by Epps.
[3 Days To Kill is] an espionage tale, a family drama and 1940s film noir. The problem is the three go together about as well as speed skating and a sandy beach.

Director Marc Forster makes the most of the guns-and-guts direction. World War Z is at its best when the zombies -- a faster moving bunch than the typical lumbering variety -- sweep through the streets.
The Bling Ring sets a new standard for film failure. It's such a mess, the teens should get back together and steal all of the copies of the movie. No court in the land would find them guilty.
What may surprise you is that this film fails not because of the low-brow humor. It's the abysmal filmmaking.
Not even the best of actors can give life to a script that has as much imagination as a rock.
Watching this adaptation of Ender's Game is like looking over the shoulder of someone playing a space video game. It's entertaining for a while, but eventually there needs to be more.
With all the death and destruction going on, there's still time for the kind of light humor that has helped distinguish films based on Marvel Comics characters.
No director/writer has shown a better understanding of the multi-faceted aspects of love than Richard Curtis.
All of this goes together to earn 12 Years a Slave a spot at the top of the list for best pictures released this year.

Catching Fire is a good enough representation of the second book that it won't upset fans. Those who don't know the book will find a film that is a mildly altered version of the first movie in the series.
All of this is good, but it's the performances by Menzel and Bell that make the movie work so well.
Seeing Black Nativity is like an early Christmas gift. The best thing that to say about this powerful story brought to life by a first-rate cast is hallelujah.
In The Book Thief, young Canadian actress Sophie Nélisse finds a way to maintain a vulnerability that creates a natural sympathy for her character, Liesel.
It's a punch-drunk story that wobbles between a family film and an over-the-top action movie that fails to utilize the best parts of either.
Jackson at least delivers an excessive visual spectacular that's stunning to watch while waiting for the end to finally come.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Ferrell and his mirthless band of comics have all bought into the idea that shouting a joke makes it better.
American Hustle is a reminder that it's a privilege to see work that's so masterful.
When "Grudge Match" pokes fun at the fight film genre, it lands some comic blows. It eventually loses the battle on points, though, when the more serious story lines get in the way.
Leto's and McConaughey's work will initially be remembered for their physical transformations. But it's the work they do inside these brittle bodies that is the true strength.
Warm Bodies proves a movie can have a lot of heart even when the heart of one of the characters isn't beating.
This is still an exciting story about competition, but without that stirring moment of humanity that helps sports movies win over the audience, Rush comes up a lap short.
A powerful and engaging story that shows the flaws that make families so interesting. Crazy and interesting.
Jonze has done such a masterful job writing this offbeat love story.
Inside Llewyn Davis hits a few sour notes, but overall it's a successful emotional composition told in very simplistic terms.
Even these name actors don't give it the vocal punch that would make The Nut Job anything to get crazy about.
Labor Day is like a pie with no crust. The filling is good, but it just doesn't hold together.
This is a movie that would be just as entertaining with the sound off. Lord and Miller have so much going on that it's impossible to appreciate it all in one viewing.
The film isn't a masterpiece, but it's a fitting tribute to the men who put their lives on the line in the name of saving culture.
As for Carrie virgins, they get both an entertaining and socially relevant take on the King classic.
Preposterousness, thy name is Rodriguez.

Greengrass makes the pirates sympathetic, but he never does it to the point of justifying their actions. That makes Captain Phillips a taut tale -- one that will make you feel like you booked passage on the ship.

Gravity doesn't travel any new ground with the space story. It just takes what has become standard and powers it into the cinema stratosphere with visuals that can't be fully appreciated in a single viewing and a story that is full of emotional fireworks.
This movie's loaded with enough action and animated fun that it will keep young viewers amused. Disappointing is the fact that after so many years, the story doesn't live up to the technology.
The majority of the project moves at a smooth pace driven by the symbiotic relationships between McCarthy's energetic and Bullock's controlled performances.
Verbinski's movies have a bloated feeling, as shown in each Pirates movie. The action sequences in The Lone Ranger would have been even more exciting if Verbinski had cut at least 30 minutes.
Comedy works best when there's a constant stream of good material that has some degree of consistency. This movie starts at a juvenile level and regresses from there.
Pacific Rim isn't bad. It's just that del Toro's attempt to go from a visionary weaver of fantasy to a merchant of summer schlock feels as mechanical as the giant Rock 'Em Sock 'Em Robots.
If there had been no Red, Red 2 would not have been as disappointing.
[Turbo] is a victim of bad timing, uninspired animation and voice talents that range from perfect to perfectly awful.

The Conjuring doesn't have the big special effects of its summer competition, but it is an old-fashioned scary movie that uses every dark corner as a source of scream-inducing frights. Don't see this movie by yourself.
This will be the only time you can have this much fun with mixed drinks and not need a designated driver.
You would have to go way, way back to find a film as touching, funny and smart as this one.
Brandy, the nerdish character who wants to lose her virginity, is unlikable, annoying, grating and so unpleasant, there's no reason to care whether she will or won't.
These four strangers who are pretending to be a family hate each other at the start. You get three guesses as to how the film ends and odds are high you'll only need one.

The East is the kind of movie that will alienate those who only see the world in black-and-white terms. It is about people who live in the gray, between light and dark, that's played out and written with great power by Marling.

Not every demographic will embrace it, but it should find a solid audience with younger movie fans. Older moviegoers who are tired of this summer's action films with dark tones can find some light relief with Percy and the gang.
When you can see every twist coming, the turns aren't exciting.
The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones should please fans of the books. Others should consider one of the other films that make up this genre.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Unlike so many horror films, You're Next doesn't cheat with the script for the sake of the action.
Jasmine's ride is not nearly as dramatic as Blanche DuBois' emotional deconstruction in Streetcar, but her journey is made tolerable by an Oscar-worthy performance by Cate Blanchett.
Crowley's deft ability to build suspense is Hitchcockian in nature, from the explosive opening to the unexpected ending.

There's nothing that's going to replace being with thousands of screaming One Direction fans at a concert. But Spurlock offers an exceptional surrogate with this film. In the world of concert movies, One Direction: This Is Us is top of the charts.
Ponsoldt has created a coming-of-age movie that won't leave you rolling your eyes.
Derbez, who also directed the film, gives the movie a strong core through his expressive face.
movie_title: No se aceptan devoluciones (Instructions Not Included) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A brutal -- and occasionally funny -- look at what it's like to live with an addiction that's treated with disdain.
Directors Cody Cameron and Kris Pearn give the film the frantic pace and bright colors needed to keep the attention of kids. Adults who are looking for more will be left cold.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's no way you will fall in love with Baggage Claim, but there's a good chance you'll like it.
The biggest problem is Jon. He's unlikable from the start and never improves.

Planes isn't going to join the pantheon of great animated Disney movies, but when it comes to light entertainment, it takes off smoothly, glides along on a sweet script and lands softly on a nice message.
Like a beautiful song, Tedesco weaves together the history, personal stories and tributes by well-known performers like Cher, Nancy Sinatra and Mickey Dolenz.
While the plot of Argo sounds too unbelievable to be true, this fact-based story ends up as both compelling and as exciting as any adventure James Bond ever had.

It helps that the script by David Nicholls captures much of the beauty and ugliness of the Hardy novel. Vinterberg then put together the right cast to create a first-rate adaptation that gets an additional boost from the stunning English setting.

The last quarter of La La Land is so beautifully shot and performed, it makes up for the flat opening. It becomes a film that embraces a world where dreamers may seem foolish but eventually are very interesting.
The entire movie resonates with an authenticity that stems from Portman's performance. From the wardrobe to the re-creation of historical moments, there are no shortcuts taken.

A more personal approach would have elevated Patriots Day from a solid effort to retell a familiar story to a deep and moving reminder of the kind of personal damage that comes with this kind of tragedy.
The majority of Silence is a deeply moving story of faith, where unlike most movies in the genre, there are no clear answers.
Touching and well-crafted.
It's a shame A Dog's Purpose doesn't have more of a purpose than as a melodramatic mess.

The movie is enough fun that it will be a good one to buy on DVD. That's the only way to enjoy all the jokes and see the massive amount of characters who populate this latest brick-built world from LEGO.
This is pure entertainment that is entertaining because Reeves plays the character with never wavering sincerity.
It makes for a film that doesn't take chances, but at least Mastretta knows how to pick a likable cast. That's particularly true with Souza who should be cast in more romances.
This movie is such a complete dud that even the bloopers over the closing credits are as funny as a puppy's funeral.
Visually, The Great Wall has some beautiful moments although nothing looks that original.
Get Out is best enjoyed by getting to watch the tale unfold without knowing where the plot is going.
Director Ash Brannon finds a nice blend of music, adventure and comedy that he presents with a couple of different animation styles.
You're Killing Me Susana is one of the purest love stories to come along in years.
movie_title: You're Killing Me Susana (Me estás matando Susana) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a faith-based movie that uses a heavy hand to pound viewers with its religious messages. That's a shame because when the film isn't preaching, the story of how someone deals with great loss is touching and moving.
Logan gets its strength from its heartpounding action scenes and its heart-breaking personal moments.

It would have been easy for one of these plot threads to strangle the other, but the crisp writing, strong direction by Amma Asante plus Oscar-worthy performances by Oyelowo and Pike make each story support the other.

Whether it's Baldwin speaking or the readings done by Samuel L. Jackson, I Am Not Your Negro pulls no punches. It's painful for a society that declares itself to be educated to be forced to look at how ignorant it has been and remains.
The latest attempt to do a live-action version of an animated film, Beauty and the Beast, is neither stunning nor dazzling. It is little more than a mediocre production.
One day, there will be the time to look back at MacLaine's career and this film will help recall her work fondly even in a movie that has so many writing problems.
If only one of his efforts would have shown any signs of the talent Shepard has revealed in past work, CHIPs would have risen from abysmal to merely awful.
Although familiar in concept, Life has strong performances, a willingness to take chances, a beautifully designed set and plenty of tension.
Power Rangers won't have you seeing red, feeling blue or in the pink. It's just nostalgic fun that would have improved with a better villain and less on-screen merchandising.
The Boss Baby is like a diaper. It starts out fresh but it sure doesn't take long for it to become a stinker.
The film is the latest to look at the evils committed during World War II but feels fresh because Caro keeps the focus on small moments.
Washington's work as director and actor along with the amazing cast delivers Wilson's story in a proper and impressive style.
This holiday movie would have to improve 1,000 fold to reach the level of merely being awful.
You know there are big problems when even Pratt and Lawrence can't do enough to save the day. They are set afloat in a story that lacks even the smallest bit of gravity.
Although it continuously slips into being overly sentimental, it's hard not to be pulled in by the film's tale of love, loss and the time it takes to deal with both.

Frears works at a frantic pace to get Jenkins from one failed performance to the next. This gives Streep a lot of moments of musical misfortunes but they are delivered in such a helter-skelter manner that each seems little different than the one before.
First-time director Travis Knight, who was the lead animator on Laika's previous three films, presents the story with a beautifully fluid style.
War Dogs suffers the same problems as other movies about arms dealers have faced: No matter how good the writing or performances, there is a dark cloud hanging overhead.
[Hell or High Water] rides superb writing, Oscar-caliber performances and a serious social message to such grandeur as to make it one of the best pictures of 2016.
Writer Amy Fox manages to find a nice balance between the financial and personal stories.
The director offers a compelling look into the Arab world, including the struggle for survival in a landscape scarred by decades of fighting.
Most of all, it is a beautiful tribute both of a filmmaker to a subject and a son to his father.

Blair Witch is nothing but a pale imitation of The Blair Witch Project -- void of all creativity and originality. It's so bad, it manages what should have been impossible and is far worse than Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2.
A moving and emotional production.
It has been such a strong year for animation that it would take a movie with nearly flawless voice casting, story and animation to stand out in the crowd. Storks is a definite standout.
What makes the movie so entertaining is how Berberian and Pirhamzei, who also directed the movie, show that the pitfalls of filmmakers are universal.
If you can get past the places where the new movie fails to match the original, it's a Western that shoots straight.
It's taken 20 years to get an update on the guys. But the film proves that the pish and vinegar that made the characters so much fun doesn't weaken with time.
The Hollars" follows a very predictable storyline but the journey is made far more interesting by a first-rate cast.
You don't have to ask a Ouija board about the quality of this failed attempt at horror. If you did, it would spell out S T I N K E R.
Inferno should have been a blazing mystery driven by the sparks of two solid actors. Instead, it lacks the heat of good writing to create any cinematic sizzle.
American Pastoral is as powerful as any movie that uses war as a catalyst for the story. It shows that emotional scars can be created in a myriad of ways.

Even when the movie gets massively visual, it never gets away from the central strength of Cumberbatch's performance. That's not easy to do, but accomplishing the task is why Doctor Strange is pure Marvel magic.
If you are looking for a fantastic movie and don't know where to find one, look no further than "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them."
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Just like the Spruce Goose, the Beatty film is beautiful when it lifts off, but it fails to soar.
Disney should be applauded for adding more diversity to their Princess court. Those good intentions can only mask a few errors and can't bandage the clunky script.
In general, Allied gets strong marks for the chemistry between Pitt and Cotillard, plus the beautiful visuals created by Zemeckis.
There are plenty of opportunities in the story for the film to take a brutal edge, but Nichols keeps the film focused on the emotional elements.
The script by Johnny Rosenthal and Shauna Cross will make you uncomfortable and embarrassed at your laughter. It's OK.

Gyllenhaal is so compelling to watch as a wounded author and broken husband/father, and Adams can sell sadness with a simple look. Shannon turns in yet another brilliant performance as the one person who thinks revenge is overrated.
The Force is strong with this film -- a perfect fit as a prequel to A New Hope.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A powerful and personal story.
Sausage Party has plenty of funny moments, especially for fans of lowbrow humor.
Your Name is a beautifully crafted story of love, loss, desperation and hope brought to the screen with visual splendor.
The film's not Smurfless but it's not as Smurftastic as it should have been.
These young performers manage to play their characters as heroes, while never relinquishing the elements that make them seem like the kids next door.
[Writer/director Paul Shoulberg] never shies away from the religious aspects of the story but at the same time gives the film enough air from outside the church to give the tale wider appeal.
... "American Assassin" gets the job done in a very real feeling world.
[Lena] Khan has directed Pudi into such a passive approach to the character that there are no sparks whether it be the sweet love story or the cockeyed corporate world shenanigans.
[Judi Dench's] acting gravitas is strong enough to make even the lightest of stories automatically feel like they have more girth.
... the most visually stimulating feature film to be released in years.
Anyone looking to enjoy some scares while trying to figure out a very clever mystery should plan on seeing Happy Death Day.
"Geostorm" finds ways to draw attention away from an interesting use of weather as a weapon by using a cold front of political jabber.
"Only the Brave" is a heart-touching reminder of what real heroes look like and how they act.

It's the same kind of uncensored imagery that comes from home movies but these images were captured by one of the greatest nature photographers in a world of flora and fauna just an apple tree away from being an Eden.
... seeing "Thor: Ragnarok" is like riding the world's fastest and tallest roller coaster that keeps looping through a funhouse.
"Wonder" is a movie that should be shown to young and old as a life lesson in how to deal with people who appear to be different.
The only person who truly understands the right way to play a comic book hero is Gadot.

It not only offers a fresh look at the familiar ghost story, but it also has a lot to say about the good in humans if they will only stop trying to suppress it. God bless the filmmakers, one and all, for creating such a treat.
You know the writing is solid when animated characters can touch your heart so deeply that a tissue is needed.
James Franco has placed enough links to the original film that his based-on-fact look at the making of The Room is weirdly fun on its own and one of the most creative films of the year.

It's a salute to the strength of the human spirit as presented by three phenomenal performers playing out a touching and unforgettable story that solidifies Linklater's place among the best directors working today.
The real tragedy is that not every film from Allen is as good as "Wonder Wheel."
The film is a massively muddled mess of ideas that might have made more of an impact if Matt Damon's performance wasn't so painfully bland.
This one is a real blast.
It's one of the better movies about murder, manipulation and celebrity since Gus Van Sant's 1995 feature To Die For.

Unlike a Tony Stark who can entertain with his dry wit or Captain America who dazzles with his passion for patriotism, Boseman must play both T'Challa as a man of great reserve. He's a warrior, but one who rules the screen with a quiet calm.
Looking at "Early Man" as a whole, it combines weirdly funny comedy with a sweet story about what it means to depend on others.

Game Night is like playing Monopoly where the only properties are the four railroads. The players can go through the motions, but without more elements the overall result is good but far from as great as it could have been.
This script could have used a few less dreamers and a couple more realists to make a solid series of elements fit better together.
At its gooey center, "I Do ... Until I Don't" is like vanilla cake. It is sweet, but generally there's nothing that memorable about it.
Even if Jackals had been a direct-to-video release, it would have fallen into the category of "rent something else."

Even if Terminator 2: Judgment Day had only been re-released in theaters to mark the 26th anniversary without any enhancements, the quality of the production would make it still worth the price of admission
Beach Rats is presented in such a no-frills way that there are more moments than not when it feels like it has slipped into full documentary mode.

Farhadi masterfully moves between the real world and the stage production. Not only does this give him parallel points to play with but also offers a compelling look at how an American classic is seen through the eyes of others around the world.
Overall, from strong acting to a well-crafted script, everything adds up to make Gifted work.
It's all about how furious the action scenes can be, and those are supercharged.
The movie serves as a heartrending memorial to a people who persevered even in the face of some of the most inhumane actions in history.
Unforgettable is very forgettable.

The best thing Gunn has going for him is that even when he gets off the best beat for the movie, his cast is so talented and breathes so much life into their roles that they can cover up any small dark holes in this Galaxy.
Best-case scenario with Snatched is that you are kidnapped and taken from the theater during a screening. Worst case is you are kidnapped and forced to watch this total mess.

Dead Men shows life when there are big action scenes. If 30 minutes of jumbled mythology and cheesy writing had been cut, the movie would have had an action beat as driving as the heart-pounding score by Geoff Zanelli.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The important thing is that while the production never reaches for intellectual grandeur, it is on a very basic level one of the funniest movies of the year.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Elliot not only conveys complicated emotions with just a look from that expressive face but his deep voice sounds like the echoes of decades of life resonating off the walls of time.
Baby Driver is filled with fascinating characters who could all be the focus of their own movies.
One of the best romantic comedies to hit theaters in a decade.
Going in Style is at its best when the three main stars are allowed to go at the story with the style and grace that has made them acting treasures.
There was a feeling of doom that enveloped the original... Coppola fails to find that same energy and any connection to the war being waged outside the walls is vague at best.
It works because Brie, Micucci and Plaza attack the roles with unbridled energy.
A word of warning. The Little Hours is an assault on conventional religious thinking that will most likely shock those who expect this movie to show any respect toward the Church.
The third film is more like a series of different vignettes more intent on introducing new characters than capitalizing on what made the first two movies work.
It's pretty and sweet, but there's little inside.
There's a pure honesty to Noxon's story and direction that makes "To the Bone" a tale of despair and promise, gain and loss, horror and hope.

Visually, French director Luc Besson's Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets is tres magnifique. When it comes to the story, the film is what Pepe Le Pew would call a "le cinema avec grand stinker."
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The real problem is the story. It has enough bits and pieces of action and drama to work as a graphic novel. But it's not enough to make this movie a roller coaster ride.
The action is good, but that only makes up slightly for all of the writing problems. A list of those miscues could be stacked up to make their own impressive dark tower.
It's Larson's performance that gives the film both its touches of hopefulness and brushes with total frustration that binds all of the emotional threads.
[Jackson and Reynolds] are so good at handling this kind of verbal sparring that they make up for the weakness in both the direction and writing.
Stanfield's performance is the solid foundation for the film.
The film is still loaded with strong special effects and a must-have soundtrack. This makes the sequel good but lacks the element of surprise that made the original film so much fun.
All of these elements unfold in more a stream-of-thought manner than real design. And Waterhouse turns in a solid performance.
Even [Robbie's] performance can't counter the painfully slow start, steady flood of trite action scenes and a convoluted story that would have to improve tenfold to be even passable.

Although Dunkirk looks at one of the most amazing military/civil operations of World War II (or maybe of any military conflict in history), it's not a war movie. It's Christopher Nolan's view of a war movie.

Captain Fantastic is a deep examination of parenting, family, excess, isolationism, hope and the challenge of making the right decisions.Most importantly, this is a movie that asks the viewer to think.
The film does a masterful job of spotlighting the music. Even when the musical style changes -- often taking on a modern sound -- the power of the words and religious significance is never lost.

The way [Depp] plays Bulger, where even a touch of his hand to a woman's face is more threatening than a gun placed to an informant's head, goes beyond the normal bounds of acting. This is greatness unfolding in front of our eyes.
If Addicted to Fresno was a narcotic, it would be a baby aspirin.
If you don't guess the big twist in this story by 15 minutes into the film, you fell asleep at 10 minutes.
"East Side Sushi" writer-director Anthony Lucero shows that subtle differences between cultures can be presented with great respect and concern.
The spookiest thing about Hotel Transylvania 2 is how much funnier, colorful and original it is this second time around.

It does redeem itself in the final 40 minutes, but it still may be best to wait and see the movie at home where you can turn down Gordon-Levitt's exasperating narration and just look at the magic that comes when one man defies gravity.

Aram, Aram works on a variety of levels, but the core strength comes from the very personal story of a grandfather and a grandson looking for answers in a world that just keeps giving them more things to question.
It's a mishmash of ideas that aren't bad. They just aren't that good either.
Just like Malala, He Named Me Malala delivers its message with quiet power that makes it the most powerful and important film to be released this year.
It's a film that's as much fun as it is creepy. It can't survive under the harsh scrutiny of horror film experts, but it is mildly chilling enough to scare youngsters.
The pacing by director del Toro is so slow that by the time a ghost does show up, it's more apt to wake the audience than scare them.
Director Baltasar Kormákur takes moviegoers on a journey that is so spectacularly beautiful and terrifying that it's the closest thing to making the journey up the mountain without going to Nepal.
The real star of The Prophet is the animation. The visuals make this a film a craft of art that also has spiritual uplifting of words.

Our Brand Is Crisis is like a third-party candidate who enters a race in the final weeks. Any good qualities just don't get exposed and the candidate gets lost in the pack no matter how much manipulation is happening.
Until this misstep, Craig had been one of the top actors to play the British spy. His lack of energy, coupled with the long list of other miscues, leaves Spectre bland, very bland.

It is smart, fun and offers some strong messages without being preachy. That is the framework Schulz established when he introduced the comic strip. The best thing that can be said is you're in a very good film, Charlie Brown.

Mulligan turns in a strong performance, going from a woman who has quietly resigned herself to a certain life to a woman who is willing to speak out for others. It's a transition that comes slowly, and it feels real.
Despite a valiant effort by the actors, The 33 had the major mountain of familiarity to overcome. Everyone tries, but they just can't do enough to get viewers to the emotional peak.
Despite all of the ills, there is something satisfying about getting to the end of this film franchise.
John Crowley creates a hauntingly beautiful tale of love on two continents in his period film Brooklyn.
This adaptation of the Oscar-winning movie shows that improvements can be made even with a product that is already first-rate.

It all comes together to make The Night Before a fun hybrid of a raunchy buddy comedy and a sweet holiday movie. This is a hard combination to blend but Levine pulls it off by keeping a nice balance between the naughty and nice.
It is weighed down by a flawed concept, unappealing characters and a soundtrack that lacks anything close to a memorable tune.
Creed is a reboot of the franchise and follows a very similar structure to the original movie. To that end, the movie repeatedly falls short.
Mother Teresa's life was so inspiring that even a film that tells her story at only about 75 percent of its potential still delivers a heavy spiritual punch.
The Last Witch Hunter manages to be both overly complicated and painfully predictable at the same time.

Nowar's story and locations carry the viewer along a journey of life and death. His pacing allows for the emotions associated with both to be absorbed and digested completely. It is a film journey well worth taking.

Mistress America has enough bumps and bruises to keep it from being a superhero among comedy-drama movies, but it's not from a lack of trying by Gerwig. Her energy's enough to take a chance on this film.
The drama gets in the way of the action, while the comedy disrupts the drama.
Hard to recommend a product when you can buy a whole season of the series for less than the price of a movie ticket.
Osborne's take on The Little Prince shows a reverence for the original story, plus an understanding of what modern audiences want with a more linear story and bright animation.
The best comedy about international crime fighting since the heyday of Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery.
A fun and chilling creep show that is more concerned with scares than being gross.
This action film set against the months leading up to the Revolutionary War has the same strong visual effects, story and action sequences of films with 10 times the budget.
Director Colin Trevorrow shows a steady hand at building up the tension and then releasing it with great force.
While there are parts of Wild Tales that prove more interesting than others, the overall package is consistent enough that it becomes a fun ride.
A beautiful and smart coming-of-old-age film.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is the first feature film role for Moore and he delivers a performance that is sweet, smart, naive and -- when needed -- tough. His performance comes across as strong as many veteran actors.
Pixar's latest successful blend of fun elements for kids and smarts for adults.

The sequel is so haphazardly put together that it lacks the juvenile charm, weird wit and creative comedy that made the original movie work. What's left is a comedy that's thin on laughs and wobbly in construction.
What elevates it are the fun, warm and very real performance by the young cast. They make the journey one worth remembering.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The real star is the script.
If you are looking for a film suitable for almost all ages, then sit, stay and watch Max.
Terminator Genisys is the best re-launch of a solid-gold franchise since J.J. Abrams kick-started Star Trek. Here's hoping the director and cast will all be back for more films.
[Faith of Our Fathers] gets high points for good intentions but loses most of them for execution.
Self/less is built around the idea that one person's thoughts and memories can be transplanted into a better body. It would have been nice to have had a better plot transplanted into this film.
The charm and humor they brought in tiny doses in the previous films now comes in a massive blast that wears thin quickly.
It hasn't been that long since her death, but Amy feels timeless, partly because of Winehouse's intoxicating sound and partly because her tale has become an unfortunate norm in the creative world.

The combination of a solid story, good acting efforts from the young cast and enough logical use of the hand-held cameras helps The Gallows rise above the flat fodder that is often seen in this format.

Although set in a specific time and place, the film's message about human life is universal. And director/writer Zaza Urushadze makes his points without being heavy handed, overt or politically demonstrative.
Director Peyton Reed tries to piece it together but there's just no way to make the scenes with Rudd seem like anything more than a rejected Saturday Night Live skit.
Pixels ends up having too many glitches to make it worth your quarters.
Vacation is an endless journey of foul jokes, uninspired humor and predictable material. This is a rare occasion where it's possible to get car sick while sitting in a movie theater.

Shaun the Sheep Movie proves silence can be golden if the story is laced with enough solid jokes and presented with a flock of clever characters. The beautiful craftsmanship of this film speaks for itself.

Edgerton has created a movie that respects the intelligence of the audience. He's created an ending that will spark debates and that's a blessing in the summer plot doldrums where everything gets wrapped up with a loud bang or big scare.

It's one thing to linger on a scene and another to have it play so long there's time to go to the lobby for a snack and get back before it ends. This is a story about high energy dancing presented at a half-speed pace.
Howard charts a dramatic course through a sea of emotional whirlpools, tidal waves of stunning special effects and a steady current provided by the narration.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Watching the documentary Ballet 422 is like standing in front of a Picasso without knowing anything about the artist, the subject or the context. The work is beautiful but a little more knowledge would bring a lot more depth to what is being viewed.
The result is a film that has a good heart but no strong humor.
The Jungle Book gives more than the bare necessities when it comes to the elements that make a movie special.

Marshall uses the same formula of blending together multiple story lines for his light comedy Mother's Day, but this time has better defined the plot and embraced the emotion. It's not perfect, but it's a sweet Mother's Day gift.
Ratchet & Clank is an energetic, animated and colorful trip down memory lane aimed at the blurry-eyed fans who have carpal tunnel syndrome from all those hours playing the game.
Toss in a few secrets revealed and Captain America: Civil War kicks off the summer movie season with a punch strong enough to make the Hulk's head spin.
Money Monster" isn't solid gold, but it is worth the investment to see the rich acting work by Clooney and O'Connell and the solid direction by Foster.
The only saving grace is that it should keep anyone under the age of 6 entertained. Of course, you can do the same thing with the video game.
This sequel proves as unlikable as the original.

The concept is solid and Black's formula for this kind of film has worked before. Where The Good Guys goes astray is in Black's decision to downplay the '70s as fodder for his script and the casting of Gosling as the quirky private detective.

Hollywood is always going to lean toward youth, especially with women. It's wonderful that when given a chance, mature female actors can show they are the most capable at playing complex roles that come across in a very simple way.
The original Alice in Wonderland had problems, but it now looks like a classic compared to all of the miscues and misfires of Alice Through the Looking Glass.

It takes a tour de force performance to stand out in a film that features compelling performances by Tilda Swinton, Matthias Schoenaerts and Dakota Johnson. They are so good that even when Fiennes is not on screen, the quality never waivers.
The story has a purity when it comes to love. It is definitely the kind of movie that should be seen with someone special.
The comedy remains strong, even with the addition of an extreme topic. In fact, it does just the opposite by giving the film an added texture.

The movie's uninspired plot about a rapper who struggles with his second album has enough material to fill a three-minute sketch on Saturday Night Live. And even then, there would be about a minute of failed comedy.
It's not perfect. But it is a lot of fun, especially because of Ruffalo and Caplan, who bring very different but equally strong elements to the movie.

Warcraft has achieved a lofty goal: There hasn't been a movie as unrelentingly bad since Jupiter Ascending managed to surpass the bloated and pitiful Battlefield Earth as the worst big budget science-fiction film of all time.
The main reason the movie works is the chemistry between Johnson and Hart. They are like Bud Abbott and Lou Costello on steroids.

The tension the director/writer has infused in the story is relentless. It's just the unnecessary efforts to make the story bigger, coupled with a predictable plot, that leave it the least compelling of the Purge movies.
The Legend of Tarzan is not the king of jungle movies, but it is presented with such royal reverence that some people will go ape over it.

This mildly amusing adventure story will both entertain young moviegoers with its dazzling color scheme and scare them with some intense moments. It has a bit of charm, but it is not enough to keep a tight leash on parents.
This comes to life through another amazing performance by Bryan Cranston.
This reboot is a spirited effort that ends up a pale specter of the original in the end.

Sell all your stocks immediately and invest in companies that make candles, flashlights, light bulbs or anything else that creates illumination. There's going to be a run on those items with the release of Lights Out.

With The Force Awakens, Abrams got to build a whole new universe on a base of returning favorites. No character is stronger, though, than Rey (Daisy Ridley), who is the central player in the new story.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It all comes down to how beautifully Lumley and Saunders bring their characters to life. They have had so many years to play the roles that they come across as more of a second skin than an acting job.
From action to aliens, Star Trek Beyond combines the legacy of the franchise with contemporary visual effects to create a production that should live long and prosper.
It's a movie that latches on to your entertainment soul with a complexity that can't be dislodged, for better or worse.
Every beat of [Kevin Costner's] performance works. It's just a shame that nothing else about this movie is as original or interesting.

Once again, the movie's strength is in the way Wan plays out the scary moments. He takes safe and special items, like a child's toys, and uses them as instruments of terror. This works so well because an audience can relate to the simple items.

Hello, My Name Is Doris is aimed at an older audience, but Field's performance has so much youthful energy that it ends up being a broader story of the first buds of love that, like Doris, would be acceptable and entertaining with any crowd.
Lawrence never falters, even when the script does.

More of a push by director Tom Hooper to place this story in the real world where it unfolded would have added to the power. But that doesn't distract from the two memorable acting performances by Redmayne and Vikander.

Hardcore Henry thrives on its original design and copycats will just be pale imitations. The only thing they could do better is write better dialogue, more plot, better characters and at least one scene that makes logical sense.
The biggest problem with Concussion is that it takes the less interesting approach to a fascinating subject.
If you are an extreme sports junkie, Point Break is cocaine. If you are a fan of good writing, it's a placebo.
Director Todd Haynes has created in "Carol" a world so rich in texture, design and mood that it is easy to fall into its loving arms of emotions and get enveloped in its story of love and loss.
The movie... is so engaging there are times when it becomes almost overwhelming. But that is a glowing sign of how well the movie is acted and put together.
It is as compelling as it is frightening.
Hollywood uses the phrase "based on" so that it can amplify the story as needed. It's a valiant effort, but it never fully rescues the film.
Not only do the genres co-exist, they manage to pump up each other to the point the film is both a sweet and endearing romance while also being a thoroughly entertaining action movie.

It all ends up being familiar pieces of the kind of stories Sparks tells so well. He's found the right formula of creating likable people, pushing them together and then creating a crisis that will either make or break their love.

How To Be Single is a wonderful surprise. It takes a high road in both comedy and story that makes it work on multiple levels. More comedies that focus on one gender should pay attention to this movie. The cast and crew deliver from start to finish.
If you are willing to accept a superpowered character who spits at superhero conventions, then Deadpool is a (expletive deleted) good time.
Not since "The Grand Budapest Hotel' has a film blended so smoothly the elements of fact and fantasy with a quirky and whimsical cast as "Youth."
Its haunting effect comes from how Eggers uses this family as a vessel for serving up a fear that rests in the netherworld between reality and the unchained mind.

Even if the idea of a religious movie leaves you cold, the film is still incredibly moving because it's a reminder of the strength parents must have and how life is made up of small acts of kindness that happen on a daily basis.
Where To Invade Next isn't Moore's best, but even when he shows a newfound restraint the filmmaker's work always generates conversation.

A relentless barrage of over-the-top violence, video game style battles and special effects that will knock the cup of afternoon tea right out of your hand... this film is the stuff dreams of action movie fans are made of.
The bigger problem is that the franchise is moving further and further away from the elements that made the first film passable.

When the new animated movie focuses on the critters, it's a funny trip through the animal kingdom. What slows the ark (oops, make that arc) of the film is a crime story that's in need of a few more monkeyshines.
At its heart, the promised battled between the DC titans has some punch. The blow is just softened considerably by worthless plot points that take the super out of superhero.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's like a dud hand grenade in that at first glance it looks like it could blast but soon it's clear there's no pop.
Gods of Egypt is the most epic sun-and-sand disaster since Elizabeth Taylor almost broke 20th Century-Fox with her 1963 film Cleopatra.
It presents some horrible truths about mankind with a power and grace. The film's messages are powerful and beautifully conveyed.

Risen uses the Bible as a basis for a story about finding faith. As long as you look at the movie from that perspective, then it will accomplish its purpose of creating dialogue about being a believer.
The Bronze is the worst sports comedy since "The Benchwarmers.
The climax, a 20-minute dramatization of the crucial contest, lacks both suspense and poetry -- essentially, we're left to watch a clumsy recreation of a game whose outcome we already know.
I confess to a deep uncertainty about whether this can be rightly called a movie. A bunch of scenes, maybe.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The children are engaging yet the script and direction are not.
A film about youthful passion -- for sex, for politics, for music and, above all, for film itself -- that feels passionless.

What if on my way to the screening, something had intervened -- a runaway bus, a lightning bolt -- to prevent me from ever seeing this movie. How would my life have changed? Would I have become a happier, a kinder, a less bitter and disappointed man?
Even among the ranks of the diminutive, this one's got nothing to boast about.
A splatter of scenes that relocate the funny-bone in the lower anatomical regions -- sometimes hitting the mark, occasionally a glancing blow, often missing completely.
It's always rather sad to watch gifted performers stranded in a tepid thriller.
