movie_review_blurb: Word is Ferrell got the idea for the film one night while watching a documentary on the male dominated world of 70s television news. His fans should thank their lucky stars the comedian happened to catch it.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Who would've guessed the guy who gave us Money Talks, Rush Hour and The Family Man had what it takes to realize a thriller as smartly effective as this?
Think Mean Girls rewritten by Joe Piscopo.
Not since the days when Joel Silver ruled Hollywood and musclebound subliterates vied for supremacy on the big screen has the industry spawned a phenomenon as garish and confounding as Vin Diesel.
Not a great movie but a nice time and a welcome break from the season's nonstop torrent of interchangeable horror films and Ashton Kutcher comedies.
It's Zwick who fails to take care of business here.
Offers a frills-free meditation on the many faces of oppression.

The reality is that Hollywood is such an idea poor place Kaufman tends to get more credit than he deserves for work which only occasionally rises above the level of mind games and showy sleight of hand.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Life may or may not be everything it's cracked up to be. This movie most definitely is.
Mann's taxi driver saga may not quite reach the level of art but, anyway you cut it, it's anything but standard fare.
This is a major blast of fast-talking, loopily plotted, politically incorrect film fun.
Destined to rank among the Coens' least memorable achievements.
Rare is the motion picture which grapples with issues this provocative and profound. Rarer still is one which does so this well.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This is one of the finest films -- foreign or otherwise -- to come along in years.
An affecting work of compassionate craftsmanship.
movie_title: The Letter: An American Town and the 'Somali Invasion' (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Black and Stiller have an appealing chemistry.
As it is, [Petersen] doesn't just fall short of The Iliad. He makes you want to run out and rent Gladiator.
Ramsey's heartbreak, stock taking and determination to see to it the relationship gets a second chance are as affecting as anything the genre has produced in recent memory.
Serves up heaping helpings of everything fans loved about the first.
Beyond any contention is Morgan Spurlock's gift for metabolizing common knowledge into uncommonly entertaining cinema.
A sweet natured, uplifting experience whose faults are few and forgivable and whose pleasures come in all sizes.
A silly comic book movie with provocative psychological overtones. Or a provocative character study with silly comic book overtones.
With the western and Arab worlds increasingly at one another's throats, the sliver of hope for finding common ground this film provides is nothing short of a revelation.
The picture fires on all pistons.
A-by-the-numbers action film retrofitted as a sci-fi work of art.
For a big dumb production about a movie monster smackdown, Alien vs. Predator is a surprisingly good time.
It's a triumph of chills on the cheap that delivers its gut punch of terror by slowly but surely immersing distinctly everyday characters into the unthinkable.
Over the top, improbable, as cheesy as stuffed crust pizza and immensely entertaining.
Crosses the line between offering mindless entertainment and insulting our intelligence.
The end result, while satisfying, is a picture one might quite fairly describe as Notting Hill Lite.
The risks firefighters take, like the sacrifices they make every day, are all too real. They deserve our thanks, our respect and infinitely better movie treatment than this.
There's no excuse for a big budget Hollywood production having as many holes and loose ends as this one.
Unusually well drawn characters and the empathy its creators have for them are just two of the things that distinguish Peter (Very Bad Things) Berg's latest from most sports movies.
It is in fact consistently adequate and, in places, achieves nothing short of above-averageness.
Over the top, improbable, as cheesy as stuffed crust pizza and immensely entertaining.
It's a mess, an all over the place, everything but the kitchen sink jamboree of potty humor, cheap shots and missed opportunities.
While the director may have ambition to admire and career-risking courage to respect, the sad truth is his new movie has almost nothing to heart.
What is incredible in The Incredibles is the computer imaging.
Had the picture been written half as well as it was drawn, I suspect it would have proven at the very least twice as super.
Despite a couple of half-hearted, half-baked twists tossed in at the last minute, the story never feels fully fleshed.

Keaton gives an understated performance that reminds you how it was that he became such an appealing screen presence in the first place and makes you wish better material would start coming his way rather than goofy messages from the great beyond.
The fact is the depth of Scorsese's latest never quite justifies its length.
It's difficult to imagine why any of the talented people involved in this instantly forgettable affair would have been tempted to bother.
The final act reaches up its sleeve and pulls out a big twist that's supposed to take us by surprise - but, instead, just takes us for idiots.

Eventually, Anna goes so Mob Wives on Abel that the very concept of their relationship (and with it, of the film) loses credibility. These two never would've hooked up in a million most violent years.
The dirty half dozen may find God at the last minute, but they've all been disciples of Judd Apatow for years. So the absence of taste is balanced by an abundance of heart.
Hunt for the Wilderpeople is very likely the summer's most magical film.
This is a picture that works on multiple levels and proves to be a pleasant, powerful surprise on every one.
The action is a been-there-done-that yawn, the obligatory wisecracks fall flat, and the CGI work looks like outtakes from Ghostbusters. The original.
Run, as they say, don't walk to the nearest theater showing Josh Kriegman and Elyse Steinberg's spectacular new documentary.
If you're familiar with the twisted, tragic universe that writer-director Todd Solondz has created with eight features over 27 years, you may care to read on. I have good news.
The Secret Life of Pets is that rare achievement: an animated movie that entertains on so many levels, and at such a level of cockeyed brilliance, that it really is fun for the whole family.
You'll never look at your neighborhood supermarket the same way again.
War Dogs never preaches, but it reminds us of the rampant absurdity that became the new normal during the Bush-Cheney years, especially within the military-industrial complex.
Easily one of the most assured and immersive horror films in recent memory.
Only the most shrivel-hearted grinch could watch this Christmas release and not be moved.
It's revelatory to see what devoted friends they were throughout this unimaginably challenging time.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The makers of Morgan are far more interested in gun fights and grisly slayings than in the implications of for-profit genetic monkey business.
Who'd ever have guessed? Dwayne Johnson is The Scorpion King of Comedy!
This is a story that pretends to have a lot more on its mind than it really does.
This isn't a particularly compelling or well-made film. It's very much the work of an ambitious beginner, corny in some places, pretentious in others.
You've probably heard the axiom "Tragedy plus time equals comedy." Pearlstein mines it to illuminating effect.
Instantly forgettable.
Truth, as we know, can be stranger than fiction. One piece of evidence is the fascinating, affecting courtroom drama Denial.
It took a while, but the world eventually caught up with the Stooges. What a difference 40 years can make.
Dunning is not your father's farmer. A fair poet and something of a philosopher, he's fascinating company.
Teller is a knockout. He nails the hometown hero's accent, fighting style and goofball charm.
A frequently silly, forgettable bit of fluff.
Lonergan's dialogue, as always, is a thing of beauty.
It's the most aesthetically audacious, thematically visceral movie you'll see this year.
It's preposterous but propulsive and never less than compelling in its perception of current digital culture and the craving for instant fame wrought by reality TV.
That crucial balance of the old and new is just one of many things [Feig] gets exactly right.
If you've never seen movie explosions before, you're in for a treat. Otherwise, you've got lots of hard-to-follow, poorly lit, very loud chaos to look forward to.
What Mike and Dave really need aren't dates but better, more imaginative material.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Miller and cowriter Karen Rinaldi have created a sly, frequently funny film that starts as a traditional rom-com and ends up flipping those traditions on their heads.

Fiennes' Harry is a fabulous character, a human whirlwind and walking, talking bacchanal who doesn't so much disturb the peace that his hosts are enjoying as turn up the volume on their insular lives. It's a fantastic performance.

The filmmakers and cast are careful to focus on the drudgery, dead ends and shoe leather that go into an enterprise of this scale, eschewing sensationalism. Of the film's 128 minutes, not one is wasted on self-righteous grandstanding or speech making.

Cranston brings style and brio to the part but his character rarely achieves three-dimensionality.The man who gave us Roman Holiday, Spartacus, The Brave One, Exodus, Papillon and dozens more deserves far better film treatment than he receives here.

The movie's writing, direction and acting are not alone in blowing. Ciaran Hope's overwrought score sounds like a mashup of music from hokey old biblical pictures. If a duller, less inspired film hits the cineplex this season, it will be a miracle.
Poehler and Fey attain Bridesmaids heights, with Fey working bluer than a Smurf sailor and wringing nonstop laughs from her potty-mouthed riffs.

Mangano's rags-to-call-in-riches saga is so kitschy and improbable that you can imagine Tim Burton drooling at the thought of taking a seriocomic stab at it. The problem is Russell decided to tell a different sort of story and much of it is a snooze.
Not every filmmaker has what it takes to shape material this bleak into a blackly comic blast, but McKay and his AAA-rated cast are on the money throughout.

Abrahamson's film does the virtually unimaginable: It stares down inhumanity and, in the process, emerges as perhaps the year's most uplifting cinematic experience. Room won't win Best Picture but it will win your admiration. Maybe even your heart.
Revenge, it's said, is a dish best served cold. In Alejandro González Iñárritu's symphony of savagery, The Revenant, it's served frozen, bloody and without mercy.

The Pendleton rescue ranks with the most amazing stories in nautical history but Disney tweaked and twisted the facts and added hokey, hammy stuff that never happened to the point this comes off more like a high-seas Hallmark movie.

A playful, subtly patriotic work from our greatest cinematic gadfly. His goal isn't to criticize this country but to point out that others have solved problems we're still grappling with, and to suggest we take a hint. What a foreign concept.

I can't imagine whom this lightweight curio is intended to appeal to, honestly. With its combination of third-rate Charlie Kaufmanisms, clumsy meta touches and ho-hum narrative, it certainly didn't appeal to me.

As a child, she tells us, she compulsively tried to imagine "things that have never happened in the history of the world." Older, wiser and never better, Laurie Anderson has imagined a movie that meets that challenge magnificently.
The songs are an insanely comic combination of infectious beats and deranged lyrics. The Judd Apatow-produced film pushes the raunch envelope farther than any mainstream comedy in memory.

Nemes has said his goal was to tell a Holocaust story "without projecting postwar emotions or emotions codified in film." I think it's safe to say the filmmaker has created an unforgettably fresh hell.
How the hell did Paolo Sorrentino's latest not dominate awards season? Spotlight and The Big Short are timely films. Youth is timeless.

I'm not sure what this is, beyond a tiresome oddity for the viewer and a career low for its star. Something tells me the most sensible way to deal with Doris is simply not to say hello in the first place.

Suspense and tension are masterfully deployed. Your knuckles will be white. The edge of your seat will see action for 102 minutes. And you will never think about drones in quite the same way as you did before you saw this timely, electrifying film.

Abraham's snoozy, meandering, insight-free biopic was originally slated for an Oscar-qualifying November release. Then someone at Sony Pictures Classics watched it, I guess. A title more apt by far would have been I Saw the Lite.
A great comic mind is a terrible thing to waste.

Baker, we learn, spent the last decade of his life in Europe, using heroin and making much of his greatest music. As an antidrug message, Budreau's film blows. As the study of a famous creative figure, it gets inside to a degree biopics rarely do.

Cheadle gives a convincing physical performance, looking and sounding eerily like Davis, but this is otherwise a confounding cartoon. The actor worked hard for the chance to bring his dream to the screen, but the bottom line is, he kind of blew it.
A nuanced geopolitical parable has been repurposed into a generic romantic comedy, the equivalent of turning, say, The Corrections into a sitcom.

The filmmakers had a duty to make their subject's breakthroughs appreciable to the viewer, to put them in perspective. Without that, the film adds up to little more than a by-the-numbers bromance. Both Ramanujan and the viewer deserve better.

Recall the Clooney of Up in the Air, a trenchant cinematic response to the financial crisis, or the Clooney of Good Night, and Good Luck and you can't help but wonder what persuaded the star to invest time and talent in a junk bond of a jumble like this.
Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising is great. And I don't mean great fun. I mean great. I doubt you'll see a more perfect comedy this year.
It's often said that Hollywood creates too few roles for women. I think anyone who sees The Meddler will agree it's created at least one too many.

112 minutes of insensitive cultural stereotypes, casting that'd make the bigots who inspired #OscarsSoWhite proud and shots of dogs humping. Seriously. I lost count of the number of times the directors cut to close-ups of hounds going to town. WTF indeed.

Dialogue so dumb it will make your ears bleed-some of it spoken by a pet; one-dimensional characters with zero entertainment value; Keaton, as usual, wearing selections from the Jane Jetson Collection and overacting. Love the Coopers is ho-ho-hopeless.
Peter Berg has fashioned something both immersive and beautiful out of tragedy, namely his best film yet.
I can't remember the last time I saw a film on a subject this familiar filled with so many startling historical facts.
Wind River fires on all cylinders. Spare, knowing and powerful, Sheridan's dialogue is worth the price of admission.
At this point, these guys feel almost like family - extraordinarily talented, erudite and funny family. I can't wait to spend time with them again.
Directed by Andy Muschietti (Mamá), It is less a remake than a recycling.
More than anything, though, the movie is just stupid. Which is sad, since it was directed by Michael Cuesta.
This is a film in which a goth from beyond the grave exacts revenge for being unfriended by-are you sitting down?-making her victim less popular on Facebook. The horror!
American Made is an undeniably good time.
This is an exceptional film, insightfully conceived and built on a beautifully written script by British Oscar winner Simon Beaufoy (Slumdog Millionaire).
What other filmmaker could get away with giving Moss' character a chimpanzee for a flatmate and never commenting on it?
Without a minute to spare, the movie's creators tailor-made Stanton the role of a lifetime. We who get to witness his final lead performance are the ones who should count ourselves lucky.
The movie's sole distinction is the light it shines on the moral hypocrisy of a military that claims to leave no soldier behind yet does the minimum to make its returning soldiers whole again.
Repeated viewing tends to suggest some validity to Barbara Harrison's 1980 assessment that Didion's "subject is always herself" and her writing "sounds good" but "doesn't signify."
movie_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Now, having seen it three times, I can't imagine Jane not being the year's finest nonfiction feature.
I'm genuinely impressed that a director as inexperienced and evidently talent-free as Patrick Hughes (The Expendables 3) was capable of doing so much jaw-droppingly wrong.
Watching Wonder, I felt as though someone had set off a sap bomb.
... the picture ranks among the year's most confounding and flawed.
Wonder Wheel is the auteur's 49th feature and his most ill advised promotionally, artistically or by any measure.
Payne's latest is big on laughs early on as its premise is established. Over the course of 135 minutes, however, the filmmaker widens his thematic net with diminishing returns.

Spielberg's rush job about the role of journalism is diminished by dot connecting, historical liberty-taking and a cloying sense of self-congratulation. Instead of an incisive comment on our strange American moment, The Post is, in the end, old news.
The film's last-minute twist is strictly spoiler territory, so all I'll say is that Call Me by Your Name is that rare achievement: a great film that only gets greater as it unfolds.

Cooper's based most of his scripts on perceptive best-selling books. In this case, he reworked an unfinished manuscript by Donald E. Stewart. So what we have is a film about the barbaric birth of a nation from the guy who gave us The Hunt for Red October.

U.S. intelligence concluded Russia hacked the election in retaliation for our part in the unveiling of its doping program. In other words, because of what's revealed in this film. The Russia investigation, as it turns out, is playing on Netflix right now.
Despite the occasional Old Vic melodrama, Oldman lends it all an irresistible credibility.

Like all art that employs negative space, The 15:17 to Paris is really about what the audience doesn't see: in this case, the unthinkable horror El-Khazzani would have unleashed if a handful of ordinary people hadn't done what they did.
... 140 minutes have rarely added up to this much insanely wacked-out fun.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... Game Night is a gloriously preposterous comedy/thriller hybrid that pays homage to the oeuvre of David Fincher - a delightfully preposterous thing for an absurdist comedy to do.
Red Sparrow is many things. Regrettably, a good movie isn't one of them.
Rarely does a film defy both expectation and convention to such powerful, borderline-poetic effect.
And the award for Loopiest Completely Fabricated Fact-Based Drama in Which a Famous Actor Radically Alters His Appearance for No Apparent Reason goes to...whatever this is.
Another of those tiresome movies about colorful antiestablishment parents who raise their offspring to question society's rules while practically ruining their lives in the process.
The picture rocks and rolls, razzles and dazzles.
Peck's transfixing film offers a portrait of the artist as an unshockable man.
Jim Jarmusch: His hair is a national treasure. And Paterson is the finest film in the indie writer-director's (he does the music too-and doesn't even take credit!) distinguished career.
Most of The LEGO Batman Movie's 104 minutes are devoted to action scenes, and audiences are likely to exit the cineplex baffled by their unrelentingly boilerplate quality.

Ultimately, a handful of eye-popping Yimou flourishes can't compensate for filmmaking so line-toeing and occasionally cartoonish that it makes the idea of a wall between Hollywood and Chinese interests actually sound kinda great.
The Red Turtle more than merits that most overused of descriptors: It's enthrallingly, impressively and mind-blowingly one of a kind.
The Salesman is a serviceable work, but take away the brouhaha. and I seriously doubt anywhere near as much attention would be paid.

Nothing wipes the smiles off their faces-even when jobs vaporize, girlfriends bail and homes go into foreclosure. After a while, their positivity actually began to creep me out. They're like Stepford bros.
The final act ranks with movie history's most mind-blowing. Don't let anyone ruin it for you. Just make it your mission not to miss this instant creature-feature classic.
Julieta has been called a departure for the filmmaker... It certainly is, if by "departure" we mean a really dull and convoluted movie as opposed to a good one.

If I could grant Maren Ade's third feature the rating it deserves, its title would be followed not by five stars but by a constellation. The Academy blew it. Toni Erdmann is by far the finest foreign language film of the past year.

Going in Style is that most irksome, instantly forgettable of films -- a remake that fails to make the case for not leaving well enough alone. It also fails to offer its cast material worthy of its talent.

Some of the things I dug most were the weird, playful touches that Sandler plays down here -- for example, his character's bedtime ritual of apologizing to clothes he hasn't worn in a while. Brilliant.
At a time when tensions between the black community and police have been strained nearly to the breaking point, Detroit appears designed to accomplish little besides fanning the flames.

Without dialogue that dazzles in juxtaposition to the low-life milieu, what's the function of a film like this? Wheatley, it's clear, hasn't a clue. His experiment misfires, and what's truly minimal is any chance that you'll feel differently.
One hopes those with a taste for smartly written, superbly acted movies about things that matter in the real world will sample The Dinner.
A big-screen blast. When was the last time a movie with a giant city-crunching reptile blew your mind while touching your heart?
This may be Poitras' Nate Parker moment. The most recent edit of Risk is a muddled, psychodramatic mess shaped by a thirst for retribution. Now playing: the unkindest cut of all.
One of the craziest things you'll see on a screen-any kind of screen-this year. War Machine has its flaws but, long before the closing credits roll, you're likely to surrender to its bizarre charms.
The filmmakers do a highly entertaining and engaging job of introducing the world to a musical pioneer whose work it already knows by heart.
It Comes at Night may well be the most minimalist horror movie ever made... an exceptionally tight, sly and, yes, heavy exercise in psychological suspense.
Any incremental gains civilization may have made have been wiped out, obliterated without a trace by the fact of this film's existence. It's an affront. An atrocity.
Another month, another $50 million TV tentpole from Netflix. And what a fabulous, fun, thoroughly first rate tentpole. How does a director follow Snowpiercer? Precisely like this.
Will Ferrell will turn 50 in a week or so. How sad for him-and his fans-that Cohen's birthday gift is the biggest flop of the comedy legend's career.
Rarely has a mainstream film taken as unflinching a look at aging and illness without losing its sense of humor.
The year's best comedy, an Annie Hall for the age of ISIS.
Dunkirk makes a fairly standard "war is hell" statement. It just appears to say more because Nolan went all William S. Burroughs and played cut-up with his script.
This dud is such a yawn, not even Big Brother is watching.
Will Craig slip into that tux once more? For now, all we can say for sure is that, if he doesn't, it'll be a shame. As Carly Simon sang almost 40 years ago, "Nobody does it better."
Equal parts detective story, political thriller, chase movie, black comedy and head trip, Larraín's film is unequaled in its breadth and intellectual boldness.

Look closely and you'll see this isn't really a movie about computers at all. The machines are there, but the new iterations introduced in the launches-the ones the filmmakers are truly interested in-are the slowly new and improved models of Jobs the man.
This ho-hum ode to the importance of great paintings and statues is as much fun as an art appreciation class and just about as exciting.

Farhadi piles on plot twists and sensational revelations until we realize what we're watching is soap opera packaged as art. Five or ten minutes into hour three, the film reaches a critical mass of preposterousness.
What it lacks in Albanian sex traffickers, the picture makes up for in bizarro comic flourishes and heartstring-tugging corn. I've seen Lifetime movies with more existential drama.
It's La Dolce Vita for the 21st century, of course. But, more than that, it's the rare work that not only tips its hat to a masterpiece but sort of shockingly tops it.

It's hardly surprising that a movie made by Penn and Teller would feature a mind-bending stunt. What you're less likely to expect is that it's a 17th-century Dutch masterpiece that's pulled out of a hat.

Morris' latest is a sequel of sorts to The Fog of War (2003) with its examination of another military mastermind's imprint on history. His attempts to penetrate Rumsfeld's delusions and defenses, however, are hindered less by fog than smoke screens.

The fledgling filmmaker finds what feels like just the right ratio of glitz to guts. One comes away with the sense that Stritch wants more than anything for the show to go on, while knowing better than anyone that her final bow can't be far off.
With his latest, the time has arrived to stop thinking of Anderson's movies as great to look at and start thinking of them simply as great.
Perhaps the most surprising thing about Lars von Trier is that he still can surprise us.
The filmmaker has some truly trippy fun with the siblings' cells. These are easily the eeriest phone calls since Robert Blake dead-dialed in Lost Highway.

A tale of two Brit boomers looking for lost love in Paris, this is Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? with room service. Broadbent and Duncan have never been better. Their eyes and body language say as much as the dagger-sharp dialog.

Nothing in this upside-down ode to empowerment is remotely believable - much less entertaining - and no one in the cast does anything that even resembles acting. It's a manic, misogynistic mess from start to finish. You can feel your brain cells dying.
You're certain to wonder when the manhunt for the wunderkind auteur is going to begin. Because, in Labor Day's nearly two hours, the Jason Reitman fans have come to know is nowhere to be found.

The story is movingly universal. You'll connect with these characters. You'll root for them as they risk everything to break free of the bleakness they were born into. And you'll feel it when, just as things begin to go well, they go haywire instead.
If devastation porn is your cup of tea, this is the picture for you. That's all it has to offer-just monster-on-monster, building-bashing action like you haven't seen since maybe last week.
There will be drool.
A meta western so gutbusting it makes Blazing Saddles look like Unforgiven. Ignore all other reviews. It's genius.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Liman's the brains behind the Bourne franchise, so one approaches the picture with great expectations of breathless action, depth of character and narrative dazzle. One is in for great disappointment.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: 22 Jump Street takes Hollywood comedy to a whole new place - a neat trick for a picture whose business plan is revisiting the past.
The second half of the film feels tacked on from a different project. It's a cautionary tale. Not about drugs or hubris but about poor bookkeeping.

Transfourmers, as I like to call it, is everything you could want in a big-budget tentpole, so long as what you want is sound and fury signifying nothing beyond a guarantee that more of the same is already on the way.
This is a road movie in which Melissa McCarthy - one of the planet's funniest people - takes her audience down a dead end.
2014 is barely past its midpoint, but, my friends, we have a winner: Paul Haggis' latest is a lock for worst movie of the year. It's a crashing bore with the tagline "Watch Me." Don't.

Douglas flails in search of a credible comic tone and Keaton doesn't so much play a character as wear a succession of signature getups. This is wrinkle porn at its laziest, cheesiest and most braindead. And so it blows.

It's not every day you see something you don't see every day. The day you experience Linklater's remarkable new work, I guarantee, will be one you won't soon forget. It's perhaps the most artful and audacious experiment in the history of film.
This is a storm that's far from perfect. But adjust your expectations sufficiently and you just may have an experience that doesn't blow.

A funny, fascinating rumination on art, ambition and the fickleness of fate. It's also unique in the history of film: a documentary that goes behind the scenes of a movie for which not a single scene was ever shot.

Woody Allen pulls off a pretty impressive trick with his 44th film: He makes the charm of Emma Stone and Colin Firth disappear. Rarely have such appealing performers found themselves stranded in roles this underwritten and tiresome.

Greenwald's work gets to the point like cinematic surgical strikes. As with Whistleblowers, he's in and out in an hour and doesn't leave a base uncovered. The bottom line: The present administration is basically the previous administration on steroids.
Think Zero Dark Thirty minus the happy ending.
For all practical purposes, it's Steve Jobs with aprons.

Plot holes are barely outnumbered by the undead. How, for example, did the zombie apocalypse bring civilization to the brink of collapse without folks hearing about it on CNN? The film's writers, as Ricky Ricardo would say, 'have some splainin to do.'
Sandler and his pals are in the enviable position of having the muscle to do their thing for fun and profit.
James Wan's 2004 breakthrough, Saw, was the definition of torture porn. His latest, on the other hand, is simply torture.
A moving bit of business about a boy learning the secret to making life a day at the beach and the best work yet from two guys who really do go way, way back.

The film doesn't so much unfold as detonate. It's a swift kick in the pants at 66 minutes and utilizes a deft blend of archival footage, graphs, subject interviews and bites from knowledgeable talking heads such as David Carr.
movie_title: War on Whistleblowers: Free Press and the National Security State (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Certainties are few in this life, but you can take it from me: Though the movie listings might suggest otherwise, there's no such thing as Miller time.

The picture's most significant problem is simply that it's pointlessly truncated. It's the truth, just not the whole truth. Stern and Whiteley's is a story about big business when it should've been a story about big ideas.
After all the great things I'd heard, I felt like I must've stumbled into the wrong theater as I watched the sloppy, misanthropic sitcom that is Blue Jasmine

Spurlock makes inventive use of 3-D technology. The picture is trippy in places, making it more pleasant to sit through the forgettable songs than it otherwise would be. But Beatles comparisons? Please. One Direction is less a band than a business plan.
Director James Ponsoldt has a drinking problem. The problem is that he apparently can't stop making movies about drinking.
Obviously Robert De Niro was abducted by aliens, and the fellow we've watched sleepwalk through nearly 20 years of shlock is a pod person. A pod person with a terrible agent.
A tale of two flawed, fascinating creatures for which you should have great expectations.
Every one of these ten shorts is a winner in its own way and proves beyond a shadow of a digital doubt that less, in the right hands, definitely can be more.
A minimalist masterpiece that more than merits the response it's gotten from the public and critics alike. How fitting, given its subject, that the acclaim has been universal.
A funny, life-affirming portrait of a well-meaning young woman who's a work-in-progress and a welcome departure for its director.

This portrait of the world's most notorious bean spiller reveals so little I couldn't say with more certainty today than a year ago whether his crusade for transparency is sincere or just a freedom of information act.
As long, strange trips go, Bad Grandpa's cross country odyssey feels more long than strange.
A geriatric riff on The Hangover. Minus, you know, the tiger, the roofies and the laughs.
Well, it took a Brit to get the job done, but we finally have it: a nightmare snapshot of plantation life from the viewpoint of an American slave.
This shipwreck isn't a train wreck by any means, but, in the case of the writer-director's sophomore outing, less really is less. All Is Lost winds up nautical miles from all it might have been.

The combination of that cadaverous visage, redneck rage and cowboy cockiness yields an affecting portrait of a complex man defying the odds - and the authorities - by figuring out how to survive a plague while Big Pharma worked on making a buck off it.

Dench pulls a De Niro here, trading on her legend in the service of a profitable triviality which morphs the tale of a woman's lifetime of regret into a feel-good buddy film offering yuks at the unsophisticated biddy's expense.
You'll laugh. You'll cry. You'll wish you'd watched The Deer Hunter.

Russell's principal obsession is the period and, I'm sorry, but someone really should've taken the filmmaker aside before shooting began and reminded him the decade's been done to death. Maybe Ron Burgundy could've broken the news.

For the first half hour or so, Streep's bitch-on-wheels shtick is good mean fun. But the script jettisons so much of the play that the remainder feels sketchy and super-stagy - like something Eugene O'Neill might have written for the Lifetime channel.
An overrated racing picture that literally goes nowhere fast.

If you see just one weeper based on a YA best seller about teen love blossoming beneath the dark cloud of death this year, do yourself a favor: See the other one. If I Stay makes The Fault in Our Stars look like Citizen Kane.

Siskel's widow recalls he kept his condition a secret to spare his kids and James drives home the devastation of the unexpected loss for Ebert, who vowed that, should anything like that happen to him, he'd hide nothing. Sadly, something did.
Once in a great while, a film leaves you dumbstruck. Which is wonderful, unless you happen to be a reviewer. You're kind of expected to come up with something to say.
While We're Young isn't Noah Baumbach's greatest film. It's more like a collection of his greatest hits.

I think Crowe wanted to make a film that brought to mind David Lean and John Huston. But, as we all know, they don't make them like they used to. If he accomplishes anything with this movie, it's to remind us that's mainly because they can't.

A primary symbol, the Maloja Snake is a cloud formation that winds through the Alps like a colossal cotton anaconda. There's a reason it's called a natural wonder. It's only natural to wonder what any of this self-indulgent silliness is supposed to mean.
For a guy who used to be James Bond, Brosnan makes a surprisingly unconvincing superspy and the story is a meatheaded misfire riddled with loose ends, plot holes and action clichés.
This is not your father's Mad Max.
In places, the CGI mayhem is snazzy, but mostly the whole business is exhausting. It hardly helps that Robertson comes close to exceeding the perkiness limit even for a Disney product.
With a bench this deep, it's mathematically impossible for the film not to be entertaining - or, at least, weird in an extremely interesting way. As it happens, Aloha is both.
Feig worked with McCarthy on Bridesmaids and The Heat and he's helming the Ghostbusters sheboot. What he hasn't done before is write a screenplay for a major feature. And it shows.
Love & Mercy is that rare biopic that respects both its subject and its audience. It's the most insightful portrait of an artist and his process I've ever seen on screen, a privilege to watch.

Cinematographer James D. Cooper makes his directorial debut with this entertaining, if incomplete, account of how the six men made it together as far as the creation of the rock opera Tommy before self- destructing.
At nearly two hours and half a dozen story lines, Ted 2 is simply too much of a so-so thing
Hey, I appreciate quirk as much as the next guy, but I'm not sure the untimely, painful demise of a young woman is the most appropriate subject for showcasing a filmmaker's hip worldview.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Horror has experienced a renaissance with the release of innovative works such as The Babadook and It Follows. Viewers expecting The Gallows to continue the trend will be disappointed to find that Cluff and Lofing have, so to speak, left them hanging.
To say the least, this is a movie with a few bugs in it.

This mesmerizing, meticulously crafted and moving film offers a reminder that, before the people she trusted allowed her to become a punch line, Winehouse was a serious talent. With Amy, Kapadia sets the record straight.
The movie may have been 30-plus years in the remaking, but it most definitely is a trip.

This is a psychological thriller that reflects a genuine grasp of human psychology. That's uncommon. It's what made Hitchcock Hitchcock. It's what makes The Gift one of the extremely rare films that deserve to be described as "Hitchcockian."
The most remarkable novelist of our age is the subject of the most remarkable picture of the season - possibly the year.

The high point (get it?) is an imaginatively choreographed confrontation between Mike and a literal truckload of assassins. They should've called it Operation Overkill. The sequence is delightfully reminiscent of the church massacre scene in Kingsman.

Dowdle's intent is to put an ordinary American family in the way of the kind of harm that Westerners the world over face today with increasing frequency. ISIS is going to give this film five stars and use pirated copies as recruitment tools.
Mistress America lacks the star power of last fall's While We're Young, but it has something more important - Greta Gerwig - and, largely for that reason, it's the superior picture.

I've watched loved ones suffer the indignities of dementia and can't help but find the filmmaker's decision to use them for comic fodder and cheap shocks in deplorable taste. Shyamalan should be ashamed.
Johnny Depp ditches the flouncy flourishes, silly accents and funny hats and gets back down to the business of acting in Black Mass, easily his finest film in a decade.

You know a movie's something special when it succeeds at generating tension and excitement from a game in which two people do little more than stare at a board and move pieces of wood. And does it ever.
Matt Damon may play the marooned astronaut who fights to make it home in this feel-good sci-fi epic, but the big news is that director Ridley Scott is back.

Having digitally rebuilt the city with astonishing historical accuracy, Zemeckis stages Petit's 45 minutes on a cable, 1,600 feet above the street, as one of the most lovely, terrifying, suspenseful and joyous sequences in movie history.

Spielberg's latest is like a double agent: Coded into this tale of Cold War intrigue is a stinging indictment of U.S. policy during our wars in the Middle East. Just exactly where, the film urges viewers to ask, are the James Donovans of today?
Pacino dials the hoo-ah down, letting his smile and charisma do the heavy lifting. Naturally, it doesn't hurt that all the feeling and healing are accompanied by a soundtrack of Lennon songs.
In his harrowing debut, Demange transforms quaint hamlets into nightmare labyrinths and supercharges the suspense with a premise as minimal as it is electrifying-a man running for his life.

I know what you're thinking. Uptight female cop, mismatched female buddy, drug lords, sight gags involving a female law enforcer's underwear - this is kind of like The Heat, right? Wrong. Its creators attempt to commit literary larceny but bungle the job.
Laughably sanctimonious for a Taken retread about a murderer who's too sexy for his shirt.
The suits at Screen Gems had the right idea. They just failed to carry it through. Their mistake wasn't scrapping the picture's press screenings. It was failing to scrap them all.
Here's hoping Winterbottom doesn't wait another four years before cooking up a third course.

Washington's 60 and, apparently, it's the law: He must play a former CIA superagent who takes on Eastern European sex traffickers employing his very particular set of skills, in this case, along with an assortment of home and garden products.
Her beauty, independence, and stock portfolio notwithstanding, Chelsea's tale is a timely, tragic one told with typical Soderbergh finesse, a sly, sleek merger of sex, lies and hi def video.
The film chronicles a contest that's not so much between good and evil as between evil and unbelievable stupidity.
Two things a movie should never waste-the talent of its cast and the time of its audience. The Judge is guilty on both counts.

Fury is the first picture that, to my knowledge, has been designed to convey the experience of warfare itself rather than simply to tell a war story. The film literally has no plot. Do the experiences of real-life soldiers have plots?
On paper, Get Hard might have been a prison riot, but on screen, lazy writing turns it into a longer-than-necessary letdown.
Gilroy's directorial debut is a crazy cool indictment of media voyeurism from which you'll be powerless to look away.
I can't think of a movie with as much to say about the warped symbiosis between show business and society - Scorsese's The King of Comedy included.
There wasn't this much blood in Gladiator.

The film may have its Hallmark moments and gloss over an unflattering fact or two, but in the end it triumphs as a portrait of a brave, brilliant man and the equally courageous woman who gave him everything.
What an astonishing, immeasurably important historical document this is-on top of being a lock for the Best Documentary Oscar.
You know a movie's got problems when the story of how it got made is more entertaining than the movie itself.
Wild chronicles the completion of a daunting physical challenge while intimating that it's about something more spiritual, more meaningful. It isn't.
Tommy Lee Jones' face is a national treasure, is it not? Is there a face on the screen as wizened, as ruined, as made for playing men who've seen unspeakable things?

Zvyagintsev's brutal, beautiful fourth feature won the best screenplay prize at Cannes and, astoundingly, was selected as Russia's official entry in the foreign-language Oscar race (by whom and has anyone seen him lately?).
A gut-busting glimpse into a future in which only the cars are smart.

Neeson and Harris really are quite wonderful actors. They bring a dignity and depth of feeling to their roles even as the filmmakers do everything in their power to turn them into characters in a second-rate Frank Miller comic.

Here's how you know Colin Firth's performance in this movie is among the year's very finest: He plays a figure born into almost unimaginable wealth, privilege and power and succeeds at making you feel sorry for him.

The film's only shock is that it was helmed by David Gelb, who made the wonderful 2011 doc Jiro Dreams of Sushi. Raising the question: Now that Gelb's career is officially dead, will he have better luck than Duplass' character in bringing it back to life?
A mind is a terrible thing to watch waste away and rarely has the horror of losing one's inner self to Alzheimer's been conveyed as precisely and powerfully as it is here.

Rex Reed, who called Melissa McCarthy a "hippo" in his review of Identity Thief, has done it again, stating that Mr. Turner's star is "too repulsive to watch for 150 minutes." Reed's remarks are totally uncalled for. His dismissal, however, would not be.

The picture isn't in any sense about the final act tragedy, the random act of a deranged man. The filmmaker merely uses it as a punctuation mark, a futile grasp at gravitas calculated to move Foxcatcher up in weight class.

Cooper extends his streak as the Last Member of the Wedding Crashers Cast Anyone Would've Expected to Achieve Awesomeness But Did and Then Some. He gives a quietly powerful performance that I'm shocked to see hasn't registered on the award-season radar.

One of the movie's many problems is that the script wants to have it both ways: It suggests Margaret was a browbeaten victim of her husband's greed while making it clear she was actually a willing participant in the ruse.

In a million years, nobody watching The King's Speech could've imagined that one day the Oscar winner would clean house in a house of worship armed with a bulletproof umbrella. But he just did. Somewhere, Tarantino is kicking himself.
Having carefully and sensitively drawn an interesting character and put him in an interesting place, the filmmakers start painting with their fingers and ultimately provide a very familiar picture.
Evocateur offers so much more, some of it compelling, some of it disturbing and some of it revelatory
movie_title: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Scene to scene, encounter to encounter, its tension builds unrelentingly. So, fasten your seat belts. It`s a blast.
It is about bullets flying and bodies falling, but it will capture you on a deeply personal level.
Likely to stay with you forever.
Less movie than fawning infomercial.
It's way too hackneyed for John Hughes. He's already shown us that he knows better.
Real star is the fire, mesmerizingly camcorded from the air and ground. TV is supposed to be the electronic hearth. This time it's the real thing.
T Bone n Weasel is kind of like a good road-kill: it's funny, gross and makes a lasting impression.

A healing exercise for Lucie and Desi Jr., this scrapbook memoir sometimes gets psychobabbly. But it's worth it for the behind-the-scenes insights into what drove their parents together and then split them in two.
All do what they do best: flirt, fight and look good.
movie_title: Saved by the Bell Hawaiian Style (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Dooley's masterful light touch adds most of the levity.
Laura turned out aggressive, Ed passive. Until she pushes him over the edge. Strauss pulls this one out of a hat. He's very sensitive.
The main tale is one of love and redemption, with a silvery hue. So what if the young kids get upstaged by a couple of old pros?
Unfortunately, although as an actress Roseanne Arnold has many qualities, lovable is not of them.

Michael Miller's direction is by the book (Krantz's) and Leonora Thuna and Janet Brownell follow their bible faithfully, allowing Welch andScalia to do what they do best. Hint: It involves lingerie.Two words: yecch and ratings.
In Welch lies most of the bad acting - as she incredibly evolves under Matthew Patrick's telegraphed direction from callous and uncaring to concerned and responsible.
G.I. Joe: Retaliation is a genuinely fun, popcorn adventure that leaves you looking forward to the next installment instead of wondering if the franchise is worth saving.

Salles makes a strong case for On the Road as one of the best adaptations of Kerouac's work to date, managing to tell a story that's both faithful to the source material and well aware of the elements that make the story timeless.
Iron Man 3 defies typical third-chapter drop-off and makes it clear that the franchise is in good hands with its new director.

Star Trek Into Darkness does a nice job of providing all the excitement and explosive moments one expects from a blockbuster of this sort, but it might try a little too hard to hit the obligatory beats for fans of the franchise.
If the intent of 1978′s Superman: The Movie was to make audiences believe a man can fly, then Man Of Steel would have you believe a superhero can sulk - and punch things while doing so.
World War Z offers a strong case that a bigger focus can indeed be better when it comes to the living dead.
The back-to-basics approach works for Riddick, even if it does follow a familiar blueprint.

Viewed as the explosion-a-minute, simple action film that it's intended to be, Captain America delivers on what it needs to do: introduce the character to mainstream audiences while not offending longtime fans, and prime the public for The Avengers.
A recycled story can't dim the sheer star power in the new Jumanji.
Every new Star Wars film was building to The Last Jedi, and it's worth the wait.
Superman's clay face is just the beginning of Justice League's problems.
Imagine Die Hard playing out in the White House, and you're on the right track.
Thor: Ragnarok finally gives Marvel's god of thunder the movie he deserves.
Clooney and the Coens can't save Suburbicon from tripping over its picket fence.
Kingsman: The Golden Circle can't stack bodies high enough to match the original.
It hits a high note in horror, teaching an old clown terrifying new tricks.
War for the Planet of the Apes is a thrilling end to a groundbreaking trilogy.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Peter Parker is back at Marvel and better than ever in Spider-Man: Homecoming.
Baby Driver is the best car-chase crime musical ever made.
Transformers: The Last Knight sets a new low for Michael Bay's franchise.
The Book of Henry is a story best left on the shelf.
The Shape of Water tells an old tale with a bizarrely beautiful del Toro twist.
It's not often a film comes along that's just as much fun to watch with your parents as it is to watch with your partner or friends, but Admission is just that sort of film.

Sam Raimi does a nice job of positioning Oz the Great and Powerful as a bridge to L. Frank Baum's world for younger audiences, hinting at what came before and teasing future adventures lying just ahead on the yellow-brick road.
Dwayne Johnson ventures further outside the straight-up action genre with a tense thriller that proves he he doesn't need to punch, shoot, or body-slam anyone to carry a movie.
The Avengers greatest accomplishment could be this: its ability to make an entire audience feel like children reading their favorite comic for the very first time.
The Amazing Spider-Man is a balanced mix of bright and dark, fun and angsty, fast-moving and deliberately ponderous -- just like its hero.
In his last adventure under Christopher Nolan's guidance, the Dark Knight never quite rises to the occasion.
A funny, scary, and cheer-worthy adventure that somehow manages to make the 16th President of the United States a bad-ass action hero.
An excellent film, but not quite the genre-redefining, mind-blowing, life-changing experience much of the hype suggests.
The Dictator mines its comedy from the film's talented cast instead of people he pranks, and it feels like a very different film than what we've come to expect from Cohen.
Jason Statham is still one of the most entertaining action heroes on the big screen, and when he inevitably puts up his fists, it's always a show worth watching.
Lockout ultimately amounts to a series of bad imitations of good films.
A surprisingly good, fun film that makes great use of Singh's talents and offers a much more enjoyable experience than the trailers for the film suggest.
The good far outweighs the bad with John Carter, and leaves you hoping for a return to Barsoom in the future.
Universal's reboot of The Mummy franchise tries to be a lot of things at the same time, without excelling at any of them.
The film rarely tests the boundaries that Hammer Films were famous for stretching and keeps the scares relatively tame and for the most part, bloodless.
Does Total Recall succeed as a movie? Sure. But unfortunately, the movie never quite succeeds as Total Recall.
Premium Rush does an admirable job of not only taking you inside the bike messengers' world, but making convincing heroes out of them, too.
It's a science-fiction story that does without the typical sci-fi tropes-and that's just part of the magic in this clever, compelling film.

Dredd 3D is the movie the character has always deserved, and proves that you don't need the intimidating budget and star-power of a Hollywood tentpole film to bring a character like Judge Dredd to life on the big screen.
Let's just dispense with all of the usual deliberation and give Lincoln star Daniel Day-Lewis the Oscar now.
Peter Jackson seems keenly aware of the differences between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings, and instead of trying to make one more like the other, he embraces what makes each story unique.
In the end, it's easy to believe that the only mystery Jack Reacher can't solve is the question of where his movie went so very, very wrong.

Only time will tell if John Dies At The End will achieve as similar a level of under-the-radar success as Coscarelli's Bubba Ho-Tep, but it's easy to believe the film is well on its way to becoming a cult classic.
Just when you thought the zombie genre had shambled off into the sunset bereft of any fresh ideas, a movie like Warm Bodies comes along and makes the undead seem, well... very much alive.
The latest chapter of John McClane's continuing adventures raises the bar for what its hero can accomplish without becoming an outright parody of itself.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A heist film that never quite lives up to its compelling premise.
Having no idea what to expect in indie horror film It Comes At Night is all part of the terrifying effect in this grim, psychologically driven thriller.
Charismatic as ever, Tom Cruise keeps American Made flying high.
Dead Men Tell No Tales doesn't reinvent the Pirates of the Caribbean franchise, and plays it safe instead.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: 'The Nice Guys' turns Russell Crowe and Ryan Gosling into a truly memorable odd couple and showcases the best elements of writer and director Shane Black's unique take on action comedies.
It doesn't do anything too drastic or change the status quo, but X-Men: Apocalypse does deliver an exciting adventure that moves the franchise forward without abandoning what works.
Aliens and explosions can't save 'Independence Day: Resurgence' from feeling like a stale remake.

Nostalgia weighs heavily on director Paul Feig's reboot of 'Ghostbusters,' but the film's talented cast - particularly Kate McKinnon - and clever writing prove more than capable of shouldering the burden.
'Star Trek Beyond' turns the intensity up for a fast-paced, high-flying adventure that makes the best of new director Justin Lin's knack for action sequences and takes the series in a new direction.
Matt Damon's reunion with director Paul Greengrass for 'Jason Bourne' has the title character playing the same old spy games without much of the old excitement.
Like Leto's lukewarm Joker, Suicide Squad is more sad than scary.
Sausage Party is gory, raunchy, ridiculous ... and exceptionally clever.
After three underwhelming films, Warner Bros. Pictures finally finds the formula for success with director Patty Jenkins' live-action Wonder Woman.
Oliver Stone directed Snowden, but Joseph Gordon-Levitt brings him to life.
Director Antoine Fuqua's ensemble-driven western The Magnificent Seven is a thrilling return to form for the genre that's more than just a remake.
Miss Peregrine's Home For Peculiar Children is Tim Burton's X-Men.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some serious narrative flaws, The Accountant and its autistic action hero offer an adventure that holds your attention and keeps excitement high.
The biggest mystery in Tom Hanks' return to the role of intrepid symbologist Robert Langdon is why there are so few surprises.
Benedict Cumberbatch's debut as surgeon-turned-sorcerer Stephen Strange in Doctor Strange is a treat for the eyes that transcends its flaws.
Sicario director Denis Villenueve goes sci-fi in alien-invasion movie Arrival, and offers up a truly moving story about what makes us human.
Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them makes the wizarding world feel fresh again.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An island in the Star Wars franchise, Rogue One stands alone for better and worse.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pratt and Lawrence shine, but chemistry alone can't carry Passengers.
Black Panther breaks Marvel's mold without losing its magic.
Ex Machina director Alex Garland adapts Jeff VanderMeer's terrifying best-seller in Annihilation and offers a terrifying expedition into the unknown with a cast led by Natalie Portman.
The third phase of Marvel Studios' cinematic universe gets started in all the right ways with the surprisingly deep, wildly funny, and gloriously action-packed Captain America: Civil War.
Zack Snyder doubles down on the killing and the brooding in Batman V. Superman: Dawn of Justice, a sequel to 2013's polarizing Man of Steel, and a disappointing film from start to finish.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A visual treat from beginning to end, Kubo and the Two Strings is the best feature yet to come out of celebrated stop-motion studio Laika.

Taron Egerton takes on the role of Eddie "The Eagle" Edwards in a funny, heart-warming account of an unlikely Olympian's quest to represent his country and soar to new heights on the world's biggest stage.
'10 Cloverfield Lane' will keep you guessing with yet another unexpected spin on monster movies from JJ Abrams' Bad Robot team and a tense mystery that will keep you guessing until the credits roll.
There's a lot that feels familiar about Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2, and that's a very, very good thing for everyone's favorite team of a-holes.
Although it features a strong cast led by Emma Watson and Tom Hanks, The Circle still manages to be a frustratingly shallow spin on the balance between freedom and privacy.
Director James Gray's film about obsession and exploration in the Amazon shows flashes of potential with beautiful cinematography, but ultimately falls short of its greater promise.
One would think that a movie franchise would start showing signs of rust after seven installments, but The Fate of the Furious proves that some series just keep getting better.
Scarlett Johansson goes cyberpunk for Ghost in the Shell, a flashy film that falls short of its legacy but still offers surface-level entertainment value.
Although it doesn't reach the genre-busting heights of its screenwriters' recent works, outer-space thriller Life still scares up an entertaining adventure.
'Kong: Skull Island' makes the giant ape great again
Hugh Jackman's final adventure as Wolverine is not just the best film in the franchise, but the fondest farewell Logan could hope for.
The directorial debut of Key and Peele co-creator Jordan Peele, Get Out is a taut, terrifyingly appropriate thriller.
Matt Damon can't save The Great Wall from underachieving with a beautiful movie that's all style and no substance.
Ridley Scott's desire to turn the Alien franchise into an existential drama about the nature of life is an odd distraction in Alien: Covenant.
The horror franchise that started with 2002's 'The Ring' returns to the screen with a clever concept that it abandons far too early.
Milla Jovavich's final adventure as Resident Evil action hero brings the franchise to a fitting but somewhat underwhelming end in The Final Chapter.
Vin Diesel's return in 'xXx: Return of Xander Cage' uses the 'Fast and Furious' formula to make the franchise fun again.
Red director Robert Schwentke comic book adaption of R.I.P.D., starring Jeff Bridges and Ryan Reynolds, blends the fun and the familiar for a supernatural buddy-cop adventure.
Seth MacFarlane's wild western comedy manages to keep the laughs rolling and the body count high in a hilarious sendup of life on the American frontier.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Wes Ball's sequel to 2014's The Maze Runner never slows down as its heroes sprint through a post-apocalyptic nightmare and keeps tension high at the expense of character development.

Daniel Craig's latest (and possibly last) adventure as secret agent James Bond manages to be both different and familiar as 007 takes on the mysterious criminal organization threatening everything he holds dear.

While it's not an instant holiday classic, The Night Before manages to put a fresh spin on Christmas comedies with a funny, fast-paced, and frantic adventure starring Seth Rogen, Joseph Godon-Levitt, and Anthony Mackie.
In Star Wars: The Force Awakens, director J.J. Abrams strikes just the right balance in the seventh installment of the franchise to make fans fall in love with the saga all over again.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most unique characters in Marvel Comics' superhero universe, Deadpool makes the leap from page to screen in a very funny, very violent, and very unconventional comic-book movie.
By focusing on all the best elements of its 2014 predecessor, John Wick: Chapter 2 lives up to the hype and improves on the original's winning formula.
An intriguing and muddled relationship between three brilliant artists is downgraded into a tedious and lurid art-world soap opera full of convoluted love triangles.

Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines is without a doubt the weakest entry in an otherwise beloved trilogy, but let's be honest, T3 was doomed from the very day franchise creator James Cameron decided to pass on it.

On the Ferrell scale, Land of the Lost ranks squarely below Anchorman and leagues above Semi-Pro, landing right in that murky middle-ground Talladega Nights territory. Let your tolerance level for the comedian be your guide. If

House of Wax director Jaume Collet-Serra returns to the horror genre with Orphan, a clumsy thriller that elicits far more laughs than genuine scares. Like too many horror films these days, the movie is so rife with false scares or misleading
Need your fix of Black and Cera? We recommend renting School of Rock and Superbad instead of heading to the theater for this one.
At every turn where The Proposal could have seemingly gone in a less obvious direction, it just puts on the blinders and forges ahead with the cliches of this genre.

Ben (Mark Duplass) and Andrew (Joshua Leonard) are two college friends whose lives have taken very different paths. While Andrew's gone globetrotting, Ben settles down with a wife (Alycia Delmore) and a white picket fence. When Andrew shows up at Ben's do
Despite its lofty aspirations, Angels & Demons is no less artificial and forced than the latest Fast & Furious sequel. Different target audience, same motive: easy money.

There's not much in Imagine That to appeal to critics -- or to anyone with an even marginally cynical disposition. Every A-list funnyman seems contractually obligated to do a high-concept family comedy like this, but it's a lot less fresh this time
State of Play is a rare exception to the rule that thrillers are only as good as their twists: it's good almost in spite of its sometimes obvious plot machinations.

Comparisons to the similarly set and massively popular Paul Blart: Mall Cop will inevitably pop up, but where the Kevin James comedy played things broad and safe, Hill's latest is anything but. Unlikable characters, gratuitous male nudity, a dry and somet

A war-room farce in the proud tradition of Dr. Strangelove, the satire is sharp and biting, and the comic incompetence and witty bickering that's become a hallmark of recent British comedy exports is absurdly terrifying when it's also found in the

While Halloween II starts out as a character study in post-traumatic stress, it's safe to assume that's not what most horror fans will be looking for. And though Zombie maintains the motif of nightmarish visions throughout, the movie eventually cha

The Time Traveler's Wife stars Eric Bana as Henry DeTamble, a Chicago man suffering from "chrono-impairment disorder" -- that is, a genetic anomaly that causes him to involuntarily time travel. The defective gene doesn't prevent Henry from meeting

By glossing over much of the Italian designer's past, Tyrnauer assumes a certain level of familiarity with his subject from his intended audience. If you can't tell Valentino from Versace, you ain't it. That said, The Last Emperor isn't totally ina
Moonlight may be a quiet, understated gem. But you can expect the buzz surrounding it to become deafening.
It may hit some familiar notes along the way, but when the story is this good, you don't really mind hearing it again.
For those equally unfamiliar with Morgan, or who only know him because of the tragic end to his story, Collins' new film will make for a worthwhile education.
[Deadpool] the (anti)hero we didn't even know we needed.

Along with his later 8 1/2, La Dolce Vita is regarded as one of acclaimed Italian director Federico Fellini's best-loved and most influential films. The '60s-set tale of one man's struggle with the so-called "sweet life" stars Marcello Mastroi

The Wolfman boasts a solid principal cast from Del Toro to Hopkins and up-and-comer Emily Blunt, but Del Toro especially seems to be going through the motions at half speed, as if waiting for the beast and the stuntmen to take it from there. Only H

Denzel Washington deserves equal credit for this, delivering his best Man with No Name impression as a Bible-thumping hero in a much more literal sense, one who delivers bloody vengeance in lieu of sermons. Though these types of roles are far more demandi
Rarely a boring moment or unnecessary scene. Avatar isn't going to redefine movies as we know them, but on the level of pure visual spectacle, the bar has certainly been raised.

Despite its title, Sheridan's film is less concerned with sibling rivalry (romantic or otherwise) and more with post-traumatic stress disorder -- which would be fine if it had anything particularly new or profound to add to the conversation. Unfortunately

A movie that ultimately has more cult than mass appeal, how much you enjoy Bad Lieutenant will probably come down to how much you like Werner Herzog rather than Nicolas Cage. A notoriously eccentric director, his latest film is nowhere near as mainstream
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)
