(Director Ronnie) Yu puts minimal effort into staging flavorless, slow-motion, everything-but-the-kitchen-sink action sequences that feel about as fresh as a microwave dinner.
...but pardon me if I shoot the messenger (ooh, the horrible pun!) for his propagandist approach to the subject that comes close to crippling his credibility.
Once all the pieces are in place, the director's choices make a certain kind of sense -- but not enough so to make the movie seem any better in retrospect.
Already packed with all the claustrophobic wartime tension a good sub thriller needs, Below squeezes in something more -- a bone-chilling element of the supernatural.
Dingbat love has never been as oddly appealing.
Never lets go your emotions, taking them to surprising highs, sorrowful lows and hidden impulsive niches...gorgeous, passionate, and at times uncommonly moving.
Amusing but otherwise forgettable...having a good time took precedent over making anything more than a insubstantial romp designed to entertain (the cast).
Ana's journey is not a stereotypical one of self-discovery, as she's already comfortable enough in her own skin to be proud of her Rubenesque physique...
...does such a fine job of engulfing you in its world and allying you with its characters' choices, good and ill, that its shortcomings are remembered only as an afterthought.
One of the scariest, most original scream-at-the-screen style horror movies I've seen in years...nonetheless ruined by an insultingly insipid cliché of an ending.
Unless Bob Crane is someone of particular interest to you, this film's impressive performances and adept direction aren't likely to leave a lasting impression.
Wouldn't it be funny if a bunch of Allied soldiers went undercover as women in a German factory during World War II? Um, no. But here's a movie about it anyway.
Mark Wahlberg...may look classy in a '60s-homage pokepie hat, but as a character he's dry, dry, dry.
...fuses the events of her life with the imagery in her paintings so vividly that the artist's work may take on a striking new significance for anyone who sees the film.
Strictly for shallow-end-of-the-gene-pool types who find professional wrestling and monster truck shows too sophisticated for their simple-minded tastes.
An uncreative Hannibal the Cannibal prequel with bite but no brains.
Something akin to a Japanese Alice Through the Looking Glass, except that it seems to take itself far more seriously.
(A) Hollywood sheen bedevils the film from the very beginning...(but) Lohman's moist, deeply emotional eyes shine through this bogus veneer...
Making only a minimal effort to be any different...than the hundreds of other forgettable, predictable, almost-married-the-wrong-guy romantic comedies that have come before it...
...has a bit more going for it than just bikini babes and bitchin' waves. But the plot is ankle deep at best.
Neil LaBute has taken another large and confident step into an unexpected genre with gratifying results.
(Danny Huston gives) an astounding performance that deftly, gradually reveals a real human soul buried beneath a spellbinding serpent's smirk.
Beneath the uncanny, inevitable and seemingly shrewd facade of movie-biz farce...lies a plot cobbled together from largely flat and uncreative moments.
...plot holes so large and obvious a marching band might as well be stomping through them in clown clothes, playing a college football fight song on untuned instruments.
So refreshingly incisive is Grant that for the first time he'll probably appeal more to guys than to their girlfriends who drag them to this movie for the Hugh factor.
...harmless, wholesome and just barely winning enough to overcome its fantasy-suburban, Norman Rockwell nature.
Overly stylized with lots of flash black-&-white freeze frames reminiscent of a pseudo-hip luxury car commercial, (it's) at its worst when it's actually inside the ring.
Romanek keeps the film constantly taut...reflecting the character's instability with a metaphorical visual style and an unnerving, heartbeat-like score.
If (this) sounds like entertainment to you, perhaps you should save the price of admission and put it toward therapy.
Paints such an authentic, vivid picture of the fictional Vincent's life (that) most of the film doesn't feel conspicuously scripted. The ending, however, screams "Hollywood."
Christensen...is such a fun, wicked, spiteful villainess that she keeps the flick afloat all by herself.
A highly personal meditation on the choices we make that define our identity.
Watching (Cedric) go on a politically incorrect jag about Rodney King, O.J. (and) Rosa Parks...is a can't-believe-your-ears laugh almost worth the price of admission by itself.
Downright transparent is the script's endless assault of embarrassingly ham-fisted sex jokes that reek of a script rewrite designed to garner the film a "cooler" PG-13 rating.
It's hard to believe these jokers are supposed to have pulled off four similar kidnappings before.
An affectionate, sophisticated parody of Technicolor melodramas and musicals of the 1950s -- with a some mock-Agatha Christie thrown in for fun.
Quote not available.
One of the most incompetent big-budget action movies I've ever seen.
An emotionally resounding, life-affirming film of surprising connections and affections.
One of those rare, exhilarating cinematic delights that gets even better in hindsight, as you mull over its every nuance in your mind.
A hollow-hearted epic for the sake of an epic.
(An) ugly duckling fairytale that is predictable and brimming with clichés - but so earnest, funny and joyful that it's a complete delight all the same.
Another boorish movie from the I-heard-a-joke- at-a-frat-party school of screenwriting.
All leather pants & augmented boobs, Hawn is hilarious as she tries to resuscitate the fun-loving libertine lost somewhere inside the conservative, handbag-clutching Sarandon.
The film left me with a slightly empty feeling that all Morris has accomplished is getting me to split my sides in the face of something wholly terrifying, and that's OK - even necessary - for now.
This film is not exactly a defining moment of anything, past or present, but it offers a compelling peek at an important point in time.
Bigelow's camera is impartial and dispassionate, but explosively powerful and unflinching. There is no commentary or judgment, just war and fatigue.
Whatever Works won't set the world on fire but it has more than its share of riotously hysterical moments and delicious absurdities.

There is nothing so sparkling to this film at first glance. It's a film about man's mortality and how he handles it, but death is not cleverly hidden inside a bigger story. It's a wake-up slap in the face about the gritty part of dying: the bodies.
Every time something seems to be happening, Jarmusch tips us gently back into sleep mode. It's enough to make you long for a sip of one of the countless espressos the nameless man enjoys.
The goodwill that the charming Dennings has built up in earlier films, such as 40-Year-Old Virgin and Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist, doesn't excuse this role.

[Director Fukunaga] spends as little time dwelling on the whole as possible, instead opting for a classic road-trip story of the parts: the people who are emigrating and the gang members trying to kill one of them.
While The Girlfriend Experience is not a good film by any stretch, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it as being, at the very least, worth the time to watch it.

Director Christophe Barratier has not crafted a film for the ages here, but it's a workable, fun piece about family and friendship, full of wonderful songs and musical numbers performed on the Chansonia stage.
As much as the film is about war, it's also about the mutability and self-distortion of memory, and that makes animation the ideal medium to paint battle as the surreal experience it is.
Pro wrestling is not an easy subject to take seriously, but director Darren Aronofsky displays it well as a spellbinding muscle ballet, sweaty and bloody, but graceful and addictive all the same.
Where Gran Torino fails at social criticism, it succeeds at capturing an engrossing snapshot of the human saga. If itâ(TM)s Clintâ(TM)s last film, itâ(TM)s a perfect ending.

Even the out-of-place moments and blunt conceits can be forgiven, as they perform dutifully in service to the kind of thrilling movie adventures we regular folks can only dream of, but which the wizards at Pixar perform with ease.
Not only are the movie's key questions left unanswered, they are left almost entirely unexplored once the cast begins their journey on the trail.
Redux clocks in at a slightly shorter running time than any of the previous versions Wong has offered. The tighter edit is a better fit, but ultimately, it's not enough.

If I didn't see it with my own eyes, I never would have thought it possible to make a fairy tale out of Hurricane Katrina, but that's exactly what first-time director Benh Zeitlin has done in Beasts of the Southern Wild.
Don't let the impressive cast list, which includes Vanessa Redgrave, Monica Bellucci and David Strathairn, fool you: This is the Rachel Weisz show.
It's unclear what the director, Atom Egoyan, intended to do here. The film has no personality or authorship. There is no arc or drama, only scenes lined up one after another.

Each half of the plot is strange and funny in an entirely different way, but the two never mesh as a whole like they might in a novel, so the wildness of this storyline grab bag leaves the stitching far too visible.
A microcosm of baseball itself, the knuckleball is a cruel, unpredictable thing.

I've always been on the fence about Law. For every Gattaca or Closer, there are a handful of The Holidays and Cold Mountains to contend with. But if Dom isn't his best performance, it's certainly his funniest.
There are worthwhile scenes, and the mood is occasionally affecting, but it doesn't come together as a singular piece overall, and that's too much to overlook.
Hansen is the film's only redeemable quality; it's a shame that she is wasted on this pointless search.
Somewhat conspicuously lacks both the ham and the cheese that we've come to expect in the landmark cinema of Nic Cage.

There are so many pitfalls, and it seems like every TV movie version of the story falls into all of them at the same time. But in Short Term 12, writer-director Destin Cretton manages to skillfully step over all of them.

Bro, it comes down to this: if you can't turn the brain meat off and sit back and enjoy Charlie Hunnam, Rinko Kikuchi and Idris Elba beating the crap out of some monsters then, dude, you're the monster.
Anderson's woodsy thought process... elicits a thorough batch of the rainy summer daydreams where most grand childhood adventures and romances are so often had: in heads and hearts, if not in flesh.
He simply evades and bargains. It's tough to say what audiences are supposed to do with that.

I appreciate [Reeves'] interest and passion on the subject, and his interview style is fine -- the conversations he finds himself engaged in with the Wachowski's especially is worth watching it for alone.

Filmed in Spain and Canada, Red Lights is limply staged and even more uninspiringly shot - everywhere looks like nowhere. The effect of all this is a total lack of emotional connection to these characters right from the start.
Despite the rumors of its demise, 2D hand-drawn animation isn't dead. In fact it's becoming vital again in Europe, and this is a brilliant example of what it could be again.
Tense, well-acted, and managing to avoid Misery territory, its only real misstep is the ending, which feels more like writer's paranoia - an ever-hovering spectre - than the natural outcome.
A clever and entertaining sci-fi comedy that features all of the things that made Ghostbusters great.
A meandering, flawed, but electrifying film.
Can't decide if it wants to be a romantic comedy or a sarcastic send-up of all things Hollywood.
American Outlaws may well prove to be one of the funniest comedies of the season. Unfortunately, it's supposed to be a Western.
Sci-fi at its worst: bad enough to be funny, yet loud and obnoxious enough that it can't even be enjoyed as unintentional comedy.
Despite its good nature and some genuinely funny moments, Super Troopers suffers from a bad case of arrested development.
The two intermingled films in Osmosis Jones add up to much less than the sum of their parts.
This movie is Tarantino on speed, and without focus and style. It is in-your-face and proud of it with no apologies.
The same dumb character decisions stick around to facilitate the murder.
Space Cowboys is about the enduring hunger for adventure and frontier, a story that both explodes and celebrates the American Dream.
The struggles of gay teenagers are handled with vast humor, insight and honesty.
A raucous summertime treat for kids of all ages that anyone would be a fool to miss.
Despite special effects far inferior to those used in the 1998 American version, [Toho Studio] is still the master of its original 1954 creation.
This is lowest-common-denominator moviemaking that definitely rings hollow.
Here, finally, is a film about the '60s that comes closest to showing the true grit and idealistic vulnerability that mixed to make the hippie generation an engine for social change.
Crackles with the malicious glee and harsh, gratuitous extremity that continue to keep this enduringly naughty director's work teenage-fresh and mainstream-resistant.
Director Miguel Arteta escapes the sophomore slump.
Thomas may make you lose your own 'sparkle', so take some Valium if the children insist.

There's no good reason to justify how a film that's essentially about robots bashing other robots can be stretched out to such gargantuan lengths, especially with a plot as hole-ridden and lightweight as this.
It doesn't really know what it wants to be: big, bawdy studio comedy or something more subtle and indie spirited, as evidenced in its final third. The result is an ill-conceived mess.
A wildly entertaining feel-good movie that not only rates as one of the best mainstream comedies of the year but also one of the finest sequels you are likely to see.

With the principal players all on top form, some arresting set pieces and a nice mix of humour and drama, Days of Future Past does more than enough to overcome its imperfections and keep fans satisfied.

A self-confessed Godzilla geek, Edwards has stayed true to many of the origins of the original Toho creation (directed by Ishiro Honda way back in 1954) by playing once again on nuclear fears and nature's ability to remind mankind of its power.
Despite some decent moments the film struggles to realise its potential.
Even the unintentional laughs eventually give way to groans of disdain. Don't be conned into seeing it.
Amazing in places, overcooked at others, Marc Webb's sequel to The Amazing Spider-Man is a generally crowd-pleasing affair that thrives on the ability of leading man Andrew Garfield.
It's always disappointing when a film that places so much emphasis on the need to be free-thinking and different from the masses conforms so rigidly to other movies.
Ealy and Bryant make for a bland couple and during the more weighty stuff appear to be just going through the motions.
Muppets Most Wanted is a solid effort but lacks the magical quality of its nostalgia-driven predecessor.
While Thor: The Dark World is fun in places it's far from a satisfying experience.
Feels much less potent, despite some very good acting and a couple of genuinely moving moments.
Proves you can marry visual spectacle with something to engage the heart and the head too.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Endless Love is the type of film that resorts to big soundtrack moments to let viewers know how they should be feeling, which has the effect of highlighting the movie's failings even more.

A romantic comedy from the perspective of three male friends has the potential to offer something new to the genre but despite one or two comedy highlights That Awkward Moment largely makes a mess of things.
For all its many flaws, Grudge Match wins you over - but it's a points decision!
A competent genre entry that delivers its thrills efficiently and in a more old-school manner than the recent Bourne or Bond films.
From poor conception through to shoddy delivery, Devil's Due is a tedious and wholly derivative horror experience.

Berg's direction is super intense, especially during the prolonged fire-fights in the mountains - sequences which will likely leave viewers feeling as bruised, breathless and scared as the soldiers themselves.
First-time director Carl Rinsch's mega-budget take on one of Japan's most enduring legends feels like a folly that should never have been indulged.

Clocking in at in excess of two and a half hours, this second film in The Hobbit trilogy hits the ground running with a couple of impressive set pieces but runs out of puff long before it reaches the scenes with Tolkien's fabled dragon.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Powder Room is designed to be an amusing expose of what really goes on in women's toilets but its wayward plotting and lacklustre comedy mean it has more disappointments than laughs.

The Counsellor is a cold, pessimistic film that feels especially unforgiving. McCarthy's script is far too distanced for its own good and requires more from its audience than it is prepared to give back.
Kimberly Peirce's update on Stephen King's Carrie slavishly follows the path taken by Brian De Palma's 1976 film and fails to make any real impact.
For all of its lofty ambitions, A New York Winter's Tale emerges as a hugely disappointing experience.
Essentially, Hercules is a fun ride while it lasts.
Ultimately, Charlie Countryman bites off more than it can chew and winds up feeling more absurd than memorable.
Into the Storm may blow you away with the quality of some of its special effects but it'll leave you underwhelmed and exasperated in most other respects.
Most Bond films have flaws but few Bond films end up as enjoyable as this.
The Cabin in the Woods will undoubtedly be one of the best horror-thrillers you'll see all year, as well as one of the best films. It will also standout as an all-time horror classic.
Redford takes on the role of Bryson, while Nick Nolte is his travel companion Katz, and the two veterans share an engaging chemistry that quite often makes up for the film's many shortcomings.
For all of the technical prowess surrounding the production, Kormákur never loses sight of the human element underpinning the tragedy.
Tom Hardy delivers not one but two outstanding performances in Legend, an engaging if flawed look at the reign of London's notorious Kray twins.
Far from feeling repetitive or even drawn out, Fury Road grips like a vice throughout.
Jurassic World is a surprisingly thrilling blockbuster experience that should leave fans roaring with approval.
It may boast the world's smallest superhero but Marvel's Ant-Man is big on fun and ingenuity.

Fortunately, Ted 2 is more hit than miss, trading strongly on the still winning camaraderie between Mark Wahlberg and his foul-mouthed, pot-smoking teddy bear (voiced by MacFarlane) and some genuinely laugh out loud gags.
Four years after Entourage concluded its hugely enjoyable eight-year run on HBO, the characters make a winning return for this feature-length movie.
The Drop is one of the finest crime dramas you're likely to see in a long time, graced by some truly exceptional performances.
Part horror, part sci-fi but totally engrossing, William Eubank's The Signal is a small scale production that thrives on some very big ideas.
Closed Circuit may tackle some heavyweight issues but it ends up feeling lightweight.
A bonkers take on the serial killer genre that grips in spite of its flaws.
It marks a tour-de-force acting performance from man-of-the-moment Oscar Isaac and another mightily impressive screenwriting and directing credit from JC Chandor.
The film offers up a breathless battle of wills that inspire a whirlwind of emotions before leaving you on an exhilarated high.
A pretentious wreck of a movie that severely tests the patience.

If you can overlook the film's weaker elements, however, then Spooks still entertains consistently enough to make it a genre entry worth investing time in, whether or not you've previously been a fan of the series.
Fans of more curious romantic dramas such as Benjamin Button and The Time Traveller's Wife will get the most out of The Age of Adaline, an engrossing if flawed drama.
The ensuing action-adventure may promise more than it ultimately delivers but remains fun for long periods.

A passion project that Rock writes, directs and stars in, the film encapsulates the raw, edgy, provocative energy of the star's stand-up routines, while providing plenty of food for thought in the process.

Rogue Nation is a blockbuster that expertly combines exhilarating visual thrills with the kind of intricate storyline that requires viewers to pay attention. It also treads a nice line between the drama and the humour.
Schumer, meanwhile, is a revelation: her Amy emerging as a volatile force of nature seemingly only ever one step away from self destruct, who nevertheless commands our sympathy and support.
A slickly executed, hyper stylish mix of action and comedy that seduces by virtue of its visual appeal.
Sadly, the resulting film feels every bit like the desperate cash-in it really is.
This is an endearing entry into the Tinkerbell franchise that succeeds in spite of the reservations and flaws that have hitherto been outlined.
movie_title: TinkerBell and the Legend of the NeverBeast (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Let's Be Cops is an amiable watch that succeeds in spite of its many flaws, but you can't help but wonder what someone like Kiss Kiss Bang Bang's Shane Black or Superbad's Greg Mottola might have done had they got hold of it.

The Expendables 3 suffers from a desire to play safe; from its lazy formula to its watered-down violence and largely consequence-free peril, and as a result never rises above the level of expendable viewing itself.
For all its feel-good intent, the film is ultimately generic and dispiriting.
Alongside the film's increasingly irritating 'Googliness', The Internship is as silver-tongued and soulless as the rhetoric it appears to peddle.
Nooshin succeeds in keeping things suitably tense throughout, throwing in a few decent set pieces without compromising the credibility of the situation, at least until a slightly overblown finale.
A flawed but intriguing take on a well-worn genre.
It's sure to gain cult status but it's still a real mess.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Trouble With The Curve works because of its performances.
By the time the film grinds to its ridiculous conclusion, you'll be praying for it to end.
Winstead is good, Paul is great and Ponsoldt's film is solid, even going so far as to deliver a genuinely poignant final scene.
Langella provides a formidable central presence, both stubborn and endearing, while Sarsgaard injects warmth and humanity into Robot.
Tense, uncompromising and morally and ethically challenging, Denis Villeneuve's Sicario is a formidable piece of filmmaking that undoubtedly rates among the year's best.
Sandler overdoes the camp in his portrayal of Dracula, Gomez is a generically surly teen and Samberg just irritates as the unlikable Jonathan.
The story is weak, opting for the Die Hard 2 approach of having the same thing happen to the same guy twice.
Despite its shortcomings, Savages isn't a complete waste of time.
Badly let down by some silly plotting that negates the film's ability to be taken seriously and a screenplay that all too often reduces a lot of the characters to stereotype.
A satisfying piece of head-rush cinema that should leave viewers feeling exhilarated.
Rigidly formulaic and shamelessly sentimental.
Packs a mean punch, revelling in the bleak world it effectively creates and Travis' penchant for ultra slow-motion sequences that take the balletic violence of Peckinpah and Woo to new excess.
While [REC] lacks any real potency in the scare department, it's a wild ride that keeps the franchise at the forefront of the zombie genre.

Far from paying respectful homage to the memory of the original Stooges and potentially encouraging a new generation of viewers to revisit them, this lame comedy may leave them wondering what the fuss was all about in the first place.
At its best, The Expendables 2 thrives on the camaraderie that exists between the various action icons, while dropping in cheesy gags that reference their back catalogue.
Sadly, the latest entry in the seemingly interminable franchise offers more of the same contrived scenarios.
One of the comedies of the year.
Marc Webb succeeds in breathing new life into this Marvel favourite.
A consistently enjoyable and often laugh-out-loud crowd-pleaser.
Nothing can prevent this from being an empty, shallow experience for those unlucky enough to see it.
The longer things last, the less interesting they become as the tone veers wildly between gung-ho action, unintentional humour and shameless jingoism.
From its flimsy concept to its similarly sloppy use of post-conversion 3D, Wrath of the Titans is a sequel that fails to improve on the original in any way.
The Pirates! no doubt will play well to the whole family and with such enchanting visuals and astonishing attention to detail there's still much to treasure here.
Contrived and inconsistent.
The inevitable ending offers nothing new on the Blair Witch template either which feels like scant reward for the effort required in reaching it.
More miss than hit, despite some hilarious sequences.
While easy on the eye and enjoyable for the most part, especially when Gosling occupies the screen, Gangster Squad has a few too many flaws.
Hoult and Palmer provide engaging performances and keep things watchable and Levine's soundtrack is admittedly cool. But overall Warm Bodies struggles to convince.
Escape Plan ... promises more than it delivers. It's disposable, even expendable, hokum.
It has heart and intelligence to offset its more raucous moments and looks destined for cult appeal.
Macdonald's film may operate within the same genre as past releases like Tomorrow, When The War Began and Red Dawn but it's more intelligent and a lot darker than those films.
Arrives with an emotional complexity and gripping intensity that has been sorely missing from a lot of Hollywood thrillers of late.
Once all of the film's cards have been revealed, it's hard not to feel a little cheated.
A shambolic and hugely speculative look at one of her love affairs that has more in common with a bad romcom.
Every bit the lifeless blockbuster that its name suggests.
A brainless, tedious experience.
For all its obvious flaws and stupidity, Riddick consistently entertains.

Thanks in no small part to its trio of hugely likeable teenage leads, the film breezes along, mixing comedy with drama to often seamless effect, while exploring the kind of issues that viewers can all find relatable.
It quite often feels like fantasy movie making by numbers and is particularly uninspired.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part, Elysium is a thrilling blockbuster that marries intelligence with spectacle to striking effect and confirms Blomkamp as the new king of the genre in the process.
As comebacks go, Schwarzenegger has chosen a really good vehicle with which to remind people of how he became so popular in the first place.
There's very little about the film that rings true.
This is a deeply unpleasant subject matter and Hyett's handling of it leaves a nasty taste in the mouth.
Overall it's a solid thriller that hints at a life beyond blockbusters for its leading man.
This is tedious fare. Best avoided.
The whole endeavour smacks of franchise desperation.
Chan's film may be derivative of plenty of other films (most notably David Cronenberg's A History of Violence) but it manages to keep things fresh and exciting.
Thanks to director Shane Black (who also co-wrote the script with Drew Pearce), it's a film that rejuvenates the franchise while having some fun with superhero convention into the bargain.
The whole endeavour feels lazy and conformist with little to recommend it.
While GI Joe: Retaliation may still boast an overly indulgent running time and some ridiculous displays of gun fetishism and gung-ho patriotism, it's a fun ride while it lasts.
The film ends up being devoid of tension. They probably should have kept the bunny in the box.
Odd is exactly the right word for this curious experience.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Attempts to tap into the emotional complexity at play find everyone wanting, especially during the Romeo & Juliet-style love story, which often feels like an after-thought.
Overall, this is a bad day that you'd rather forget.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's perhaps no coincidence that the film ends up on a runaway locomotive as this feels like a train wreck throughout.
It truly deserves to be experienced on the biggest screen possible and it won't fail to impress.
A hugely enjoyable, if predictably rose-tinted look at the history of the world's biggest and most enduring film franchise.

Boasting two excellent performances from Ben Mendelsohn and Ryan Reynolds, the film functions as both a richly absorbing road movie and a gripping addiction drama that places its biggest emphasis on character.
It's fun. John Watts' film carries an innocence and wide-eyed brashness befitting its central character's coming-of-age journey. But it's also capable of surprising.
Taken at face value, Despicable Me 3 offers undemanding fun for all the family, which zips along and delivers more than it's fair share of laughs.

Edgar Wright has delivered the film of the summer, and one of the best of the year, with Baby Driver, a heist movie that tips its hat to past classics while retaining an energy and style that's steadfastly its own.

Incoherent, creatively bankrupt and excessive to the point of tedium, Michael Bay's farewell to the Transformers franchise is a deafening mess that will disappoint and enrage all but the most loyal of fans.

While some historians have already [rightly] criticised the film for the liberties it takes with historical fact, there is still plenty to be enjoyed and even learned from Alex von Tunzelmann's screenplay.
Destination Unknown rates as one of the most important films of recent years. It is required viewing.
A tug of love comedy-drama about a likeable uncle trying to retain custody of his maths genius niece, this unashamedly treads a clichéd path but somehow endears in spite of its over-familiarity.

Broomfield really only scratches the surface, filling in a few blanks surrounding Houston's life but also failing to paint a broader picture of the double tragedy at play, which extended to the death of Houston's daughter too.
Far from leaving you excited by the prospect of a Dark Universe packed with monsters, The Mummy leaves you cursing your own misfortune at having been tricked into seeing it.

Salazar's Revenge may be technically proficient and entertaining enough in fits and starts. But it lacks any real wow factor and struggles to recapture either the ingenuity of the early movies or bring anything new to the mix.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This latest entry into the DC Comics world is only partially successful before eventually succumbing to genre fatigue.

While the basic framework of the Jawbone story hardly feels fresh, the execution from everyone involved makes it easy to overlook some of the more familiar elements. It's a sobering film, in many ways, and a quietly impressive one throughout.
War For The Planet of The Apes... stands as a deeply impressive achievement and a shining example of how franchises can test audiences as much as they entertain.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A strong dynamic between Goldie Hawn and Amy Schumer cannot compensate for a lacklustre script and some bad taste comedy in Jonathan Levin's disappointing Snatched.

The film is a bleak offering... that begins dark and continues to get darker. As a result, it might not play to all tastes. But it remains a fiercely compelling and often shocking piece of work that lingers, if not haunts, for some time afterwards.
Terry George's historical epic The Promise may suffer from some self-consciously contrived romantic elements but its importance as a movie must not be under-estimated.
It's a very good sequel that can't quite recapture the greatness of its breath of fresh air predecessor.
As entertainingly absurd as ever, this eighth film in the franchise exists to satisfy the fans and frequently does so with aplomb without ever really mixing up the formula.
By populating the film with an array of colourful characters, some sharp dialogue and a keen sense of the absurd, Free Fire is a continually engaging, often thrilling cult classic in the making.
As flawed as The Boss Baby undoubtedly is, it remains fleet-footed enough to just about get away with it.
Beauty & The Beast is an efficient crowd-pleaser that makes it easy enough to overlook its flaws (especially if you're part of its target audience).
Big on spectacle but short on nuanced characterisation or coherent plotting, Kong: Skull Island is a deeply flawed but somehow still enjoyable romp that entertains in spite of its shortcomings.

It's not often that a film embedded in a franchise is allowed to break from its shackles to offer something genuinely different... which makes Logan, the final outing for Hugh Jackman's Wolverine, even more remarkable.
Overall, John Wick: Chapter 2 is a fantastically enjoyable follow-up to one of the best action films of recent years.
While's it's true that some (if not most) of the stories are hopelessly contrived, they're played out so well that you'll be having too much of a good time to care.
Chazelle's movie is a must-see experience and an instant classic, entirely worthy of the adulation and awards that have come its way.
Scott ensures that tension is maintained throughout and may even leave you gasping for breath on a couple of occasions.

Choose T2 because it's that rare sequel that works just as well -- and maybe sometimes better -- than the first. Choose T2 because... well because your cinema-going life will feel richer for having done so.

The third film in Disney-Pixar's Cars franchise is a back-to-basics journey of sorts, which reverts back to a more old-fashioned style of storytelling while also still managing to embrace some contemporary thinking.

Occasionally muddled and nowhere near as feminist as it should have been, Atomic Blonde still emerges -- battered and bruised -- as a tremendously entertaining action-adventure that deserves to kick-start its own franchise.
Spectacular, stylish, dark but still amusing, Spectre is a thrilling entry that combines the best of Bond movies old and new.
It is a landmark moment in blockbuster cinema that couldn't be more timely or more confident in its ability to be so.
It is a moving, thought-provoking piece of work that genuinely impresses.
It adheres to a classic British sense of humour, traditional values and warm-hearted storytelling. And yet, simultaneously, it's alive with invention.
Coco is a magical journey that is as uplifting as it is -- at times -- heart-breaking.

The Post is a smart, astute piece of cinema that entertains in spades while still having plenty to say on a political, social and journalistic level. It is a film worthy of the heavyweight talent it has attracted.
A trashy, enjoyable B-movie that succeeds in spite of its own absurdity.
Such is the power of McDonagh's screenplay, that you'll feel as though you've been taken on a journey that's as profound and moving as it is -- at times -- shocking and thought-provoking.
Molly's Game functions as both a scintillating character study and a fascinating expose. It's well worth booking a seat at this table.
The film feels like a flimsy attempt to get The Bellas back together. It's bereft of good ideas and tone deaf in terms of decent dialogue.

Johnson has delivered the goods: a film that isn't afraid to be ambitious, that delights and dazzles in equal measure, while providing a worthwhile emotional investment. It is a crowd-pleaser that will be wholeheartedly embraced by fans.
Ferdinand is a family-friendly heart-warmer that wins you over in spite of its flaws.
A vivid, heart-pounding, emotional rollercoaster of a film, Dunkirk is also one of the most immersive experiences you could ever wish to endure. But therein lies its genius.
Battle of the Sexes shows how those seeds of change were sewn. As such, it's game, set and match to female empowerment that deserves to be a smash hit with audiences.

As with the lamentable Suicide Squad, Justice League opts for action over substance, forgoing any depth and dropping in only token attempts at humour. It's essentially one long third act, which is as deafening as it is dull.
By turns charming and hilarious, Paddington 2 is that rare sequel that actually betters the original in almost every way.
Shot through with self-deprecating wit, slapstick (and knockabout) humour and all kinds of eccentric characters and elements, Thor: Ragnarok feels fresh, exciting and hugely entertaining.
Earth: One Amazing Day is designed to astonish and astound. It's packed with fascinating anecdotes, facts and figures.

Could Villeneuve match, let alone surpass, that original? Well, the answer is a resounding yes. ... Blade Runner 2049 is visually stunning, emotionally stimulating and -- at times -- emotionally devastating.
It's a measure of the film's overall success, however, that despite its hit-and-miss elements it still entertains tremendously for long periods.
A thoughtful, eye-opening experience that puts an all-too human face on a crisis that continues to make headlines.

Taking its inspiration from several grim statistics, the film functions as both a first rate thriller and the type of movie that highlights an American social injustice while posing serious questions for anyone willing to listen.
Philip John's Moon Dogs is overly generic and lacking in likeable characters.
Bigelow's latest is a harrowing and utterly gripping pressure cooker of a film that thrusts you into a nightmare from which many, sadly, are still unable to wake.
Logan's Lucky feels like a filmmaker re-indulging a passion. It's beautifully shot, as stylish as ever, impeccably acted and typically articulate.
One or two decent moments aside, The Hitman's Bodyguard is a wholly unsavoury experience.
Suburbicon is a dark delight -- a film that keeps you guessing, as well as appalled and amused. And the less you know going in, the better.
As intriguing and thought-provoking as Silence undoubtedly remains, it's very much a flawed piece of work that could well struggle to find much of an audience beyond the devoutly religious.
As lofty as the ambitions of The Limehouse Golem are, the film rather criminally wastes so much of its potential.
It's a film that should further the genuine sense of excitement surrounding this particular franchise revival, while standing as something of a classic in its own right.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Given the mind-boggling nature of the action and the quality of the performances, this once again delivers the kind of thrills we have come to expect and love.
If anything, a little more Enterprise was needed in the creative stakes to make this a more memorable experience. As things stand, it merely does what you'd expect.
A witty but tough noir thriller that offers a greatest hits compilation of the writer-director's best work to date, as well as something a little bit new.
While the film looks good visually, the quirks irritate.

While Money Monster never hits the heights of the films it aspires to -- such as '70s classic Dog Day Afternoon or financial titan Margin Call -- it's a worthwhile investment of your time that won't leave you feeling that short-changed.
It's refreshing to find a Jane Austen adaptation that's as witty and subversive as Whit Stillman's Love & Friendship.
X-Men: Apocalypse does a decent enough job without ever really blowing you away.
This is a powerhouse piece of indie cinema: tense, gripping, intelligent and gut wrenchingly violent.
Adults won't feel that angry at having seen it afterwards, while the little ones will be amused.
Captain America: Civil War is therefore a stunning achievement: one that far exceeds expectations to deliver one of the most thrilling superhero experiences you are ever likely to see.
[Eye In The Sky] already rates as one of the most important films of our time.
Serving as both a tribute to 80s sci-fi classics Starman and Close Encounters of The Third Kind and an intimate father-son tale, this touches the heart while dazzling the brain.

The good work hinted at in Margot Robbie's depiction of the playfully psychotic Harley Quinn or Jared Leto's Joker (sparingly used to the point of frustration) never get the time to breathe and grow that they clearly deserve.

For the young and innocent minded, there's plenty of knockabout fun and slapstick humour to enjoy, coupled with a timely message about tolerance and integration, while pop culture references abound for adults and film fans to savour.
In the main, this is powerhouse filmmaking: gritty, pulse-pounding, intelligent and viscerally thrilling. Genre fans should have a blast.
It's a guilty pleasure of a superhero movie that feels as naughty and as reckless as its central character intends. In that regard, it's mission more than accomplished.
If you're looking for something to amuse the kids on a cold, windy afternoon then Road Chip is bearable enough -- just. But a fifth film would really be a stretch.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: By turns breath-taking to look at and emotionally engaging, the film has to rate as a triumph for the way in which it can appeal to audiences of every age while perhaps relying more on classic storytelling elements.
A heavyweight in every sense that will keep you hooked from gritty start to celebratory finish.

Overall, 13 Hours does rather showcase the good, the bad and the ugly of Michael Bay. But it's better elements just about outweigh its worst, making this a much better movie than a lot of people would have predicted.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Spotlight is, without question, one of the best films of the year and a hands-down must-see.
THREE words best sum up Alejandro González Iñárritu's survival thriller The Revenant: brutal, breath-taking, astonishing.

It's beautiful to look at, brilliantly acted, breathlessly exciting, frequently amusing, yet capable of delivering some emotional gut-punches that take it into the dark territory inhabited by The Empire Strikes Back.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Steven Spielberg uncovers another important chapter in American [and world] history with spy drama Bridge of Spies, which grips by virtue of its continued relevance today and thanks to two riveting performances from Tom Hanks and Mark Rylance.
A sombre but thought-provoking finale to one of the most consistently gripping and intellectual franchises of recent years.
Chris Pratt and Jennifer Lawrence provide an engaging central presence in Passengers but even their chemistry isn't enough to prevent this romantic sci-fi drama from underwhelming.
Batman Vs Superman promises much but ends up proving to be something of a false dawn.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What it lacks in ingenuity, Finding Dory more than makes up for with enjoyability for all ages, making this a worthwhile plunge back into the ocean.

Dan Trachtenberg's 10 Cloverfield Lane is that rare kind of surprise: an event movie that delights by virtue of its smallness, its ingenuity and the fact that you'll know very little about it going in.
Laurent Tirard's film certainly boasts an interesting premise and has a certain amount of fun subverting expectation early on. But it quickly settles into a routine rom-com format.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Strong performances and a genuinely remarkable real-life tale help Ben Younger's boxing drama Bleed For This rise above the similarities it undoubtedly shares with other films in the genre.
The Carer emerges as a generally endearing, even heart-warming film that succeeds in spite of its flaws.
Sully rates among Eastwood's best movies as a director, while marking another personal acting triumph for Hanks.
Visually stunning but narratively basic, Disney's Moana is nevertheless a highly enjoyable family movie that doesn't suffer too much from adhering to formula.
Allied emerges as a curiously underwhelming affair that fails to do justice to the talents involved, or even the complexity of the story it is attempting to tell.
An entertaining if flawed first entry into a new wizard-based adventure.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Denis Villeneuve is fast becoming the go-to director for intelligent cinema; someone capable of traversing genre and putting his own stamp on things.

Tom Ford's second film as director is an intriguing, beautifully beguiling experience that provides plenty of food for thought. But there's also the suspicion that it's a sadistic piece of work in beautiful dressing.
A sugar coated candy rush of colourful, glittery excess, Trolls is a family movie clearly designed to leave you on the highest of highs.
The greatest puzzle surrounding Tom Hanks' latest foray into Dan Brown territory is just how these films continue to get made.
You'll have a good time -- but even those not easily offended may also leave with certain reservations.
It's the characters you remember more than the central narrative. But if taken on that basis, it's a journey well worth taking whether you've read the book or not.
As flawed as it certainly is, Free State of Jones still remains a worthwhile investment of anyone's time.

Some films are so ridiculous that they entertain in spite of their stupidity. Ben Affleck's The Accountant is a classic case in point; a supposedly serious, even muscular thriller, boosted by an A-list cast that quite simply doesn't add up.
There's just enough charm to compensate for the film's more obvious shortcomings.
A remake of the part animated 1977 film of the same name, this completely live action version re-imagines the story and emerges as a film capable of captivating both children and adults alike.
A deservedly grueling experience - but a highly recommended one too.
War Dogs could -- and perhaps should -- have been a lot harder hitting. As things stand, it's a frivolous take on a compelling story, driven by two excellent leads. You will be entertained.
Life On The Road hits more than it misses and even manages a couple of genuinely poignant moments in amongst the cringe-inducing comedy.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In a summer filled with remakes, reboots, sequels and superheroes that have more often than not disappointed, Fuqua has delivered a classic style of filmmaking that crowd-pleases without blowing you completely away.
A breezy, celebratory piece that recaptures the energy of the band in their prime.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It is this summer's gutsiest offering, worthy of its must-see status even if you may not be able to easily shake some of its more revolting images from your head in a hurry!
Destined to become a modern classic - and deservedly so.
Ultimately struggles to hold the attention.
A smartly constructed, emotionally involving, character-driven drama.
Disturbing, horrific yet also intelligent.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What it lacks in emotional depth, The Shallows more than makes up for with bite, as well as a knowing sense of its own absurdity.
Sex and sun, but no sizzle - Vicky Cristina Barcelona is watchable fluff, but *gasp* is it time for Woody to think about retiring? If so, he could do worse than Barcelona.
A rich, rewarding, polished diamond of a film.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Good The Bad The Weird is as scattershot as his second and third movies, but is well-staged, handsomely designed fun that never threatens to take itself seriously.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Marvel, stop punishing yourselves and put this unworkable franchise out of our misery.
Tiring toward the end as it breathlessly runs around tying-up loose ends, Paris 36 may ultimately bite off more than it can chew but is as lively as the titular city of lights.
Despite sounding like a mutated variant of a sexually transmitted disease, JCVD is infectious for all the right reasons.

Director of all trades Tsutsumi combines eyeball straining pop-promo visuals with the TV drama look that has blighted a lot of recent Japanese cinema, but deserves kudos for juggling timelines and characters so effectively.
movie_title: 20-seiki shônen: Honkaku kagaku bôken eiga (20th Century Boys 1: Beginning of the End) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This suspense vacuum has all the momentum of a Jason victim post-filleting.
With Paul Greengrass' eye for documentary-like realism Lopez-Gallego keeps the action close to the ground and physical.
movie_title: El Rey de la montaña (King of the Hill) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Notorious plays even more conventional than Eminem's 8 Mile or 50 Cent's Get Rich or Die Tryin', with its TV movie predictability (rueful voiceover and all) taking the gangsta out of gangsta rap.
An uncompromising and humane look at issues facing both teachers and students, The Class is an uplifting, thought-provoking, and it's only when the final bell rings you realise just how good it is.
Surveillance may brim with violence and unease, but it's a puzzle box film you'll have grim fun solving.
This compelling biopic is proof of what an engaging director he can be when not filming his own belly-button fluff.
Viewers expecting the heroics of Black Book or Female Agents may be surprised at the subdued, procedural pace Madsen opts for.
movie_title: Flammen & Citronen (Flame & Citron) (The Flame and the Lemon) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Who Killed Nancy? is most engrossing when it settles into a comfortable VH1 Behind the Music groove, complete with artsy animation and low-budget recreations.
Randy's climactic recreation of a former glory befits a film about someone unable to prevent himself spinning out of control, and is a smackdown conclusion to a mature, powerful tearjerker.
Not an embarrassment, but definitely a missed opportunity.

The director may unwisely opt for a lachrymose denouement that ruffles the carefully sustained mood, but this delightfully grim horror is worth seeking out - just follow the breadcrumb trail of positive reviews.

The amusingly cumbersomely titled OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies is about ten minutes too long for a great plot to gag ratio, but there are enough smart chuckles here to make the promised sequel worth looking forward to.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Through sheer will and fanboy love Snyder has succeeded where Gilliam and Greengrass failed, bringing Watchmen to the screen faithfully and smartly, if not completely.
Li brings the intensity previously seen in Fearless to his compromised General, while Lau is a noble savage, vying with Pang for Lian's affection in the obligatory romantic subplot.
Jolie looks every inch the star, but as with Joan Crawford or Ingrid Bergman, gives a believable and shining performance despite her beauty, while Malkovich hasn't been this good in years.

The Children could be a blackly comic warning to give kids their MMR jabs, an anti (or pro) abortion metaphor (one male victim looks like they're giving birth and Toynton's character was almost aborted), or simply a bloody, good horror film.
Succeeds in making the 109 minute running time feel like at least eight of the eleven years he took to shoot the film.
Hopefully, with this polished policier Maillot will get the small screen funding to expand this story and tie up some of the intriguing loose ends.
Carlyle's central turn is one of the year's most poignant and tear-jerking acting displays, easily erasing the misstep of Eragon.
Trouble the Water employs Kim Roberts' startling camcorder footage to reveal how little New Orleans prepared its citizens for the coming disaster.
Understated and thought-provoking, and alongside The Visitor should establish Abbass as a major female presence in international cinema.

A lugubrious pace, shots that hang... and hang... and hang... long after most other directors would call "Cut", and scant dialogue but a surplus of portentous close-ups make the film a somnambulant chore.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Australia would love to be The African Queen, but is more The Australian Prince Charles: silly, longwinded, heart in the right place.
The Spirit's greatest crime is that it is so boring - encapsulated in a scene where the Spirit and the Octopus slug it out for an eternity as both are sucked into treacly mud.

The Reader suffers from Weinstein syndrome, in which an interesting novel is filleted to its bare skeleton by overpowering producer Harvey Weinstein, and made safe, easy to digest, and oh-so award friendly.
Hard hearts may balk at the unashamed sentiment, black and white morality, and question-flashback contrivances, but let them eat pie and mash: this is a tangy banquet of smile-on-the-face feel good.

My Bloody Valentine is best consumed in eye-popping 3-D, as director Lussier delights in putting the audience on the business end of the killer's pickaxe or at the epicentre of messy eviscerations, and immerses them in the foreboding mine shafts.
Sobering and cautiously optimistic, Havana Marking's documentary is a treat.
Hitchcock succeeded in wanting to give popcorn munchers a movie to smile at. And he was never this playful again.
This bouquet of nicely observed private moments packs an unexpectedly profound emotional punch.
A striking thriller with a strong central performance from Gallic Robert Powell-alike Lindon.
Heartfelt and well-behaved, this slight story of a divorced man attempting a reconciliation with his prickly mum is gracefully watchable, but resistant to embrace any actual drama.
Summer Scars packs more suspense into 68 minutes than most big budget thrillers do at twice the length.
Caught between wanting to make a bold statement and deliver edge of the seat thrills, New Town Killers is a curious mix.
Soi Cowboy's wet concrete pacing, dialogue free scenes, and prolonged takes will test the patience of even the most understanding movie buff.
With ambition to spare and a talent for shocks and surprises worthy of seasoned directors, Kevorkian has revived the spirits of those who thought the English ghost story was dead.
Mainstream attempts at melodrama, sweeping crane shots and a Charlotte Gray gloss unbalance Wajda's desired mood.
It's a solidly-made, enjoyable story that manages to rope in some notable cameos (can anyone spot Jimmy Carr) and shows Moran is a name to watch as a director.
Those who thought Alpine warbling ended with Julie Andrews as a nun (ie. all of us), get ready to open your ears, and your mind... and your mouth, as this yodelling malarky is catchy stuff.

Fired Up is cinema as abuse, and its chief victim is any paying audience. To have shelled out cash for this witless farrago of sub-Porky's japery and straight-to-bargain-bin acting would be the airborne spin that broke the cheerleader's back.
With Ran action choreographer Hiroshi Kuze on swordplay duties, the fisticuffs is suitably impressive, with even Ayase not relying too heavily on quick editing.

Those unfamiliar with Mishima's work may find the expressionistic novel sequences overly rich, but Schrader's film is a visually arresting, imaginative and intelligent overview of a difficult subject.
movie_title: Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Capturing the site, the sounds, the smells, and the sweat of a major musical happening, Soul Power is irresistible.
Ultimately, there is something refreshing about The Proposal's undemanding humour and unabashed feel-good factor.
The Midnight Meat Train is destined for cult status as an minor horror gem.
More a mood piece than a typical documentary, it takes time to acclimatise to Gideon Koppel's quiet study of life in his mum's Welsh village, but once you're in there is much to enjoy.
Martyrs is a five star example of what modern horror can do, or a one star mugging of all that is decent. Forgive us if we go with the former.
Vanity bunkum of the first order wait until TV for this one.
Those in the mood for something kinda dumb but lotsa fun look no further.
While the visuals never rise above TV-movie adequacy and some background acting hovers at am-dram level, The World Unseen's central story is strong enough to hold attention.
Three stars for its undemanding fun and occasional wry barb about lost youth. But, add one or even two more stars depending on how much bedroom wall space Zac currently commands.

As layered as its title (lifted from the Morrissey song, Let The Right One Slip In), this is the most original vampire movie since Guillermo del Toro's Cronos, and is likely to hit every top ten films list of the year.
Offbeat and violent with laughs that frequently stick in the throat, this isn't Knocked Up but if the idea of Napoleon Dynamite meets First Blood appeals, you'll go home smiling.
The pros, including sharp dialogue from a triumvirate of writers including Bourne scribbler Tony Gilroy, outweigh the cons in a polished, engrossing whydunnit you'll want to see more than once.
Sorely in need of an injection of black humour or wit, City Rats is a long trawl through picture postcard London, populated by underwritten characters mouthing unlikely dialogue.

Crisply shot with visual flourishes punctuating the unfussy direction, despite a lack of carnage, this is an accomplished and impressive depiction of some absolute barnpots. Those who like their laughs lightly flavoured with ash should check it out.
movie_title: Funuke Domo, Kanashimi no ai Wo Misero (Funuke Show Some Love, You Losers!) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While too picture postcard and toothless, Cheri is an enjoyable, undemanding bouquet of period drama.
With its rich, mournful score and striking, snowy visuals this risks lapsing into suicidal miserablism, but emerges as something far more rewarding.
The feeling of unity and pride pierces even the hardest heart, particularly as many of these kids have experienced devastating conflicts in their homeland.
Shot with pace, energy and gusto, the rucks are worthy of the title. Featherweight, but not without scrappy charm.
It seems churlish to overly criticise. Kaufman's daring, ambition and frequent moments of beauty and sadness are worth the overindulgence.
Patronising, unsexy, and heavy with the musty smell of a director past his sell-by-date, you're advised to cut this off at the ankles.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This third act fumble knocks an unusual four star thriller down to a two star misfire.
movie_title: L'Empreinte de l'ange (Mark of an Angel) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Tormented works so successfully. The laughs are funny, the scares genuine, and the flashbacks to Darren's caught on camera torture all too believable.

Raimi keeps the gore flowing - Evil Dead fans will cheer a moment of eyeball zaniness and a séance that features a levitating demon- but what separates him from grunge meisters Rob Zombie and Eli Roth are the subtler flourishes.

Ambitious, technically excellent in its documentary-like immediacy, and played with true conviction by Fassbender (whose weight-loss is enough to make you wince), Hunger nonetheless leaves the brain undernourished.
Tarkovsky's film will be forever confined to a dark cul-de-sac in the arthouse ghetto because of its sheer monotony.
Despite the title, A Bloody Aria is unlikely to be music to the ears of extreme cinema fans.
Don't be put off by the black and white and subtitles, this is a family film with intelligence, energy and charm to spare.
movie_title: Alice in den Städten (Alice in the Cities) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: All involved should be sent straight to the glue factory.

Wise beyond his years, Morace's Tommi is a knockout performance of resilience and acceptance of his parents' foibles and by the final scene of this assured debut feature there is unlikely to be a dry eye in the house.
movie_title: Along the Ridge (Anche libero va bene) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Recommended for audiences who thought Kevin Bacon's Death Sentence was too restrained; everyone else steer clear.
Ultimately, U2 3D will infuriate as many as it dazzles - attendance depends on how much Bono-me you can stomach or how grabbed you are by 3D cinema.
An enthusiastic cast are partially up to the challenge, but some of the thesping belongs on a Straight-to-Video shelf.
Fade to Black is as sleek and attractive as the chrome polished vintage cars Huston travels in, but never truly gets in gear.
In no way an easy watch, but as a meticulous record of a tragedy and the feats of bravery it inspired, this is an excellent movie.

While no masterpiece, Children of Glory never has a dull moment. The seemingly CGI-free streetfighting, with revolutionaries facing deadly Soviet tanks, packs an explosive punch (courtesy of action and stunt legend Vic Armstong).
Short, sweet and modest, like Floriane's aquatic sport Water Lilies is pretty and dainty to the eye, but there is a raging torrent of activity beneath the surface.
Eight years before another Harmony Korine film is not a bad prospect.
The Book of Revelation is interesting enough to hope Kokkinos follows it with something equally daring.

One day aliens will land on Earth offering us answers to the secrets of the Universe. But, because of films like The Hottie & the Nottie they will deem us unworthy and return to the Heavens once more in their carbon-free interstellar cruisers.
The meaning of life just might be hidden here... only don't expect to find it on a first viewing.
Beaufort is reflective, quietly powerful, and thought provoking - a sobering postscript to the movie is that one month after filming finished, the 33 day "Second Lebanon War" broke out.
Illuminating, surreal, tear-jerking and funny, Half Moon is an unforgettable voyage into a land little seen.
Visually, the film is an uninteresting as the similarly dour Don't Touch the Axe, and now Breillat's health is failing it may be time she hung-up her viewfinder.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Told with ruthless efficiency and no sentiment or sermonizing, stands as a fitting tribute to the human spirit.
Nimbly weaving between mid-life crisis melodrama, noir, comedy, horror, this is Lars von Trier meets Michael Haneke and, in a good way, one of the year's most uncomfortable watches.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Amigorena has an eye for off-kilter camerawork and attractively shoots Paris and Venice as Binoche and the two twenty-somethings flee Turturro, but its existentialist musings and breezy road movie charm are no replacement for espionage movie brains.
movie_title: A Few Days in September (Quelques jours en septembre) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The inevitably brutal denouement provides a satisfactory close to a smartly observed and exhilarating movie.
Waters still has the audience-friendly filth to remind you exactly who this is talking, and by the closing credits words such as "bears" and "blossoming" have lost their innocence.
A minor work for the famous Gallic acting export, The Singer still leaves a song in the heart.
What could have been a mini-Scream is ultimately I'll Always Know You Did Last Halloween the 13th.
Daddy D-Day for Cuba's career.
Illuminating, witty and touching, Blame it on Fidel is a gem just awaiting discovery.
movie_title: Blame It on Fidel (La Faute a Fidel) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Watch Princess for this smart channelling of exploitation movie energy rather than the heavy-handed sermonising. And for an intelligent and sober look at porn, re-watch Boogie Nights.
Sidelines Sir Francis Drake in favour of the dashing Raleigh, nicely summing up the film: all flash, very little bang.
Paced like a Terrence Malick or Stanley Kubrick film it will not appeal to everyone, but for those accustomed to using their eyes, ears and brains at the movies this is a magnificent experience.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shot on location in London, New York and Karachi, Infinite Justice uses an impressively broad canvas to paint a picture of dangerous fundamentalism and Western opportunism and corruption.

Apart from the monochrome photography, all that dates the film is the chain-smoking and the fact that these are theatre folk rather than movie stars (frequent in-jokes about the low art of Hollywood pepper the script).
Code Name: The Cleaner is one of the year's big stinkers.
Solid performances and a well-manifested sense of the supernatural makes KM 31 a journey worth taking.
Forget Guy Ritchie's mockney morons, this is the real, chilling, deal.
The story is fragmented into flashforwards and flashbacks as Alex's narration skirts around the traumatic event, but culminates in a low-key but meaningful realization of sorts for the quiet teen.
Bridget Jones's (Incend)Diary, Maguire is to be commended for attempting a contemporary terrorist drama, but seems more comfortable in the big-knickered North London fantasy world.
Equivalent to attending a massive feast only to discover the main course is missing, The Banquet is frequently stunning, beautifully shot, but ultimately undernourishing.
movie_title: Ye yan (Legend of the Black Scorpion) (The Banquet) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Happy-Go-Lucky might have sit-com spin-off potential, but like one of Poppy's driving lessons, it lurches around, grinding gears, and ends up back where it started.
Watching the disintegration of Baghdad alongside the band members' aspirations makes this an enlightening and impassioned account of the Middle Eastern crisis.
The director's usual traits are present and correct - glacial pacing, silent film-like direction, a love of nature - meaning audiences' eyes will soon Rohmer about the room looking for an exit.

A good example of a film grabbing the audience by the collar, only for the audience to shake themselves free, The Chaser is a promising fusion of detective thrills, sweaty-palmed horror, and black comedy that ultimately does not hang together.
Only seventeen Lord of the Rings-esque endings spoil the fun, but this sweet take on teen-angst romance quietly impresses.
movie_title: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Undemanding fans of softcore nudity and hardcore gore will chew it down, but real horror afficionados will crave more meat on the bone.

With face carbon-frozen in rage and mid-Atlantic scowl in place, the Brit export is fast proving himself the most reliably fun actor on the scene, standing a good chance of becoming this generation's Charles Bronson if he keeps making movies like this.
This is Scott Thomas' film, and she commands it with a quiet performance (literally), conveying a range of conflicted emotions through her expressive eyes and gaunt, ashen features.

But The Fall defies low expectations, proving the director can now partner his exquisite pictures with a ripping yarn.
This artiness is everywhere, the movie too busy courting "visually stunning" poster quotes to actually get down to the business of being scary.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Contender for best documentary of the year, Heavy Load contains a classic moment of Spinal Tap-ism as Paul, when Heavy Load is at its lowest ebb, ponders why Michael says he hates him.

Entertaining dross, but could be another seven year's bad luck for Keifer's big screen career.
Dark, compelling, and with the courage of its hard-nosed convictions, La Zona starts off gripping and squeezes like a vice come the disturbing conclusion.

Despite the boom in Asian cinema since its first release Ashes of Time Redux is quite simply one of the best films of the year.

The Wackness offers more than fuzzy giggles and bongwater-weak characters.
Difficult, frustrating, but engrossing and ultimately enriching, make time to see it.

When the record stops spinning Flashbacks Of A Fool doesn't amount to much more than "learn from past mistakes and don't take your life for granted", but it's strikingly shot, perfectly played, and rather well scored.
Aptly-titled.
Dull and dreary despite DeVison's enthusiasm, take heart in remembering the chances of catching Captain Eager on a big screen are nil.
movie_title: Captain Eager and the Mark of Voth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The first five-star blockbuster of the year has arrived, and in style.
Worth spending a penny on, but not much more.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Married Life may fall short of the best Hollywood melodrama, but its nicely observed situations and old-fashioned storytelling ironically lend this a freshness more on-the-nose infidelity tales are missing.

Lucy Walker's inspirational, award-winning documentary, which leaves condescension and treacle out in the cold, emerging as one of the year's most illuminating, heartbreaking, and life-affirming movies.
This is better than the dull Edward Norton vehicle The Illusionist, all involved should have conjured up a companion piece to Christopher Nolan's The Prestige.
Carter is more energetic than Demme's film that fires on all cylinders only when Carter calmly but persuasively faces down his critics or recounts his time as the most powerful man on Earth.

Flawed, but a forceful debut from a promising director.
Delayed by over a year, but don't let that fool you: this may be lightweight, but it knows what goes bump in the night.

Leone's film, authentic yet hyper-stylised, complete with the coolest cowboy fashion (gunslingers in long coats has never been bettered), mainstreet shootouts and raw, memorable characters, is a tough, leathery sundried masterpiece.

A shrug of a movie.

Delirious, dumb, but admittedly fun.

movie_review_blurb: King Kelly is a film worth seeking out for fans who like social commentary mixed intelligently with entertainment.
Fans will find a lot to love with Breaking Dawn Part 2, both expected and unexpected, and critics will find a non-stop checklist of laughable dialogue, poor acting and sub-par special effects.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A smart, funny, sweet and well-acted romantic comedy.

Steven C. Miller's remake of the nasty 80s original keeps the violence and mayhem but adds both personality and humor with the result being a fun slasher that vastly improves on Silent Night, Deadly Night.
Viewers have come to expect visceral combat between characters who feel tangible in their appearance and reactions, but there's none of that here.
American Mary is not a great film, but it's a great deal of fun.

Quote not available.

Evil Dead is a better film than was probably expected, but as good as the effects and bloodwork are here -- and they are jaw-droppingly fantastic -- they don't make up for the film's incredibly shoddy and flaccid script.

What it does get right is the sheer adrenaline rush of watching kinetic cinema crafted by a serious and talented filmmaker unafraid of showing onscreen carnage in his quest to entertain and create a new action hero.
It's easy to get bored by the necessary repetition found in a setup like this, but the script finds more than a few ways to keep things moving.
Jack's journey is allowed to feel natural (if increasingly obvious) as he moves closer to the unknown dangers hidden behind the truth, and the trip is ultimately a rewarding one.
Graceland is a deceptively simple thriller with a smart setup and a cruelly efficient execution.
Quote not available.
The Way, Way Back is a funny and wonderfully-told tale about the beginning of one teen's autonomy at a time where everything remains out of his control.
100 Bloody Acres is extremely funny comedy for viewers who can handle bloodshed, death and yappy little dogs being kicked across the room. (No dogs were harmed in the making of this film.)
Thanks to the new revelatory and inspiring documentary A Band Called Death, the truth behind the band's nearly simultaneous birth and death may yet find them their proper place in music history.
Deliver Us From Evil makes no excuses for the actions of its antagonists, but it's still interested in exploring the motivations of all involved.
movie_title: Deliver Us From Evil (Fri os fra det onde) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It turns out Elysium isn't the summer's savior that some may have hoped, and worse, it's actually a lesser film than some of this season's other big movies that underwhelmed.
If nothing else his film stands out for its quaint scale in a summer of gigantic blockbusters, but that lack of size isn't enough to warrant a watch.
While it misses the mark in some important areas it comes far closer than most. And bottom line? It's a fun and bloody good time at the movies.
A smart script makes the film good, but near perfect delivery by some of our favorite unhinged actors make it great.
Vulgaria is being marketed as a "dirty" movie, but that's underselling the film's real strengths.
Movies need more than non sequiturs, gags and nonsense, and it's there where Dupieux fails his film and the audience.
South Korea may just be the most exciting place on the planet these days when it comes to stylish and violent thrillers.
Wonderful performances across the board; fantastic chemistry between Plaza and Duplass.
Sadly, V/H/S is more miss than hit.

Citadel is a solid enough horror thriller anchored by a strong lead performance and an earnest heart. The second and third acts could have used a polish to punch up some otherwise dull happenings, but the film remains another fine genre offering.

movie_review_blurb: Vigalondo's interest in the invasion extends only so far as it works to isolate his characters and force them into interaction.
Reveal too much and you've done all the heavy lifting for the audience. Reveal too little and they're left scratching their heads. The Woman in the Fifth will leave you very itchy indeed.
