The most incredible 25 year old film you'll see in theaters this year.
Quote not available.
Writer/director Anders Morganthaler has made an odd film that seems as unsure of its point as it does its execution.
Their uncertain flirtation and growing affection feel authentic, and their situation is bound to remind viewers of similar circumstances in their own lives.
There's an attempt here to make the ghostly villain, Charlie, into a memorable antagonist - kidding, there's no attempt at all.
A wickedly sharp, funny, and suspenseful look at the thin divide between our emotions and our actions.
The message comes through loud and clear - stay away from Australia.
Nacho Vigalondo's best and most accomplished, but the real breakout is Jason Sudeikis.
It's not Blue Ruin great, but it's in the same colorful neighborhood.
All four segments have something worth recommending, and one is a terrifically creepy success.
An effortlessly beautiful ode to the loves destined to last a lifetime even when those we love are no longer in our lives.
It's funny and features some strong performances, but the film's premise - and almost every moment devoted to that premise - are a tonally confused and inconsistent misfire.
Do you love THE OFFICE's self-sabotaging regional manager? You'll like him as a struggling musician.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's undeniably impressive how well it recovers from its irritatingly obnoxious and terribly-charactered first act to become a thrilling and suspenseful little morality tale.
Like the building at its core, the bones are strong but the flesh hanging from them is weak and sickly.
Who do Voodoo? Not you if you value quality horror and your free time.
Familiar but never dull thanks to exciting, stylish action, engaging-enough characters, and a dedication to not pulling its punches.
A terrific comedy, but a somewhat muddled thriller.
There's fun to be had, but it's a forgettable romp serving only to bring us one step closer to the next entry in the franchise and the cold, inevitable grip of death itself.
Not quite enough here to fill its admittedly short running time, but the themes and visuals offer some nightmarish distractions from your day.
Does nothing new beyond the rarity of pairing two A-list actors in a genre piece   but minor stupidities aside it succeeds in delivering plenty of thrills and suspense.
Less tangible than the titular ghost, but it's a slick and attractive sci-fi/action picture all the same.
A darkly affecting tale about the high and sometimes bloody cost of self awareness and sociopathic conviction.

The Void offers more than a few strongly dramatic beats and plenty of visual thrills as violent encounters and monstrous creations paint the walls red. It doesn't land the destination, but the road to hell is never a dull one.
As devastatingly beautiful as it is beautifully devastating.
A bloated and dull film kept alive by a thread of  fight scenes, an effortlessly charming Russell, and the mild entertainment of counting how many times someone says "family."
Fairly one-note on the narrative front, but as it delivers plenty of laughs for its duration it's difficult to fault the film for *only* being funny.
It walks a fine line between entertaining thriller and psychological drama, but it succeeds at merging the two into a darkly memorable feature.
It moves with the force of a woman scorned by the world itself, and fighting back has rarely been this satisfying and entertaining.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It might be time to put this franchise down.
Let this one go to voicemail, and just re-watch 1408 instead.
The bottom line here is don't let this Intruder into your house.
The Shallows is a terrific little thriller that might just leave you dreading your next trip to the beach.
Along with a ton of laughs, a terrific score, a great cast, and the best movie dog since Up the Creek.
Low-key action junkies will be satisfied with this 88-minute romp, but Mel Gibson's fans will be rewarded with much more.
Almost works better as a revenge tale between a tree and a logger than it does a suspenseful story of survival. (It does not work well as either.)
All three leads do strong work with characters and a story that never quite approach their level, and together they make the film entertaining and engrossing despite itself.
An entertaining watch despite its missteps, and it's still far better than most found footage films as it delivers solid performances, smart observations, and a fun ride.
A smart and twisted breath of fresh air for a sub-genre at risk of growing stale.
Wingard and Barrett's previous films are told with style, wit, and energy that amount to a voice uniquely their own. That voice is sorely missed here.
Denis Villeneuve's latest is smart, hopeful, and intimately devastating science fiction.
Safe Neighborhood is a rarity that pairs immense entertainment with dark, vicious thrills.
It's a refreshing spin on the familiar that feels at one with the world of 28 Days Later while still plotting its own path in character and emotional weight.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is as straightforward a thriller as M. Night Shyamalan has delivered in years, and that works both to its advantage and detriment. And no, it's not an even split between the two.
While details grow shaky - the logic and repercussions of certain actions don't seem to hold up - the effect is still an oddly original effort that marks Miller as a filmmaker to watch.
Trash Fire entertains with laughs and thrills, but it also leaves you with an unexpected weight on your chest.
For all that feels uninspired and unnecessary in Rogue One, it's no disaster.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: More action than horror/sci-fi, but it works well to create an entertaining hybrid fueled by charismatic actors, strong CG work, and some solidly exciting combat sequences.
It fails to generate anything resembling scares or suspense here, and the fault rests almost entirely with the script.
It becomes a more enjoyable movie around the midway point, but it also becomes a lesser one.
A relentlessly beautiful film and one of the decade's most exhilarating and satisfying love stories.
Arsenal offers up some minor Nicolas Cage-fueled laughs, but as an action movie it's firing blanks. Skip it and go rent Marauders instead.
No tale at all would have been an improvement on this exhaustively bland one.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Guaranteed to leave you hungry for good food and a better movie.
She does not disappoint.
An unhurried look at one woman's journey of self-discovery.
movie_title: A Bride for Rip Van Winkle (Rippu van winkuru no hanayome) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fuses office politics, bloody violence, and pure silliness into a fun little romp that's ultimately as entertaining as it is forgettable.
An improvement over the dour idiocy of Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice and the silliness of Suicide Squad. Incremental maybe, but still, an improvement.
Splits its attentions between two threads, but only half delivers spectacularly with heart, thrills, and some truly beautiful story beats while the other limps through space.
Dumb fun is still fun.
Sets the scene well and ups the ante with characters we can't help but care about... even if it does fail to take advantage of the gift of nature.
The only winning move is not to play.

Low-key weirdness and high-energy intensity may not seem like an ideal match, but the pairing of director Panos Cosmatos and Nicolas Cage sees both talents giving everything they've got into a uniquely memorable collaboration.
Some segments work with smart writing, solid acting, and a sexy vibe, but most are weighed down with witless gab and slightly exaggerated performances.
An immensely satisfying and highly entertaining journey touching on multiple genres in search of a simple truth. Plus a machine gun-wielding schoolgirl.
A solid action picture that never tries to overstep its bounds or abilities, and in a world overflowing with big movies heavy on CG and light on charm it's more than enough.
In space, no one can hear you [fart noise].
Like the best blockbusters it's flawed but ridiculously entertaining anyway, and like too few of them it's also so incredibly important.
Nicolas Cage completists will see it, but no one else should feel obligated.
Francois Ozon's latest leans towards the stronger end of his filmography despite a penchant for some over the top shenanigans.
It may not be something to shout about, but it's definitely worth an indoor-voiced cheer.

Mohawk finds power in its themes and performances while also delivering a handful of genre-friendly moments, but while its ambitions noticeably exceed those of Geoghegan's terrific debut, they come at a price the budget can't quite afford
The Cured is a terrifically tense thriller that works both as a simple genre effort and a deeper exploration of how we treat those who've trespassed against us.
This is ultimately a lesser film when it comes to scares, suspense, and atmosphere, but it edges out the original in its sense of fun and energy. So go ahead, answer the door.
Guilt, ghosts, and a powerhouse performance by Toni Collette help make this a must-see for horror fans.

Writer/director Yoshida Daihachi fills his brightly-lit scenes with darkness between relatives - some mild, some involving physical abuse - but the occasional laughs and visual flairs prevent the movie from ever becoming a dour affair.
movie_title: Funuke Domo, Kanashimi no ai Wo Misero (Funuke Show Some Love, You Losers!) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Tragedy Girls is pure bliss for those of us who love a skilled pairing of gore and guffaws.
A beautifully-affecting rarity in many ways, from its content to its themes, and it's every bit one of this year's best superhero movies.
The Foreigner doesn't break the mold, but it never tries to - and doesn't need to.
John Cusack plays the villain, but you've never cheered harder for him to win.
It's not a fun film, but it is a tensely thrilling one.
Goes off on a few too many tangents, but its core theme comes through by the time the credits roll. Whether its worth waiting for it to hit though is a different story.
A town terrified of the shadows yet too stupid to turn on some lights.
A Twilight Zone-worthy story obscured minute by minute with tonal inconsistencies, convoluted plot turns, and a highly unlikable lead character.
Increased stupidity at the end aside, it's more often than not a tight and effective little thriller offering a strong script, solid performances, and some creepy beats.
Comedy is subjective, so while I'm about to trash this lazy and obnoxiously unfunny movie you may actually enjoy it. Especially if you have an terrible sense of humor.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The new Spider-Man's solo Marvel debut is a near-perfect mash-up of superhero movie and teen comedy.
Issues are minor in comparison to what it gets right, and what it gets right is the action... the occasionally brutal, frequently ridiculous, always entertaining action.
It's not Stephen King's THE DARK TOWER, but it is a perfectly fine YA adventure. Make of that what you will.
Sharply directed/edited look at the high cost of cheating, and while its action is far removed from life & death situations it delivers tense and highly suspenseful sequences.
The talents involved commit to their craft and to the film, and the result is a rare horror movie that will have you jumping, smiling, and actually giving a damn.
A slick and suspenseful landing until it fails to stick the landing.
As delicately beautiful a film as you're likely to see.
A powerful film set in the relatively recent past, but with messages and themes that remain every bit as relevant in today's world.
'IT' is the 'Stand By Me' of Stephen King's cinematic horror canon.
A simple premise, a steady build-up, and a fantastically creepy third act that lands with a punch to the gut.
Works as pure entertainment with laughs and gore aplenty, but its lasting power is in its recognition of the monsters within us all.
Makes a misstep in its final minutes, but the remainder of the film succeeds at building suspense, increasing our pulses, and making viewers care about one woman's struggle.
If you're not smiling during this one, you're probably an a**hole.
A fun, endearing look at a fictional creation, and it's enough to make you a fan of the show that never was.
Replace is a bloody cautionary tale about both the human condition and the inevitable reach of science. See it before you're too old to appreciate its warning.
A funny, bloody blast.
Easily one of Tobe Hooper's better films as it entertains and frightens without ever feeling the need to sink into debauchery or tawdry terror.
A beautiful, hauntingly precarious coming of age film that uses mystery and an at times dream-like atmosphere to create a mesmerizing tale.
It's no Thunderheart.
The most broadly appealing film to come out of Greece in some time, but it's every bit as deserving of the attention afforded to its crazier cousins.
Creep is an exercise in the kind of unease we've all experienced.
There are bad people. Sometimes they die, sometimes they go to jail, but they'll always be recapped by the end credits.
Gorgeous visuals, an immensely talented cast, and a handful of harrowing moments create a compelling feature guaranteed to leave you disinterested in ever climbing Everest.
Not only a massive step up in every way it's also the best YA genre adaptation since Beautiful Creatures. Hopefully audiences don't screw up and avoid this one too.
High-Rise is an incredibly funny and absurd look at class, blind consumerism, and the destabilization of community.
Southbound, like almost every anthology film ever made, is a mixed bag, but that said there are no absolute stinkers here.
Make no mistake, The Witch is a horror film, but it's as interested in the terrors we bring upon ourselves as it is the ones well out of our natural control.
It should be shown in schools. It should lead to an increase in education funding. It should encourage you to stock up on duct tape.
[Rec] sets out to terrify and it succeeds nicely.
Finds beauty, calm, and trust between two strangers and makes it as compelling an experience as any big-budget spectacle could ever hope to create.

It's never dull, occasionally surprising and unafraid to delve into Bond's life more than any film since On Her Majesty's Secret Service. Unfortunately, all of that comes at the price of gaping plot holes and staggering lapses in logic.
Bone Tomahawk is a major disappointment.
The Final Girls is a fun mash-up of then and now, and any slasher fan should find themselves enamored with its nostalgic touches, new tweaks and pure enthusiasm.
There are fun beats to be found here, but it feels like an idea that began with its playful title and never went too far beyond that conceit.
Takes some time to find solid footing and pull us in, but the promise of dark dangers is ultimately fulfilled.
The ghouls, goblins, and Abominable Snowman all pale beside the film's biggest horror - the outdated and insulting notion that boys rule and girls drool.
Just as entertaining as the action itself is the back and forth banter between Olga Kurlenko and James Purefoy.
It isn't a game-changer in its chosen sub-genre, but it's a solid entry that understands the desire for a more entertaining darkness.
Far from the worst of the family/holiday sub-genre, but don't expect it to become an annual tradition.
What starts as a fast and loose adventure begins to creak and groan as it tries to tie everything together with a weak, vengeance-colored bow.
Everyone is deserving of credit, but the holy trinity at play here is Coogler, Jordan, and Stallone.
It never comes close to tapping into the potential for real character depth and emotional drama alongside the horror.
The setup feels familiar, and while there are certain beats that feel unavoidable as the film moves forward there are just as many expected moments that never come.
Every bit a magical romance that should appeal to fans of films like Il Mare with its engaging love story and accepted impossibility.
Horror for easy marks and comedy for people who wish there were more funny films about Alzheimer's, but it's just entertaining enough.
It seems Tarsem's grown out of his artsy phase with his latest effort, and now for the first time ever a Tarsem film can be called drab, dull and mostly lifeless.
Is it a winner? The answer's yes, but only if you consider not losing to be winning.
It's a darkly comic thriller that also serves as a fantastic introduction to a character I hope we see again soon.
A lazy, flat and poorly written thriller that fails at grabbing viewers by the throat or by the heart.
The character work and humanity impress, but thankfully the film never lets the depth and heart get in the way of the creepy, terror-inducing bits.
It's Gumby sci-fi - so focused on being bendy and fun that its attempts at more serious tangents immediately crack under the pressure.
Holds your attention hostage even as the urge to look away from the terror grows within you.
Its narrative leans toward the untenable side of melodrama and pushes viewers away when it should be pulling them in for a suspenseful finale.
Never really cruel in the way viewers would expect - this isn't a mean-spirited film - and instead it ultimately becomes about the cruelty we discover within ourselves.
There is so much wrong with the new Fantastic Four that writing about it feels more like an autopsy than a review.
Save your breath and your time - let Submerged sink to the bottom of your to-watch pile.
If A Hard Day sounds like a Korean mash-up of After Hours and I Know What You Did Last Summer, well, that's not too far off in regard to the setup.
I'd wonder if the writers even bothered to watch the original film if I didn't know they actually wrote that one too.
Because sometimes subtle symbolism needs repeating... she waits for a return visit from her rapist by tending her front garden.
It's not brought to us by "Epic Pictures, the #1 leader in LaserDisc sales" for nothing.
A slight affair, and while it's an enjoyable enough experience it's probably not something you'll be discussing come Monday morning.
As far as tennis comedies go, this one sits somewhere between WIMBLEDON and BALLS OUT. Make of that what you will.
Delivers beautifully crafted action sequences, a colorful gallery of characters and far more story than it needs.
An engaging tale that doesn't reach the level of epic but should appeal to fans of wuxia action and majestic visuals all the same.
A journey fraught with atmosphere, mystery, grim discoveries... and maybe a few laughs?
Somewhere around the mid-point the wide open spaces they're traversing close in around them to become an oppressive and claustrophobic nightmare.
Things start deceptively slow, but stick with it as the smart humor and story turns become more and more engaging and enjoyable.
Too much of the film feels like an idea that never made it beyond the one-sentence pitch of "stoner/slacker discovers he's actually a trained killer, hilarity ensues!"
Krampus is at its best when the various creatures are doing their thing, but the human counterparts don't fare nearly as well.
May not say anything revelatory, but the realization it imparts is no less valuable for it.

Anguish highlights four people in various degrees of mental and emotional pain, and while the narrative tissue here is a supernatural one the beating heart beneath it all is as real and affecting as they come.
Ava's Possessions isn't a bad film by any stretch, but it's frustrating to watch it plod along while an abundance of promise sits just outside of the frame.
If mid-'80s Chuck Norris' beard emigrated from his face, went to film school, and directed a movie - LONDON HAS FALLEN would be that movie.
It survives mainly on the power of Sarah Bolger's lead performance, but there are enough unsettling beats to make it worth a watch for genre fans.
A twisty little ride through the French countryside where everyone is suspect of playing hide the cheese knife.
A blistering, intimate, heavy metal-tinged horror/thriller worth catching on the biggest, loudest screen possible.
It so badly wants you to be excited for "Justice League" that it forgets to keep you excited about "Batman v Superman."
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a game of cat and mouse, but while it proceeds as expected in the grand scheme - killer stalking a victim who tries to stay a step ahead - the thrills are in the details.
Moves between truly frightening beats, laugh out loud dialogue, and some painful observations, and in doing so it stands well apart from its typical haunted house brethren.
It makes some progress, but it unsurprisingly stalls where so many found footage films have failed before.
Good looks can't save the girls in the photographs or THE GIRL IN THE PHOTOGRAPHS.
It introduces us to a boy we're told is meant for something great, but instead it's greatness that the film leaves behind.
It may not be one of the best video game movies, but it's definitely the most video game movie.
Green Room is a vicious, grisly, suspenseful roller-coaster ride with a razor-sharp safety bar, and you are going to get cut.
Lots of mediocrity here, but two of the shorts -- "Easter" and "Father's Day" -- make it worth the price of admission.
Is it an improvement on Walt Disney's original? Yes, yes it is.
Emma Watson shines even as the film grows dull with contrivances and generic beats.
A neon-lit fever dream where culture and sexuality tease an undefined fluidity as Persian and Russian gangsters fight over L.A.'s drug scene.
Delivers an epic adventure that finds its greatest power by scaling back the superhero antics to reveal the human combatants at their core.
It's faint praise, but X-Men: Apocalypse does what it does well enough. The real issue is what it doesn't do.
In a competition between Shane Black first directorial effort and his third, The Nice Guys finishes second.
Tales of Halloween is good fun, but it's difficult not to wish that more of the stories had aimed for darker, more terrifying and affecting goals.
The Wave has heart, laughs, and a big goddamn wave of destruction, and while we might have wanted more we don't actually need more. Enjoy it for what it is.
It's never a bad thing to be reminded of the value of trying your best, regardless of the outcome, but there's also no harm in hoping the filmmakers do a bit better next time.
A tightly-wound, achingly-suspenseful, terrifically-acted thriller that keeps viewers on unsteady ground until the end credits start to roll.
A visually and emotionally effective descent into darkness.
None of its issues, big or small, prevent it from being the tremendously entertaining return to a galaxy far, far away that we've been waiting so damn long for.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Where STAND BY ME pressed its characters' faces into the stink of mortality, the boys here have yet to even hear the news about a dead body down by the train tracks.
There's nothing wrong w/purely observational dramas or straightforward character pieces, but the drama we're given here is stale and lifeless, and the characters even more so.
You can't see the forest for the jump scares.
Under the Shadow gives us something to fear and something to think about, and that's two more things than most horror films can claim.
A highly competent, suspenseful, and fun thriller that never overstays its welcome. Do it a favor, and open the door.
There's a definite fun factor to Jeruzalem that helps make it just entertaining enough.
Not nearly as dramatic or intimately compelling as Broken Circle Breakdown, but van Groeningen once again displays a sure hand at weaving powerful displays of music and film.
An inventively dizzying concoction of farts and feelings. Seriously.
A sweetly-told, laugh-out-loud adventure that reminds us you're never too young or too old to find someone to love who'll also love you back.
The film doesn't pretend to offer any answers. It's simply holding up the mirror... and then angling it a bit to get a better look at some girl's ass.
Plenty to criticize in regard to the script and agenda, but as an action film it's an exciting, entertaining, and unflinching experience.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Captain Fantastic is in some ways a less angry, more commercial take on The Mosquito Coast as a man fights against the norm to do what he believes to be best for his family.
31 is Zombie's mildly entertaining take on a stale and simple setup. You already know if it's for you.
It feels flat throughout, the bloodletting disappoints, and perhaps most damning of all, it neuters "pancakes."
Feels in some ways like a '90s thriller à la The Hand that Rocks the Cradle or Arlington Road, but it lacks either of those films' thrills.
It trips over itself trying to balance its themes alongside the comedy and romance, but as tumbles go it's a painless one.
Bad enough to make you consider retreating from society and becoming a hermit crab.

Bridgend is a slow-burn of self-induced pain and suffering, and while it's accompanied by haunting visuals it remains an elusive watch as it becomes more and more difficult to connect with anyone or anything.
The most romantic Marvel film since Steve Rogers first wooed Peggy Carter.
Lazy writing, cheap effects, and tired gags pervade the film, and it's almost as if Kevin Smith is making a preemptive strike with its awfulness.
A smartly-crafted, lo-fi apocalypse that packs in substantial substance and care for its budget.

There is violence in The Demolisher, but the focus is more on its lingering effects than on its gratuitous display. Instead, the film's most affecting and powerful moments are those more concerned with the pain that comes in the silences after.
The CGI is beyond ropey (we're talking 1995 computer game levels); the script reads as though it was half-heartedly written during a hangover and every single main character is obnoxious.
This superstar crime thriller emerges as something surprising, fascinating and technically dazzling. Don't expect a Hollywood movie. Expect a Michael Mann movie.

Lacking the polish of the Tarantino frescoes he's striving to emulate, Clarke's multistrander still packs enough infectious gusto, humour and surprising detours to paper its obvious cracks. He's still on the way up, but the future is bright.

First-time feature director Scott Stewart is a former ILM special effects wizard who's been given the keys to the store and it shows. There's little sense of narrative cohesion - or any explanation for the moments of madness.

Romcom? Send-up? Romcom send-up? No one seems to know, least of all director Phil Traill, whose failure to deliver a consistent tone - or, y'know, any laughs - leaves his capable cast hung out to dry.
Richard Kelly returns with a tense, unnerving and jumpy thriller. It loses focus towards the end, but Donnie Darko has just entered The Twilight Zone.
Jetsam's saddled with a score that's as subtle as a pneumatic drill at 6am on a Sunday morning, but there's enough here to ensure Welsford should get noticed.

This flat-footed male weepie musters an insurance ad's worth of clichés about the importance of busting a move in middle age -- and it strains so hard to do so that it's almost perversely compelling.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: L'Enfant nudges both its protagonist and its audience toward unlikely affection.
By my count, The Aviator is the fourth Martin Scorsese picture in a decade that ends with its protagonist being forced to observe what he loves most from a tragic distance.

As in Walking and Talking, her comic lament on the evils that brides do to their maids of honor, [Nicole] Holofcener strikes a careful balance between distaff divertissement and stark, semiautobiographical realism.

Rollerball is rigged to play as a critique of the corporate media's ruthlessly sensational tactics (overseas, that is), but even a junior-high hockey goalie could recognize it as a cheesy product of such sensationalism itself.
Fat City
Nina Davenport's unapologetically cunning doc exceeds the sum of its parts to become almost unmanageably allegorical and even an indictment of its own shock-and-awe premise.
Bold attempt to present 'God as the ultimate headache' and Jesus (Willem Dafoe) 'as a metaphor for the human condition' (per Dutch Calvinist screenwriter Paul Schrader).
It's Giuliani time.
This keenly observed and darkly comic indie is named for a quartet of office temps who toil at Global Credit while receiving no credit of their own.
As cinema, it isn't much, but as a story, it's enough to set the Town Hall buzzing.

The Yards appears greater than the sum of its old sources, in part because its hero wouldn't know a cliché if it pressed two Knicks tickets in his hand and told him there's more where those came from.

This 'collector's edition' will probably go down in film history as the definitive one unless, like me, you think the movie works best in its original version, wherein the special effects of adult delinquency are left unknown.
movie_title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)

movie_review_blurb: There's something of The Big Sleep in director Curtis Hanson's unfashionably pre-postmodern tour de force of early-'50s atmosphere, tight plotting, snappy dialogue, and sharply edited action--you know, all those quaint virtues from the old noirs.

Even more than the postwar European cineastes who'd slyly titillate ticket buyers in trade for the privilege of being almost inscrutably profound, the hermitic Kubrick lived to make intellectual sport of audience expectations.
Magnolia withers under the weight of its ambition.
Who wants to be a millionaire?
Kevin Smith and Jesus Christ--coming soon to a theater near you?

The director's moody visual style befits his complex look at a character not unlike Orson Welles' Charles Foster Kane--a misanthrope who, despite his wealth of toys, has doomed himself to living arrogantly impoverished and alone.
Spike Lee's Bamboozled would be a daring movie no matter the year, but its timing at the tail end of 2000 is impeccable.
Both Jackie and Grier manage to stay tough and independent throughout, which seems a credit to both the actress and her director.
This indelibly vivid, Brooklyn-set sex-melodrama posits Latino culture against the Anglo-American "show business" milieu that appropriates and stereotypes it.
No less than Madonna's Truth or Dare, Wild Man Blues proves the degree to which stars make a fiction of objectivity.
[Soderbergh] seamlessly turns the megastar Roberts into another of his lone wolves.
We've never had American horror as we did in the decade between Night of the Living Dead and Halloween (1978), no doubt because we've never had American history like that.
Everything about the film feels ornate but funereal, like an airless luxury suite on the last night of an affair.
The [film's] pointedly bipolar tone might have been modeled on the wild mood swings of the Cure's adolescent-apocalypse epic Kiss Me, Kiss Me, Kiss Me from the white-hot summer of '87.

Like its heroine, Ghost World dares to drop its defenses, deepening as it shifts from evoking sympathy for the judgmental misanthrope to saluting the bravery of those who find beauty in others' flaws.
Quizás, baby.

Gibson dwells on the gory details of laceration -- one whipping after another and another and another -- until it's the viewer who's tortured, hurt, defensive, and, finally, numb (if not driven to retaliate).
Almost Famous
[The film] contrives to wag its own finger at itself -- to have its bonbon and eat it too.
Dreamlike in style, Police Beat is also a real-world vision of what American indies could be if they dared to recognize the drama in our own neighborhoods.

This contrived lament for the lonesome cowboy means to measure what remains of the old western in the absence of the Old West, eventually plopping its displaced ranch hand protagonist onto the fake Main Street of an old western movie set.
"M:i:III" is too oppressive, too enamored of its brutality to deliver anything like real thrills.
As a movie, 3 Needles amounts to unclean entertainment at best.
A disarmingly droll and insightful indie.
Rocky Balboa, effortlessly reflexive and patently, even proudly, absurd, is a tough movie to dislike -- and believe me, I've tried.
The film's seemingly endless revelations of double- and triple-crosses would play like bad mid-'60s Hollywood epic wanking were it not for Zhang's mise-en-scéne.
Even by the low standards of the young-jocks-as-good-clean-soldiers movie, there's little at stake here, unless you count the kids' hunger to win one for the Gipper.
Asses were indeed kicked here--flayed, even.

Director Nick Cassavetes has a blast with scenes of testosterone-fueled aggression (until it's time to repent), working the subwoofer in a way that'll surely boost DVD sales among boys with bedroom posters of Tony Montana.
It's only a slight exaggeration to say that God Grew Tired of Us, winner of two documentary prizes at last year's Sundance, is another Hollywood gloss on human tragedy.

Our eager-beaver heroine suffers the kids' sarcasm, fails to earn their respect by bringing in a Tupac tape, then wins them over in a crucial scene that, fact-based or not, rings as false as anything in Dangerous Minds.
It's an astonishingly crass and vulgar film, crudely directed on a cut-rate budget by Brian Robbins, never more than almost funny or less than disturbing.
Pretentiously impressionistic, sloppy almost to the point of self-parody, [director Julien] Temple's film is New Journalism without the journalism -- or, alas, the drugs.
Visually ravishing and emotionally cold, Zhang's third feature is one long series of pushes and pulls.
movie_title: Raise the Red Lantern (Da hong deng long gao gao gua) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: For God's sake, don't be boring. Alas, after his camera has had its fill of ogling Rae, Brewer turns out to have nothing up his sleeve, nothing in his pants, only a little on his mind and none of it, amazingly, to do with race.
Exterminating Angels is one audaciously, endearingly ludicrous movie.
[It] really, really should've been funnier.
movie_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Mimzy, whose charmingly retro FX date to around 1985, won't post Peter Jackson figures at the box office, but you can't say that Shaye doesn't have the magic touch.
Nary a dull lick in the entire 80 minutes.

For a filmmaker who's so attracted to psychological discomfort, Bier has a disarming affinity with the pleasure principle. In this she's further blessed to have cast the riveting Mikkelsen, who here displays the self-conscious jitter of the young Pacino.
Neither is it funny -- or poignant or insightful or remotely worth one's time except as a reminder that Canadian indies can be every bit as feeble as American ones.
This latest entry in the doggy-acrobat subgenre of canine comedies has but one joke, and it comes early: In the Idol age, celebrity culture has gone to the dogs -- literally.
Shannon's richly minimal performance-a series of reactions, most ranging from deadpan to perturbed -- derives pathos from the familiarly elemental: happy, sad, bitter.

Further propelled by a suitably frantic Soviet orchestral score, the insane rush of scratched, jumpy images compels you to keep your eyes as wide as possible for the entire six minutes -- even though you couldn't dream of absorbing it all.

Bug is genuinely freaky-deaky, not to mention more inventively unsettling than anything [director] Friedkin has mustered in the quarter-century since twisting little Linda Blair into a satanic spewer of pea soup and F-bombs.
Could [director Satoshi] Kon's fanciful cure for the blockbuster blues have come along at a better time?
That there's enough 'plot' in this bona fide melodrama to fill a dozen docs is conducive to the movie's near-total evasion of outside perspective.
The fun is somewhat capped by absurdly stilted acting and daytime-soap-quality DV.
You don't have to be an '80s kid to see The King of Kong as a metaphor for life itself.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Indie-film exec Jeff Lipsky's sophomore feature as writer-director shares with his distribution work a desire to restore some of the untidier virtues of '70s American film.

Twelve-year-olds might get a charge out of this purportedly daring documentary celebration of the F-word, although it never occurs to filmmaker Steve Anderson that it might be fun or even genuinely lewd to interview kids on the subject.
That the film is semi- autobiographical for caustic actor-turned-writer-director Richard E. Grant helps explain its severely, sometimes laughably bitter tone.
[An] enjoyably breezy portrait.
... the film makes for compelling psychobiography despite the fact that Gore, stiff as an air-conditioned breeze at the Four Seasons, isn't the least bit compelling himself.
Keillor's modest subservience to Altman's group dynamic feels downright gallant, and in the context of the veteran director's most humanistic movie by a wide margin, it certainly has its rewards.
This genial doc sprinkles Reagan and Nixon soundbites over its vintage stash of C&C clips for a suitably fuzzy squint at America from '69 to the buzzkill present.
Among the great docs about moviemaking.
What a breath of fresh air this stifling, claustrophobic, boldly uningratiating vision of an American subculture's last gasp imparts to its contrarian core audience.
Escapism in Melville's cinema inevitably gives way to existentialism; pure entertainment becomes unattainable.

As a brutal metaphor for the global economy, 13 Tzameti takes care of business; its assertion that desperate means require desperate measures naturally extends to the hair-trigger world of genre filmmaking.

As directed in aptly unfussy fashion by music- video vet Matt Mahurin, the movie itself is a curiously tasty dish, one that could leave even a vegan with a burning desire to sample Shopsin's lamb chops.

Not since John Sayles and Joe Dante unleashed Piranha and The Howling on Hollywood's New Morning have two features torn open the horror movie with the cut-rate ferocity and gleeful disreputability of [Neil] Marshall's Dog Soldiers and The Descent.
Half Nelson drags the crowd-pleasing white-teacher-inspires-black-students movie onto the mat and pins the flabby genre in the first round.
Stone's message--shrewder than other liberal campaigns of the last five years--is undeniably political.
Andrucha Waddington's admirably pretentious epic of woman in nature makes the rare attempt to impart a purely visual experience.
The movie rarely if ever crosses the border between familiarity and surprise.
The film is most compelling for its suggestion of how politics and showbiz are at once incestuously entwined and, perhaps, irreconcilably different.
The doc these kids would make with flea market camcorders couldn't possibly be as ugly as this absurdly hypocritical critique of the far right's role in escalating the culture war.

Rachman's montage is a frenzied, propulsive pull from here and there -- including not just an astonishing array of milky VHS concert footage (Black Flag in 1981!), but both Ronald Reagan inaugurations, the second of which seems to foretell the end.
Blessed enough to have drawn Gautier and Downey away from better-paying gigs, the kid hasn't likely failed to recognize his saints.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: No mere Western-guilt-inducing harangue, this highly informative documentary by British brothers Marc and Nick Francis is a model of patient storytelling.

Directing with a light comic touch and a palpable affection for the characters, Selim draws pitch-perfect acting from a large cast (John Heard, Ned Beatty, Alan Cumming, Alex Kingston, and Lois Smith) and achieves breathtaking levels of color and clarity.

Tone is everything in a dark-comic farce, and Murphy pulls it off. Like the book, this deadpan celebration of neurosis makes a valiant effort to repress its comedy -- which of course makes it funnier.
No one here gets out alive, as Jim Morrison put it before the End, though in Switzerland one at least has the chance of booking a smoother passage from insufferable pain to whatever comes next.
movie_title: Exit: The Right to Die (Exit: Le Droit de Mourir) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Red, in every conceivable shade, is, not surprisingly, a key color in Volver, a movie about the towering virtues of high heels and the indomitable power of good old 35mm celluloid.

Judd's typically lived-in performance and the authentic Arkansas locations -- cramped bars, dusty roads -- help vaguely distinguish a movie that comes on like a minor-key reprise of Judd's breakthrough Ruby in Paradise.
God or Jack Valenti only knows how this work of pure entertainment got an R rating 'for strong grisly violence and gore, sequences of terror and torture, nudity and language.'
Call it an exercise in threat management, free with the purchase of a photo album--or a movie ticket.
Spike Lee has launched another perfectly timed counteroffensive: a calmly wrenching mix of oral history and period newsreels.
A newly struck print of the [Maysles] brothers' 1976 classic Grey Gardens proves that their work is still plenty provocative--and especially so in this era of shallow celebrity docs.
Paramount's Footloose reboot never quite cuts loose enough to distinguish itself from the original.
The results are so visually stunning, why quibble?
[Mistakes] over-the-top dysfunctional family cruelty for comedy and drama.
Warm-blooded but largely lifeless.
Calculatedly ugly and undeservedly controversial.
Solidly acted but aloof and slow as molasses.
Too often toddles over the fine line between cute and cloying before finding its footing in the final reel.
Straining to be a distaff "Deliverance," indie thriller Black Rock is unable to shock, much less convince.
Genial but gratingly irrelevant and none too witty.
The pic scores big points by drawing a sharp distinction between corporate vidgame programmers and indies.
One of the great movies about movies.
The new Thing, helmed by first-timer Matthijs van Heijningen, nods deferentially to John Carpenter's still-scary cult film while displaying little comprehension of what made it work.
A literary film that stands to work best for those who don't read.
Under African Skies is appreciably smarter than most celebrity musician docus.
Much like the band's self-conscious synth-pop itself, Shut Up is initially satiric but ultimately disarming in its emotional resonance.
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A rarefied conceptual docu that will appeal to a limited but highly appreciative audience.
Give or take the titular disclosure, John Dies at the End is a thoroughly unpredictable horror-comedy -- and an immensely entertaining one, too.
The pic's true star is Martinovic's unblinking camera, which really ought to have been let loose in some other house.
There's no mistaking Jardin's playful mastery of the Hollywood-style action aesthetic; his movie starts in high gear and accelerates steadily from there.

This low-budget shocker eventually pays off, displaying just enough narrative ingenuity to compensate for a cinematically crude and logistically sketchy deployment of the requisite blood-and-guts mayhem.
Only dream logic -- give or take pure cinema -- can begin to explain the wacky beauty of what goes on here.
A highly satisfying Western-cum-noir in the old tradition.
Newcomer Jason Yee proves plenty adept at chopsocky, but his chops are nonexistent on the thesping side.
movie_title: The Girl from the Naked Eye (2012)

movie_review_blurb: First-time writer-director Aurora Guerrero beautifully captures the fluctuating dynamics of friendship between 15-year-old girls in Mosquita y Mari.
An aptly infuriating expose of sexual abuse within the U.S. military.
Spectacularly photographed and journalistically lame...

Sarah Palin -- You Betcha! shovels enough dirt on the Tea Party guru and self-described hockey mom to satisfy her haters, but lacks sufficient humor and insight to make it a must-see for anyone outside the Brit muckraker's fan base.
Even at 73 minutes, the film is, well, too damn long.
Cairo Time proves hard to resist, the film's familiarity gradually giving way to a playfulness that feels new to the impossible-love subset of bourgeois melodrama.
Bloody well done.
Brizé does score a nifty variation on the clichéd rushing-to-meet-destiny climax. But this encounter, brief indeed at a mere 90 minutes, doesn't fully convince.

With its jolting images of flammable tap water and chemically burned pets, New York theater-director-turned-documentarian Josh Fox's Sundance-feted shocker makes an irrefutable case against U.S. corporate "fracking."
The movie becomes oddly deep and even poignant.
The definitive screen investigation of the global economic crisis, providing hard evidence of flagrant amorality -- and of a new nonfiction master at work.
Carlos suggests that the genre-hopping Assayas could maximize his own ambition even within the tight confines of a prison drama.

At least for non-fans, the sole mercy shown by Lionsgate's latest Saw is that it's billed as the last and plays that way, wrapping things up without the threat of making another killing after this one.
Variably articulate subjects drone on and on in an 83-minute film that could easily make its TV news-style point in a half-hour or less.
Arguably the strongest American debut feature of the '90s.
Won't evict "Single White Female" from its top-floor residence among psycho-roomie cinema.
Sharp 3D lensing and low-octane camp humor help rev up Drive Angry.
More compelling as an intellectual exercise than an emotional one.
The true story of one-armed surfer girl Bethany Hamilton keeps its balance in Soul Surfer, a kind-hearted coming-of-age drama with killer waves.
Waiting for Super to deliver the funny is an experience as long as the film itself.
A possession thriller less terrifying than fun.
Not as fun as it sounds, Bonnie & Clyde vs. Dracula shoots blanks before sucking the life out of its premise.
Hypnotic slo-mo images of honeybees flapping their wings are about all that distinguishes the docu Vanishing of the Bees from a well-researched article on its subject.
Tastefully provocative, ultimately haunting.
It's strongest as the story of an artist who, in his own way, has only begun to come out.
Marsh's film remains a deeply haunting portrait of the unbridgeable gap between kindred species.
Well-intentioned but derivative and only intermittently engaging, the suburban Michigan-set indie hits at least as many false notes as true ones.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Raul Ruiz's head-spinning Mysteries of Lisbon is a period drama of contemporary import -- and of the highest order.

Writer-director-actor Evan Glodell's testosterone-fueled fever-dream indie Bellflower impresses less for its screeching take on extended adolescent fury than for its own macho, wacko, pedal-to-metal embodiment of same.
Late-reel scenes of suspense involving the heinously victimized Ukrainians fall somewhere along the line between shocking reportage and standard-issue torture porn.
[Displays] an invigoratingly acute understanding of the psychology of insecurity, longing, defensiveness and inward-turning rage.
First-time writer-director Stephen Chbosky adapts his young-adult bestseller with far more passion than skill, which suits familiar scenes of adolescent awkwardness aptly enough.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Veering between buddy movie and action-thriller, Stand Up Guys is a mildly raunchy, modestly entertaining geriatric comedy.
The ABCs of Death is an appallingly bad concoction of disgusting shorts that run through the alphabet but really should've stopped at "A."
Some genre fans who prefer the silly to the satiric may bite, but the anemic pic isn't remotely weird or witty enough for cult immortality.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This innovative study of Nick Cave playfully disguises itself as fiction while more than fulfilling the requirements of a biographical documentary.
Michael Rossato-Bennett captures some amazingly transformative results in the treatment of dementia through music.
A well-shaped and powerful reminder of a time in recent American history when white supremacy was decisively and courageously undercut.
Hubert Sauper observes the neocolonialist exploitation of South Sudan in this disturbing follow-up to 'Darwin's Nightmare.'

If a dominatrix is one who takes total control of her passive partner, then "R100" is the cinematic equivalent of a kinky femme fatale in black leather and stiletto heels, cracking a whip and a smile.
Willis Earl Beal gives a magnetic performance as a flailing musician in Tim Sutton's digressive, daringly experimental film.
"Killers" has plenty to offer genre fans - provided they don't bolt during its opening scene of a tied-up woman being beaten to death with a mallet ...
Another demanding and deeply rewarding investigation into the Holocaust from documentarian Claude Lanzmann.
An aptly obsessive study of obsession.
The effects of this beautifully unique hybrid of music and cinema are exhilarating and unforgettable.
The movie works as a contemporary look at desperation in crime-riddled Manila, but it's also as deliciously old-fashioned as the late '40s-era film noir "Kiss of Death," and nearly as entertaining.
Zweig's movie is equal parts witty and provocative ...
Its tendency to tell rather than show seems ill-suited to a portrait of the man who brought haute couture to the masses.
Kevin Smith's "Tusk" is an odd animal indeed, a movie that morphs early from stoner comedy to stoner horror flick and then, as if stoned, declines to evolve any further.
Maybe "The Zero Theorem" doesn't add up to much on paper, but, particularly for Gilliam fans, it's infinitely watchable.

The glaring problem with "Galapagos 3D" is that it's a movie about the wonders of evolution that never once mentions natural selection or even Charles Darwin, whose work was largely based on his study of the islands.
Fixating on the fat rolls of underprivileged kids without mentioning class, the film is a more polished version of the greasy tale Morgan Spurlock's Super Size Me told from the inside out.
If a key element of the Obama narrative has been the dream that anyone can thrive in America, Bronx Obama (nee The Audacity of Louis Ortiz) presents the reality as far more complicated.
I'd say this is a movie about alienation that, in the spirit of the boldest activism, isn't afraid to be ostracized itself. You may beg to differ, and I'd say that's the point.
In the end, the effort of sussing out this satire's attitude seems silly for the fact that its jokes just aren't funny enough.
To his credit, Cuesta is interested not only in the darkest side of democracy, but in how Webb's fiery work impacts his personal life.
The result is gently hypnotic.

Alas, its ultra-conventional, this-then-that approach, peppered with the reminiscences of long-since mellowed talking heads, rarely feels suited to the messy politics and personal lives of Black Panther Party firebrands ...
movie_title: The Black Panthers: Vanguard Of The Revolution (2015)

movie_review_blurb: We Live in Public is the rare documentary film whose tapping of the American zeitgeist feels downright supernatural.
"Last Days in Vietnam" combines astonishing footage from April 1975 with the contemporary recollections of some who were there.
Like Cassavetes' A Woman Under the Influence, Ade's film is as unpredictable and ambiguous as it is raw.
James D. Cooper's impeccably directed debut is a definitive screen bio of the Who and its-rock operatic rise.
First-time writer-director Peter Sattler's pic means very well, but strains credibility and ethics alike.
A bona fide high-wire act, Cirque du Soleil: Worlds Away delivers towering thrills through its candy-colored 3D ode to the titular outfit's astounding acrobatics.
A mediocre coming-of-age indie.
Maddening, pretentious, hypnotic and transcendent in roughly equal measure.
Reducing an immensely disturbing, politically byzantine tale to a series of cartoonish vignettes, this celeb-studded biopic squanders a gutsy performance by Amanda Seyfried.
[The] astonishingly hard-hitting "Dirty Wars" renders the investigative work of journalist Jeremy Scahill in the form of a '70s-style conspiracy thriller.
Though the ugly phobia that gave rise to the killing and permeated the legal proceedings boils the blood, the film's tone is somber rather than angry, and its effect is quietly devastating.
"Milkshake" sucks all the flavor out of a tasty premise ...
Writer-director Calvin Lee Reeder's randomly splattering take on the back-country-road movie.
The narratively jumbled film ... features too many scenes that amount to mere stargazing.
Walker pulls off a spectacular feat ... balancing the needs of extreme sports vid and cautionary tale.
Where Walter's film succeeds is in rendering Lutz, onscreen throughout, as an indelibly prickly and unsettling figure.
Less inferno than slow burn, Rob Zombie's retro witch thriller The Lords of Salem has plenty of portent but not much payoff.
A shocker of a remake, equal parts stylish and scuzzy.
Fully immodest and intermittently astonishing.
This bittersweet ode to the moment of childhood's end builds quietly to a pitch-perfect finale.
An impressively oozing slab of indie horror that bodes well for first-time writer-director Chad Crawford Kinkle.
What's great about "Elysium" is that it invites and even encourages discussion and debate while delivering proficiently at the levels of plot, action and special effects.
Connects on emotional levels in the telling of an up-from-nothing brawler whose colorful career climaxed in tragedy.
movie_title: The Good Son: The Life of Ray Boom Boom Mancini (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Cohen's spare but spectacularly visualized film follows a pair of middle-aged strangers who meet in a Viennese art museum and proceed to walk and talk.
Shot as if they were ads for high-thread-count bed sheets, the pic's talky afternoon delights remain more flowery than erotic.
Director Argento half-heartedly mixes schlocky 3D f/x with one-dimensional characters for a near-two-hour joke that ought to have been funnier.
The film does an excellent job of showing how hate-TV was molded in the image of snarling, chain-smoking, guest-berating Downey.
movie_title: Évocateur: The Morton Downey Jr. Movie (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A sneakily subversive exercise in low-budget surrealism and anti-corporate satire.
Overly melodramatic but fairly engrossing ...
With "The Green Prince," an extraordinarily engrossing tale becomes an extremely uncinematic experience in the hands of Israeli documentarian Nadav Schirman.
Four members of Human Rights Watch's Emergency Team risk life and limb in this dynamic and immersive documentary.
Though not as winning as "Raising Victor Vargas," which it resembles, the pic draws its romance tenderly and believably.
A costumer that's well named for being pleasant and conventional but little more.
It lingers in the mind, thanks largely to its trio of actors -- especially Alex Karpovsky, who brings a riveting sense of spontaneity to depicting the younger brother's slow-burning rage.
The pinko commie Independence Day, Burton's film orders an invasion of little green men not to reinvigorate our all-American bloodlust, but to make us look like complete and utter boobs.
Princess of Tides
Girls Town Subverts the Patriarchy.
A monster hit in Britain, Trainspotting is defiantly contradictory: an exhilarating portrait of heroin use, a black comedy of errors capped off by one character's sarcastic decision to "choose life."
Independence Day Restores Order to the Millennium.
Signifying Monkeys
Welcome to the Dollhouse puts an ugly duckling through her paces.
Pure sensation, yes, but with a distinct point of view.
Thou Shalt Not Miss
A Short Film About Love, despite its title, has more to do with guilt and remorse and manipulation; it might not be about love at all.

To understand that Scorsese suffers for his art, it isn't important to know that he's been married four times, or that he considered joining the Catholic priesthood before choosing the equally masochistic experience of NYU.
Invoking social realism more than pulp fiction, Carl Franklin's Devil in a Blue Dress is an innovative genre film on several counts.
There's a miraculous transformation in almost every moment of the film.
Shooting in widescreen while conveying a sharp sense of verticality, [director David] Mackenzie gets us dizzy from the wealth of playthings on display, from swimming pool to private parts.
The Passion of the Maher
Note to self: Need more yoga ASAP.
The ultimate lesson of His Girl Friday--that it's tougher to manage a marriage than a newspaper--looks in 2008 like pure nostalgia.
Earnhardt's film is pointedly infuriating, not least when it uses the simplest mathematical equations.
movie_title: Uncounted: The New Math of American Elections (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Six decades before Diablo Cody and Juno, Preston Sturges carried unplanned comedy to term.
Alternately jerking the audience's tears and splashing snow in their faces, 3-D indie Call of the Wild loses focus (literally) but gets by on its good-hearted demeanor.
Lensed in black-and-white, the 77-minute film is plenty arty and only arguably constructive in its tasteful fictionalization of a violent tragedy.
Yet another D.O.A. for the ADD era.
Heavy on stunts but light on plausibility, humor, surprise, visual ingenuity or psychological depth.
Rating less than zero on the sophistication scale, The Informers is thus a totally faithful adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis' novel--and an accurate look at early '80s-era Los Angeles.
Though pregnant with possibility, Motherhood fails to deliver.
Von Trier may put his characters and the viewer through the ringer, yet his empathy toward both is unmistakable.
Like Timoner's DIG!, this astounding new docu burrows into the thin and darkly funny spaces between artistry and vanity, isolation and community, collaboration and exploitation, sanity and madness.

Linklater is collaborating with a certified grown-up who also happens to be the screenwriting equivalent of a shock-jock; laid-back bong-hits have been supplanted by endless black-comic cruelty and a lot of sociocultural pissing and moaning.
With Crash, David Cronenberg drives mainstream cinema over the edge.

This fawning docu goes to lengths to portray the octogenarian Playboy magazine founder as among the greatest figures of 20th-century American popular culture, while only cursorily acknowledging his status as a pioneering softcore pornographer.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The most receptive audience will mainly be enlightened to know that you can make a movie as thoroughly unprofessional as this one and still get it released in 3,000 theaters.

Even after four hours, we're left wanting to know a lot more--and with the sense that this desire may itself be one of those human strategies to cope with the overwhelming power of a most enigmatic and undiscriminating villain.
Another few of these squandered opportunities for art-house muckraking and we'll need someone to ask who killed the left-wing documentary.
The separation of church and cinema amounts to a long yard at most in this high school football sermon from Georgia-based Baptist pastor Alex Kendrick.

Dearly beloved, we are gathered here today to get through this thing called Purple Rain--the Citizen Kane of Minnesota movies and a worldwide showcase for the ascendance of its then-26-year-old star into rock 'n' roll eternity.
Despite countless unique and amazing moments, the movie doesn't quite come together--which may not, in fact, go against the director's master plan.
Repellent not only in content but in visual style, writer-director Rob Zombie's hatchet job on the series he revived so artfully two years ago plays like a violent act of euthanasia.
Steven Spielberg tries to rescue the world's most elusive filmmaker from an unhappy ending.
With American Movie, director Chris Smith finds the heart of cinema in the unlikely environs of Milwaukee.
Produced and abandoned, the made-in-Minnesota wrestling comedy The Naked Man falls into a Hollywood sleeper hold.
Forget Fargo and A Simple Plan: In 1972, The Heartbreak Kid had Minnesota down cold.
Velvet Goldmine gives the rock movie a makeover.
Mark Rappaport is not exactly a documentarian and something more than a filmmaker. You could say he's a movie critic who writes by remote control.
A Catholic-themed indie of occasionally irreverent wit, Into Temptation is appropriately tough to resist.
The story may end in Taiwan on a heartbreaking note, but we're left somewhere between here and there, happily drifting through the film's luscious netherworld of sound and image.
You could say it's two hours of three characters with one-track minds, a distended portrait of overgrown kids playing hide and seek.
Kiarostami's insistence on putting a frame around his vision keeps the freedom of interpretation--and the responsibility for it--in the hands of the viewer.
Pop Culture Rule No. 1: Wait long enough and even the stinkiest trash gets recycled into art.
The running gag is that [this film about advertising] takes its own high-concept formula of a yuppie's just desserts and whips it up with more tang than any consumer could want.
movie_title: How to Get Ahead in Advertising (1989)

movie_review_blurb: The film's gross-out climax has the mad-scientist Baron (Udo Kier) screwing his undead Bride on a gurney, then ravaging Marlon Brando with a spot-on parody of Last Tango.
Desperate for virgin blood, [Udo] Kier's wan, fussy vampire strategically heads to Catholic Italy, but the food sucks ("They put so much oil here on everything!").
Call Ethan one widescreen reminder of fear and guilt for a country that deserved at least one.
What is it about the black suit/black tie/white shirt get-up in movies?
Still the most lavishly offensive of Greenaway's films.
movie_title: The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Ex-Minnesotan Sarah Jacobson loses it confidently with Mary Jane's Not a Virgin Anymore.
movie_title: Mary Jane's Not a Virgin Anymore (1997)

movie_review_blurb: Primo footage of recording sessions, concert perfs and various backstage trips is ubiquitous--and sadly squandered--amid wall-to-wall voiceover narration that is punishingly banal when not factually sketchy or flat-out false.
Writer-director Jake Goldberger's mild riff on Double Indemnity, etc., works best as a showcase for its veteran cast.

Hardly innovative, but effective and handsomely produced, Hansel & Gretel puts the "grim" in Grimm while placing South Korean director Yim Phil-sung on the shortlist of Pan's Labyrinth emulators to trust.
The rare post-Tarantino men-with-guns indie that works on its own terms, this hyperactive B-movie has the title selling points in abundance but also a lot of wit and flair.

Put into extremely limited release by Paramount Vantage after spending years in studio lockdown, Carriers has moments of genuinely communicable horror and thus deserves better than a de facto theatrical quarantine.
Laced with good-natured hipster kitsch and endearingly goofy girl power, director Drew Barrymore's roller-derby dramedy, Whip It, is a gas.
Burma VJ would be even more intense without its early announcement that some scenes have been restaged, putting the viewer in a regrettably uncertain relationship to what follows.
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Lazily derivative.
Seemingly made to capitalize on a dubious CG innovation -- namely, the slicing of bodies in half by whizzing five-pointed stars -- Ninja Assassin has little else to recommend it, not even laughs.
A high-concept/low-impact twist on torture porn, The Killing Room will likely do its slaying on DVD.
A film so frighteningly familiar it could well be called Saw It Already.
An intimate epic, Jonze's film is nearly unique among modern kid fare for its total lack of condescension to the core audience.
Universal's alien-abduction thriller none too cleverly bids to pass off mock-documentary footage of levitating psychological patients--and, scarier still, ordinary talking heads--as the real deal.
Equal parts comic melodrama and film noir, and twice as fun as it ought to be, Broken Embraces boasts more bifurcations than any two Hitchcock classics.
A so-so heist-gone-awry thriller, light on the thrills, Armored doesn't exactly take its audience captive.

The desperately overboard coming-attractions clip suggests something like Speed 0: Bladder Control--so it's a relief that this film's own seamanly "action" finale involves nothing more adventurous than shooting off a flare.
This tale of a sex-crazed teen who invents a nasty alter-ego in a perverse bid to seduce his dream girl has too many unfunny moments to justify more than a rental...
In purely cinematic terms, Buried, set in late 2006, is an ingenious exercise in sustained tension that would make Alfred Hitchcock turn over in his grave.

Sparked by wonderfully lived-in performances from Julianne Moore and Mark Ruffalo, "The Kids Are All Right" is alright, if not up to the level of writer-director Lisa Cholodenko's earlier pair of new bohemian dramas.

Acting more Kubrickian than ever, Scorsese uses the promise of horror to subvert expectations as thoroughly as did The Shining, which offers nothing terribly supernatural besides the twin horrors of parenthood and writer's block.
The film is deficient in form and content-not naturalistic so much as neutered, less revisionist than rote.
A movie whose audacious editing fully captures the hot and heavy relationships between past and present, sex and politics, reality and, yes, cinema.
Cyrus, alas, hasn't yet learned not to act with her eyebrows and overbite. But she does show off her considerable chops as a pianist and remains reasonably likable throughout.
Chan's old-fashioned, highly watchable mega-production comes complete with God's-eye surveys of mass carnage, the moist sounds of sword-skewering, and little or no discernible CGI.
Chan's old-fashioned, highly watchable megaproduction comes complete with God's-eye surveys of mass carnage, the moist sounds of sword-skewering, and little or no discernible CGI.
Slight but winning and often funny, the scrappy Amerindie Wah Do Dem is a fish-out-of-water comedy driven by Sean "Bones" Sullivan's offbeat performance.
Carefully apportions its visual jokes rather than bombarding the viewer with them.
Bullets fly and jokes land with a thud.
Contrived panic abounds, as do expiring camcorder batteries and expletive-laden variations on "Shoot it in the head!"
Doesn't reach far beyond its smallscreen genotype as a disease-of-the-week telepic, despite the star power of Brendan Fraser as the desperate dad and Harrison Ford as an eccentric, ornery researcher.

Bad romantic comedies with sappy characters aren't always without merit, since we cynics can at least use them to further our conviction that love isn't worth the trouble. But this bad romantic comedy is merely bad.
The Canyon could be named for the gaping expanse between its preposterously silly dialogue and sturdy, at times urgent direction.
The humor isn't funny, the horror isn't scary, and the digital wolf f/x look cheap.
Alternately political and apolitical, pessimistic and optimistic--but rarely, if ever, cinematic.
Taylor's stimulating film, enlivened by creative location shooting, will surely find an appreciative audience among highbrow cinephiles.

Profoundly (and some would say pleasurably) formulaic, the film possesses scant cinematic energy, relying wholly on the familiar transformation of a grumpy old man into an infectiously weepy humanist.
Pre-millennium tension is still the best explanation for the recent tidal wave of disaster movies--which hasn't made it any less boring.
However shrewdly contrived to keep its budget low, Pontypool, set almost entirely in a basement radio station, is a zombie flick sans bite.
Genova conveys its strongest themes through insinuation, and modulates its shifting moods through Winterbottom's precisely calibrated DV processing.
The films of French director Claire Denis often chart the flow of energy between two dissimilar people while contemplating their place within the larger community.
A birdwatchers' Best in Show, Alex Karpovsky's mock-doc Woodpecker stretches its single joke to feature length, earning a beakful of yuks.
The 9/11 truth movement might believe it has found its JFK here, despite the cold, hard fact that the pic is criminally pedantic when not dramatically absurd.

Spanning the pair's half-century-long friendship and individual work on strikingly shot films of the past four decades, pic deftly combines personal, political and cinematic histories through anecdote-laden interviews and eye-popping clips.
Director Ursula Meier generally distinguishes her feature debut by not pushing elements to melodramatic or farcical extremes.
Literally playing an action figure, bulky Butler doesn't deliver a performance so much as a workout routine; the best that can be said for him here is that he shows endurance.
The film makes attractive use of vivid period detail, but its episodic narrative never takes hold.
movie_title: Mommy Is at the Hairdresser's (Maman est Chez le Coiffeur) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film's real pleasure isn't its humor so much as its overall excess, the tone it projects of several major chords being struck at once.
Houston's inevitable chart-toppers aside, the film mainly sells the values of cooperation and good-samaritanism.
Only one element remains clearly traceable to Hong Kong cinema: The titular warriors are badly dubbed.
In & Out is the screwball Philadelphia, a movie that contorts itself in order to indulge and then whitewash the core audience's perceived homophobia.
All apologies to the handful of Americans who've waited decades for this big-screen update of the '60s sitcom--the result is both awful and awfully irrelevant.
Of course, the elephant Vera keeps sticking her trunk in where it isn't wanted, literally consuming tons of candy and stepping on Murray's cellular phone. Ha ha.
Atkinson's reactive brand of bug-eyed and near-silent comedy has always been more akin to Jacques Tati--plus a lecherous pinch of Jerry Lewis, the better to invade the viewer's personal space.
Still more millennial fear and commuter angst get routed through this toll-heavy disaster vehicle set in New York's Holland Tunnel--call it The Tunneling Inferno.
Privilege and coincidence have always been central to screwball comedy, but the speed of crosstown travel here rivals Die Hard 3 for plausibility.
When the jokes aren't sexual or xenophobic, the movie's sense of humor is merely strained.
God forbid Arnold should have to shell out for one of those Spanish-speaking turbomen being hocked in the bad part of town.
The good liberal Michael Apted seems to think he's directing a film about society's exploitation of the homeless. In fact, the exploitation is all his.

Writer/director Steve Purcell brings these new toys to life with small details that ring true to life, from the herky-jerky movement of a dinosaur playset's elevator to a brief, TV commercial-length theme song for these battling dinos.

Killing Kennedy deserves some credit for attempting to retell the JFK assassination in a slightly different way but it doesn't go far enough in getting at the underpinnings of Oswald's character and motivation.
One can't help but wish all this meta commentary had been grafted onto a better story and a better movie that didn't feel like such a cheap rush job.

The Normal Heart...offers a stinging political indictment of the shameful attitudes toward gay men's health in the 1980s and a touching evocation of the human losses suffered due to HIV-AIDS. And the film boasts winning, Emmy-bait performances all around.
The film is eerie and thought-provoking, raising worthwhile questions about the pursuit of justice without losing compassion for the victims or their families.
Even for those who don't watch Doctor Who regularly, it's a terrifically entertaining period piece with a lot of heart and appreciation for TV history.
movie_title: An Adventure in Space and Time (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The Challenge Disaster suffers somewhat from its attempts to create added dramatic intrigue... The film never offers proof either way, and it's an unnecessary embellishment that too strictly conforms to conspiracy archetypes.
Shorts like Toy Story OF TERROR! give fans an opportunity to revisit the entertaining Toy Story universe and spend more time with these beloved characters.

But if viewers put politics aside, imagining everyone on screen as a character rather than a stand-in for a real-life figure, they will find Game Change offers enough Shakespearean machinations to warrant praise as an exceptional melodrama.
Mockingbird Lane is funny, fanciful, a visual treat and, perhaps surprisingly, full of heart.
A more entertaining, clever musical than its generic title suggests.
Sharknado turned out to be the perfect blend of cheesy pop culture elements, including title, stars and the ever-popular shark-as-adversary theme.
Terrific performances make it a movie worth seeing.
Fans of legal dramas should be intrigued by Phil Spector, a well-paced 90-minute character-driven film
Top of the Lake makes for a compelling mix of moody, character-driven drama.
It's not clear why this story warranted a movie. It's a small character study about a large man who comes off as a terrorizing buffoon.
it's a clever, funny hour that's written in rhyme with imaginative songs threaded throughout.
[One} thing to note about Ghost Shark is how gleefully it embraces every bad horror movie stereotype.
It's too much of a rehash of the original, superior Elf and the songs by Matthew Sklar and Chad Beguelin while fine, won't stick with viewers for a minute after the program concludes.
It all feels a bit unfair to the real-life counterparts. And then King Charles III makes a fascinating pivot.
The story is so intent on covering the title character's life almost in its entirety that character motivations suffer.

It would have been easy for Mr. Linklater to make this an anti-war film or a pro-military production. There are moments when both are discussed with a kick-to-the-gut frankness, but the big-ticket political items always give way to the very human aspects.

Train inaccuracies aside, The Christmas Train is pleasant enough pabulum for viewers who seek comfort viewing. Fans of more complicated, well written TV can let this train pass them by and turn their attention to... Marvelous Mrs. Maisel.

Ms. Winfrey's Deborah can jump from settled to agitated and filled with perseverating thoughts in the blink of an eye. It's a role that could fall into caricature, but Ms. Winfrey brings vulnerability and believability to the part.
movie_title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Tickled runs a bit too long (at 90 minutes) and proves slightly unsatisfying in its denouement. The new, 20-minute tack-on, The Tickle King, helps somewhat and offers new, necessary details.
The Power of Words, a one-hour film, portrays Mr. Obama's oratory prowess in glowing terms, but it doesn't get into policy and mostly avoids politics.
movie_title: The Obama Years: The Power of Words (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderfully entertaining program, Bright Lights shows just how close the mother and daughter had become in recent years... that vaguely brings to mind Grey Gardens without the fallen-from-grace squalor.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: What plot there is goes sideways in the last half-hour, just as in the movie. At that point, I just wanted it to be over.
movie_title: The Rocky Horror Picture Show: Let's Do the Time Warp Again (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This sweet story that has been put to film shows the passion Cartwright found for the 1954 Fellini film "La Strada" that started a three-decade journey that resulted in the story of what it means to be deeply passionate about something.
Killing Reagan is pretty much the expected, rote bio movie of the assassination attempt on President Reagan by John Hinckley Jr.

An interesting reminder of an earlier political debacle, Confirmation likely will confirm whatever biases a viewer brings to it: Hill was railroaded; the filmmakers are in the tank for Hill (those two positions are not mutually exclusive).

Written by Murray, Mitch Glazer (Scrooged) and the special's director, Sofia Coppola, A Very Murray Christmas is an odd holiday entry but one that surely has a small but loyal audience that will find its hipper-than-thou vibe entertaining.
"I'm probably missing some great Internet snark right now," [Annie] whines. "#boring." Alas, the same hashtag can be applied to Turkey Hollow at times.
It's not a critical look at Ms. Moore's career. This show is a celebration, just like the title says, and one her fans are sure to appreciate.
No one will confuse these behind-the-scenes movies with good TV but there's some high-calorie entertainment value to be had in this low-rent pastiche of TV nostalgia.

Halfway through - right about the time a character loses his limbs one by one while trying to take heroic action - the mojo that makes these absurd movies a hoot kicks in and Sharknado 3 becomes the insane event viewers anticipate.

[It] is often quite funny, particularly in its sillier moments, including a drunk Queen Elizabeth calling Poole to demand a win, Williams' reactions to streakers on the tennis court and a digital reenactment of a Swedish prison orgy.
With Sharknado: The 4th Awakens, this B movie series most definitely - wait for it - jumps the shark.
There is an immediacy to hearing former church members' stories from them.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Full of striking moments that stick in the subconscious, you'll be hard pushed to find a more affecting cinematic experience than this.
An adrenaline-fuelled thrill burst that does Tharg's finest justice, stays true to its roots and leaves you battered, bruised and hungry for more.
An incredibly engaging story, told impeccably, with a moral backbone for good measure.
An ambitious yet flawed effort, but one executed with undoubted style and verve.
While it doesn't reach the heady heights of Iron Man, it's a worthy addition to DC's movie universe.

Anton Corbijn's new thriller is perhaps the best so far to tackle the war on terror, thanks to an ingeniously twisty and deeply cynical storyline, plus a towering performance from Philip Seymour Hoffman.
