The characters are brought to vivid life with remarkably compelling performances by two of the screen's most versatile actors: Don Cheadle as the freewheeling Greene; and Chiwetel Ejiofor as Hughes, the aggressively ambitious executive.
Evening's visual period splendour, its vivid characterizations and their comfortably clichéd relationships somehow draw us in and make us care.
Live Free or Die Hard is indeed a worthy successor to the original -- not perhaps quite as good, but close.
Even as haunted hotel King movies go, 1408 is certainly no Shining. Not even the TV-movie version.
I've got to be honest here. In the interest of full disclosure, I must confess that I was not entirely awake all the way through.
Like Shaun of the Dead, the movie enthusiastically embraces all the grotesque clichés we love and have come to expect from the form -- turning several on their ear.
Surf's Up is quite surprisingly good, going for the subtle chuckle where Happy Feet opted for show-stopping spectacle.
All-the-way-through good, from explosive start to bloody finish, without so much as a momentary lag in the action or the story.
Each vignette is wittily worded by neophyte TV writer Aschlin Ditta, and subtly performed by a large ensemble cast that contains a few fairly recognizable surprises.
A faithful and funny, entirely scripted, feature-length film version of the videotaped and improvised mockumentary series.

What the characters and satirical situations may lack this time out in a certain fresh vitality, they more than compensate for with a warm, laid-back familiarity ... and the occasional, out-of-left-fjord surprise.
Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer is a vast and significant improvement -- if not quite "fantastic," then the next best thing: It does not suck.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's big lug of a lead, Dan Fogler...could be dismissed as a poor man's Jack Black.
Relentlessly dense and unfathomable; Depp, the heart and soul of the series, doesn't even show up till several reels in.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe somebody decided the movie was already so convoluted and leaden that throwing in a few swooping, screeching valkyries could only help. They do not.
Did these people - or even these people's people - not bother to read the script first?
The movie itself stands up well, even from an adult, two-dimensional perspective.

Through it all there always shone this subtle, gleeful naughty schoolboy charm, not quite a full-on wink at the audience, but a tacit acknowledgement that sometimes even total jerks can exhibit an endearing charm.
What gets you is the smile, which first lights up his face, and then the room, reflected by everyone else who is in it.
The animation is great, in its stark, mostly monochromatic way, but the music merely serviceable.
movie_title: Le magasin des suicides (The Suicide Shop) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: We can't all be Quentin Tarantino, but that doesn't stop some people from trying.
A charming and even inspirational doc that follows eight medal-winning veterans of the sport on their way to and through the 15th annual World over-80s Table Tennis Championship.
Another one of those flicks where anything worth laughing at is contained in the commercials.

It now requires nothing less than the retroactive destruction of Shrekâ(TM)s idyllic family life to inject some necessary conflict back into the franchise. If you canâ(TM)t fix something that isnâ(TM)t broke, your only recourse is to break it.
How could such a great idea go so horribly, horribly wrong?
The film's odd conceit is its primary strength, with Van Damme in a nakedly honest, bravely candid turn that for the first time in his career can be commended as 'acting'.
Ecstasy is to ecstasy what Trainspotting was to heroin. Different times, different drugs, but the Scotland-set story of addiction and redemption is pretty much the same.
This story of unrequited love doesn't sustain interest beyond the first half-hour.

The Oscars have a long history of self-congratulation...This Oscar ceremony brought home the fact that the changes have been a long time coming. It was also a potent reminder that they have a long, long way to go.
A charming, evocative look back at events surrounding Neil Armstrong's stroll on the moon 32 years ago.
The images are never ostentatious; instead, they evoke both the terror and wonder of things that lie beyond the grasp of human understanding.
Vincent Guastini's makeup effects are the star here, a refreshing change from the inky CGI morphing of too much modern horror.
A film in which every character states her motivation out loud, and even so-called "shocking" revelations are underlined with a hand-holding voice-over.
Has some frantic action scenes, but never quite enough spring in its step.
Director Mitchell Altieri helms the thriller with a sure hand ...
Eventually, all of the mundane squabbling is topped by a ridiculous climax full of jumbled, indecipherable action and bargain-basement CGI.
Logic is a torch we can use to fight our fears. If it flickers only dimly here, perhaps that's by design.
Unfortunately, Dinosaur 13 never manages to display the story's many complex parts in a way that enables viewers to grasp the whole beast ...
This muted approach robs the film of sorely needed momentum, but offers a rare opportunity for contemplation, a trade-off that only occasionally satisfies.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It's a testament to director David Jung's smart script and Shane Johnson's performance that Michael King's decisions seem largely free of horror-movie logic - the stubborn refusal to acknowledge danger, an insistence on going it alone.
There's no denying this mixed bag contains some really choice severed heads.
Is it possible to be decidedly unsubtle and also maddeningly opaque? Marc Carreté's exorcism film Asmodexia threads that infuriating needle.
What's most interesting about Inner Demons is its third ingredient: a film crew that stirs up trouble with an intervention-themed reality show.
Catch Hell suffers from both a drowsy start and a dragging ending.
After a high-speed recap, Dead Snow 2 broadens the canvas almost immediately.
movie_title: Dead Snow 2: Red vs. Dead (Død snø 2) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The implicit criticism of psychiatry without compassion makes this confection unusually filling. Vincent Price never had it so good.
While the portentous glances and oblique dialogue of the undead evoke stylish '70s Euro-vampires - as do the trippy cuts and fade-outs - Oliver's manhunt feels more like a low-budget '80s potboiler.
Carballo squeezes an impressive amount of exposition into news reports and medical briefings, but Holden-Ried's and Hampshire's performances are what ground the film ...
If you're in the bag for werewolves (or have a thing for hairy dudes smoking distinctive pipes), Wolves is a beckoning howl in the night. As an action movie, however, it's surprisingly tame.
Paul Solet's direction relies on disorienting tight shots as Daniel creeps through the halls, followed by never-quite-frightening appearances by Mona in her bloody hoodie.
There's enough diamond lore here to please baseball diehards, but Ellis's outsize life will grip even casual fans.
The film is most successful when humanizing the people behind the objectification, with lives beyond the smut.
A film that's less a kung-fu movie and more a meditation on kung fu's limitations.
Horror movies punish the sexually irresponsible; the Spanish-language film Here Comes the Devil manages to indict a married couple with that slasher-movie charge.
Australian filmmakers Kiah and Tristan Roache-Turner remind us why we love these bloody movies in the first place, evincing Raimi-esque glee at twisting the rules of zombiehood like so much taffy.
The second most compelling performance is delivered by a polka-dotted bathrobe ...
The mysticism chokes a bit on its own tail, but is tempered by the underlying human drama.
Moments in The Second Meeting command attention-largely interviews about the combat-but where the present is concerned, the film is more greeting card than documentary, meandering into a cheery haze.
Admirably, the film gives skeptics their say, however briefly. Yet in the face of the authenticity of Shmuel's faith, the evidence for or against the Judaic heritage of the Igbo is beside the point.
The dialogue is all surface: Emotions are laid out on the autopsy table for the audience to dissect and analyze, but rarely feel.
If the thrills it yields are expected ones, the pleasure in the formula remains.
If you don't like sequels where the title's Roman numerals are rendered in jagged slashes of blood, this isn't for you.

Playing like a Down Under Elmore Leonard novel, 100 Bloody Acres features lucky breaks and quick reverses; a persistent soundtrack of Aussie oldies helps keep the mood cheery, despite a literal vatful of blood.
If the film lacks momentum, it's still an hour or so spent among people who obviously love one another. In such company, who would quibble with the cook?
Designed by Raaphorst and brought to life by Rogier Samuels's effects studio, Unreal, the half-glimpsed creatures are magnificent and repellent.
Weightless as a bag of crisps, this matinee fare offers more laughs than scares.
The howl of the desert wind and the unflagging hammer of the sun are the backdrop for every bad decision, lending them a plausibility they wouldn't have in comfort.
The Frozen Ground hits the familiar notes.

Director Dennis Iliadis doesn't overdwell on the existentialism of the concept; he lets emotional beats strobe against the WTF experience of the temporal doubles, peppering the action with distinct images and events to make the repetition stand out.
Thanks to the shakiest of shaky-cams, you don't know whether to wince or lose your lunch.
When a family is as generic as the Bramfords, you get a little antsy waiting for them to be killed off one by one.
Using hate crimes-even cartoonified ones-as a source of humor is troubling ...
movie_title: Zombadings 1: Patayin sa shokot si Remington (Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's no payoff to the paranoia.
Some clever ideas -- the new Cretins harmonize, setting their atrocities to barbershop quartet numbers -- don't negate the tired, exploitative nature of most of the action.
Ghoul rewards attention for much of its running time with subtle scares and growing unease, before squandering it in a shaky chase through twisted corridors that goes nowhere unexpected.
The Sacrament infuses the past with ghoulish immediacy.
It's taxing to watch, and Green moves between scenes with Malick-inspired ellipses, frustrating momentum.
In our zombie-glutted media landscape, this is familiar territory; we know what's coming, pretty much beat for beat.
There's no explicit attempt to put forth a Grand Unifying Theory of Zappa; Schütte immerses us in the competing aspects of Zappa's public persona for their own sake. The results are fascinating.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even [its] looming threat can't enliven the plotless lollygagging in the foreground.
Much of Carnage Park is merely a sun-bleached desert creepshow, a murky soup of a murderer toying with his victims simply because he's cra-a-azy.
Where most post-Shrek animated films are manic and all too eager to please, Rémi Chayé's deliberately paced Long Way North tells its story with clarity and an urgent calm.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Profe does an admirable job walking us through the day's events, weaving together the accounts of people on the scene.
The performances are compelling all around, but Kagawa stands out: His Nishino, somehow as cowardly as he is sinister, recalls the oily nervousness of Peter Lorre.
A lot can go wrong in a movie centered on a supernatural strip club. So why is Siren so damn entertaining?
Filmgoers who brave We Are the Flesh may regret seeing it. Forgetting it is another matter entirely.
movie_title: We Are the Flesh (Tenemos la carne) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This watered-down throwback to The Wicker Man never really heats up.
Mysteries of the characters' pasts are revealed, but Dushku and Crawford are so bland that their secrets barely registered to begin with.
The whole affair plods along in by-the-numbers fashion, and the characters are all types, displaying little evidence of interior lives.
Like a dog turd lurking in the middle of a jelly doughnut, a needless, brutal rape scene poisons the whole experience.
It's sometimes tough to follow the action, but for a short while it's breathless fun, as escaping one monster leads the group to the next.
The characters deal with guilt, disability, and trauma, culminating in an intense final confrontation...and an underlying whiff of a Very Special Episode.
Realive's greatest strength is that it takes its premise so seriously, engaging with its moral and spiritual questions.
What begins as revolting and off the rails peters out into a weak-sauce final payoff presented as an intervention-themed reality show, so tired and quaintly stupid it no longer offends.
Ahearne deftly builds the suspense, raising the stakes before steering the story into surprising new directions.
... the interaction of the film's many tensions nonetheless brings it to complex life.
The amped-up acting is oversaturated in self-aware irony, and the few laughs wrung from the characters' train wreck of a band aren't worth the time spent listening to it.
Proksch tilts his wretchedness into menace, and Mell stages a climax that's thrilling and ridiculous in equal measure.

Writer-directors Micah Wright and Jay Lender are kids'-cartoon vets and show a facility for comedy on a more human level here - as does the nimble cast, which ably handles the tonal shift from travel nightmare to actual nightmare.
Director Jordan Rubin and the cast know the material is ridiculous, but calibrate the tone so that the dangers still feels dangerous.
Jordan Galland's Ava's Possessions begins where most demonic-possession movies end.
Slipshod in every way, The Final Project can't even be bothered to show the important stuff ...
Conversations meander and fizzle; characters repeat themselves, speaking in banalities and clichés.
Early scenes overplay the shock of these phantasms, but just as you expect Geoghegan to crank up the effects, the film mixes in some subtler scares.
For viewers who don't need to suck down every last drop of vampire lore, The Stranger never gets the blood pumping.
The drama plays out as expected - the ending, particularly, seems too pat - but offers several well-executed moments of tension along the way.
At no point does this film strive to be more than a second-rate version of what it is: a halfhearted attempt to make some scratch while pretending the devil exists. Some trick.
A fun, dark movie made by the stars and staff of a kids show.
...the film sinks its teeth into toxic elements of office culture, such as the trampling of individuality...or simply how no one ever bothers to learn the janitor's name.
The film's palette is relentlessly beige, and Bosworth and Bentley echo that, speaking in elliptical hushes.
The plot is as scant and demeaning as the costumes...

Russell Crowe proves to be a proficient director in need of better material with The Water Diviner, an adaptation of Andrew Anastasios and Dr. Meaghan Wilson-Anastasios's inspired-by-true-events novel.
The anthology is a mixed stocking; if you reach inside, something's likely to grab you.
Confident and giddily brutal.
Ultimately, these feral dogs pose no danger that couldn't be solved by staying inside, boarding the windows and barricading the doors. It's not a bad approach to the film itself.
Like the house, the movie is something of a shifting puzzle box; if only the backstory that turns its gears weren't so rotten.
He Never Died is a Tootsie Pop of a movie. It has the outer shell of Taken ... but there's an altogether different treat in the center.

As impressive as the Old City locations can be, one narrow alleyway looks much like another when the Paz brothers' camera is bouncing to and fro. Not much substance is buried beneath the irritating style.
As a suspense film, Dementia is solid but unremarkable, even considering its ugly snarl of an ending. But hidden underneath, the film has all the elements for a compelling, sharp-edged family drama.
Brutality is the only thing director R.D. Braunstein cares to show with any specificity; everything else is so vague as to seem imaginary. J
movie_title: I Spit on Your Grave: Vengeance Is Mine (2015)

movie_review_blurb: First-time director Subkoff shoots even the mundane sniping in horror mode, and makes the hallucinations pay vivid dividends:
"I Served the King of England" is like an endless feast, featuring one spectacular course after another. Somehow, you never get so full that you want to push yourself away from the table.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Once your main character walks into a room and finds her boyfriend cheating on her with another woman while a chimpanzee in a dress looks on, you've pretty much lost your shot at a serious movie.
It's not "The Sure Thing" -- it's not even "Never Been Thawed" -- but it's probably about as well made as a movie called "Sex Drive" has any right to be.
I already get ESPN Classic at home, and I don't need it recreated for me at the theater, thanks.
Yeah, we really don't have enough to worry about these days. So why not grab a Pellegrino and see "Flow," Irena Salina's documentary about the end of the world's water supply as we know it?
A cinematic smear job against Atwater would be the easiest thing in the world, but Forbes is more interested in presenting a complex character study than a piece of liberal agitprop.
movie_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If there's one thing a comedy needs, it's a good exit strategy.
Here, he's actually got a story and some characters to work with, and can add offbeat, even subversive humor to a sturdy plot structure.
"Let the Right One In" is a much scarier vampire movie than the megahit "Twilight," but that's no great shakes. Would you believe, though, that it's also a much better love story?

The world may not have needed another inside-baseball Hollywood satire, but "What Just Happened?" rings true, capturing that quietly frantic feeling that a lot of veteran Hollywood players like Levinson and Linson must feel now and then, wondering if toda
A Girl Cut in Two" is fatally self-serious and plodding, a rare misfire from a filmmaker as usually reliable about this stuff as Chabrol.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: "Milk" is expertly made, rich with humor and poignancy, using a mix of recreated scenes shot in San Francisco and archival footage to give a convincing, panoramic portrait of the city, an era, and the man who changed both.
"Button" ends up being an eloquent and moving tale that keeps all its lighter and darker elements in near-perfect balance.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Once the main character visits Auschwitz and hears of Nazi atrocities, it throws off the balance of the film and makes everything else seem trivial.
There was a point about midway through "The Last Mistress" when I was honestly wondering if it was intentionally bad.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It might have been easier to simply try to make Nixon sympathetic; Langella tackles the harder job of making him more understandable while still giving us the Tricky Dick we know in all his rumbling, flawed glory.

That's the miraculous thing about Demme's beautiful, harrowing, and utterly humane film -- that for long stretches it doesn't feel like a movie at all, but like a document of someone else's real life.
While their circumstances may be forced, the three characters feel like real, complex, likable people. That's a real rarity in a film about veterans, no matter what the ideology is.
if Hollywood has all but given up on making clever genre exercises for adults, let's be grateful that a few filmmakers from across the pond haven't
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's actually Maddin's most accessible film, and underneath the surreal images and foreboding narration is a relatively familiar message: You can go home again. And if you do, feel free to take some creative liberties here and there.
There's not much substance to "Priceless," but what is there is effortlessly crafted and entertaining, and the locales in Nice and Monte Carlo are just spectacular.
Even if they do finally get to leave, the film's dispiriting message seems to tell us, in eight centuries there will probably be a new set of soldiers guarding Beaufort.
One of the most distinctive-looking films ever to play in a theater, a dark fantasy overflowing with mesmerizingly weird images at every turn.
There aren't a lot of huge belly laughs in "OSS 117" (although the chicken fight had me in convulsions), but, consistently clever and amusing, it provokes a lot of grins.
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: "Only Child" is both funny and heartbreaking, and incredibly adept at shifting between lighter and darker tones.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Although the "hyperlink" drama that features a lot of interconnecting storylines has become a common staple of the arthouse, "Jellyfish" manages to be a weird and memorable creature all its own.
Aside from a few misfires, "The Animation Show" is full of visually inventive and broadly hilarious gems.

"Stuck" does what any good B movie should, working its way under your skin with a mix of gory jolts and outrageous humor, while cutting uncomfortably close to the bone in its look at how people really behave under pressure.
"Renaissance" seems more like video footage than a documentary, capturing a little hot air but not shedding much light.
"Body of War" is so simple-minded and ham-handed in its case against the war that it ends up diluting its own argument.

The influences shown by its group of American and European artists are Edgar Allan Poe and Alfred Hitchcock rather than George A. Romero and Stephen King, getting chills not out of what we're shown, but what we imagine lurks in the darkness of the gorgeou
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The performance is so oversized that, just as Barbara cowed her husband and son into submission, the other actors seem to tiptoe around Moore.
This is that rare film where a daring style is connected to real substance, and that's an exciting thing to experience in a first-time director.
A movie that was inspired by the Lindsay Lohan flop "Just My Luck" should not run three minutes longer than "The Dark Knight."
A breathtakingly funny movie that weaves together huge gut-level laughs with some very subtle and layered satire about show business.
The film really puts you in the shoes of those New Yorkers who looked up from their daily lives one day and saw something utterly unimaginable.

The question is whether it really makes sense to turn Lamorisse's fanciful original film into a downer family drama; it's sort of like doing a modern-day version of "Narnia" where the kids never find the wardrobe.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: "Father" handles things with grace, wit and a healthy dose of authenticity, staying true to author Blake Morrison's clear-eyed memoir of the same name.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I understand Amer is supposed to be going through some sort of spiritual crisis here, but Caland plays him as so self-centered and precious that it's impossible to feel any sympathy for him.

This isn't a movie about big emotional breakthroughs, but about the slow thaw taking place in Juliette's heart, and writer-director Philippe Claudel and the actors do an excellent job in charting a series of small, telling steps forward.

Watching "Examined Life" is sort of like sitting on a plane next to a total stranger who insists on making conversation. Except this is that one time out of 100 when the stranger turns out to be a completely fascinating person.
This is one movie that could really use a trim.

Credit novelists and first-time screenwriters Eggers and Vida (married in real life) with creating such rich, complicated and humane characters, and credit actors John Krasinski and Maya Rudolph with bringing them to life so wonderfully.
In the end, both the believer and the skeptic end up less sure of their beliefs than they were when they started. Which must be at least a small step towards true enlightenment, right?
What fate could be so horrible that someone would defraud the government, lie to family and friends, even marry someone they didn't love just to avoid it? Why, moving to Canada, of course.
You may not leave the theater with a firmer grasp of Italian politics, but you will leave with an appreciation of some outstanding filmmaking.
It's more in the details and in the margins that "Tyson" is riveting, and what Tyson sometimes reveals unintentionally.
Jessica Biel turns out to be up to the task of handling Coward's deliciously acidic lines and is well-matched with an impressive all-British cast in the sparkling "Easy Virtue."
It's not much more than a ride; the plot is thin, the characters aren't very engaging, and it just lacks that storytelling spark that Pixar movies have year after year.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: "Public Enemies" knows the language of the gangster movie so well, and yet director Michael Mann has taken it and created something exciting and new out of it.
(500) Days of Summer" is the first great cinematic romance of the Facebook generation.
If the corridors of power really are this dysfunctional, let's at least hope they're this funny, too.
The sneak preview audience was gasping and shrieking throughout. A couple of teenage girls had to leave the theater midway through and sat huddled on a bench in the lobby. It's that freaky.
If ever a movie needed a restraining order issued against it, it's "I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell."
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: They say that when you gaze into the abyss, the abyss gazes back at you. Looking into the sunglasses of Vogue editor Anna Wintour must be kind of like that. Except that you never think to yourself, "I wonder if the abyss thinks I look fat in these jeans?"

Cinephiles who thought Atom Egoyan went off the rails with the tawdry cheese of "Where The Truth Lies" will be happy to see "Adoration," which shows the Canadian filmmaker once again in fine, austere form.

boy, when you see Ellen Page and Juliette Lewis whipping around the corner, the beer-fueled crowd cheering, and the Breeders' "Last Splash" blaring on the soundtrack, you know that "Whip It" has the spirit of roller derby down cold.
The tights and the hairstyles may have changed a lot in 30 years, but the desperation and the elation remain the same.

In its unassuming, offhand way, "Humpday" gets the details of male friendship uncomfortably right -- the self-denials, the macho bluster, the constant comparisons about where that guy's at in life versus me.
It's a breezy, entertaining little film that ends up being more sophisticated and thoughtful about love than it first appears. Sometimes a kiss is just a kiss, and sometimes it's a lot more.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's as if he's trying to reach through the screen and show us the real guy behind the image he's spent a lifetime creating. I'm not sure if he's successful, but the attempt is fascinating.
The rich may be very different than you and me, but you have no idea how different until you see "Valentino."
"The Brothers Bloom" operates on a much larger scale, a globe-hopping, visually dazzling caper comedy, but at heart it's just as in love with language and storytelling as "Brick" was.
"Che" is a taut thriller, a fascinating character study, a pitiless black comedy, and one of the most singularly interesting biopics ever made.
"Bashir" is an animated film that mixes truth, memory and fantasy in a phantasmagoric concoction that is hard for the viewer to shake.
The indie drama is a slow-motion exercise in economic frustration, as a young woman with already limited options sees her few choices evaporating around her.
See Life of Reilly and you won't see him as a pop culture footnote ever again.

Cregger and Moore not only star in "Miss March," they wrote and directed it too, which seems like a selfless act akin to throwing yourself on a live grenade, protecting any innocent careers around you from getting hit by flying shrapnel.
The filmmakers seem more interested in running the camera over Marcela's body than really figuring out who she is.

Every student has some potential, we see, which is why it's so heartbreaking to see them caught in the gears of a public education system that's doing its best, but hampered by limited resources and an institutional mind-set.
It's a masterpiece that deserves to be ranked up there with mob epics like "Goodfellas" and "Once Upon A Time In America," even as it rebukes the conventions of those movies.

Abrams has approached the source material with the right spirit of loving irreverence, and set the stage for what hopefully will be a rebirth of an enduring franchise. A five-year mission doesn't feel nearly long enough.
"Hunger" pushes through the cliches of both prison films and political films to make something original, powerful and hard to shake.
Ah, the London Blitz. Bombs falling, buildings on fire, people dying all around. Good times, good times.
It's a documentary-style look at the harrowing journey illegal immigrants take to get into this country, but it's also a tightly plotted thriller.
Was there any idea that came to writer-director Matt Aselton while he made "Gigantic" that he didn't use? Seriously, that cutting room floor must have beenSPOTLESS.
Larrain's film is primarily a character study of Raul, an unpleasant but unforgettable man who is part "King of Comedy" Robert DeNiro, part "Cape Fear" DeNiro.
But take away the bedroom settings, erotic websites and pillow talk, and it's really a fascinating look at anyone who finds their business and personal lives completely fused together.
Writer-director Eran Riklis handles these questions subtly and thoughtfully, tying the little struggle over the trees to larger issues without turning "Lemon Tree" into a parable.
We're so used to sports movies hitting certain dramatic beats that when "Sugar" completely avoids them, it forces us to sit up and pay attention.
It's a romantic "dramedy" that treads some familiar ground, but does so smartly and thoughtfully.

I don't know what's more surprising: that director Gus Van Sant has made yet another movie about the lives of disaffected Portland teenagers, or that he's pulled it off one more time with "Paranoid Park."
DiCillo hasn't lost his gift for artfully skewering both those basking in fame's spotlight and those lurking in the shadows, while still finding a measure of affection for all of them.
While the film stresses how hip-hop unifies different cultures, it's interesting to see how each culture's youth has appropriated the principles of hip-hop for its own self-expression.
"Ratatouille" is so fresh and fun and original and wonderful that the very least I could do is get through this review without any lame cooking metaphors.
It's those personal stories, of ordinary lives destroyed one form letter at a time, that make "Sicko" so powerful.
The dialogue in "Poison Friends" is clever and erudite, but underneath the lit-crit the film has the atmosphere of a Hitchcockian thriller.
Just go with it, drink in the rich and innovative images, and wish that you could remember your own dreams as well as you'll remember "Paprika."

Author James Howard Kunstler says the suburban landscape is "brutal" and "soul-draining," and it's hard to argue when the filmmakers show him sitting in a bike path "rest area," a little bench behind a chain-link fence with a view of the freeway.
Equal parts heartwarming and repulsive, the compulsively watchable film is certainly 90 of the fastest, weirdest minutes I've spent in a theater in a long time.
When Frank stands up at a meeting and confesses that he wants to kick the bottle so he can devote himself more fully to killing people, "You Kill Me" achieves a perfect black-comic pitch.
There is some great acting here, and some scenes do have an undercurrent of elemental power in them that tugs at your ankles. But the film never pulls you in.

I'm not sure what's so amazing about "The Boss of It All" -- that Danish director Lars von Trier turns out to be such a deft comic filmmaker, or that he seems to be so palpably enjoying this rare foray into comedy.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: When the film veers into drama toward the end, it's a bottle-throwing, mascara-streaked exercise in bathos rather than anything remotely resembling real life.
That the film overlooks Austen's imagination becomes understandable when "Becoming Jane" reveals itself to be a rather unimaginative second-rate copy of a Jane Austen novel.
Folks looking to pass 90 minutes with a comic horror movie in the vein of "Tremors" or "Shaun of the Dead" won 't need to feel -- heck, let 's just say it -- sheepish about buying a ticket.

When the film falters, it's when it pulls its punches and gives us conventional horror that we can hold off at a safe distance, rather than uncomfortable insights that we can unsettlingly recognize from our own household experience.
At times, "Hot Rod" seems to park itself on the viewer's head and refuse to budge until it gets a laugh. And it does, sometimes.

You just want to shake the filmmakers by the shoulders and yell, "You have a damaged spaceship loaded with nuclear weapons speeding straight into the heart of the sun. Really, that's not enough drama for you?"

It's way too early to signal the rebirth of the western at the movies, but if it happens, it'll be because of smart and thoughtful entertainment like this that sucks audiences in whether or not they care how the West was won.
we leave the theater feeling like we've just been at a church service that went on a little too long.

The brilliance of "Earrings" is in the precision with which Ophuls carefully strips away all the luxury until what we see is not the extravagance, but the wounded, tragic marriage that the extravagance is meant to hide.
movie_title: The Earrings of Madame De... (Madame de...) (1954)

movie_review_blurb: I'm not saying this is a John Cassavetes film or anything, but the movie's ability to uncork one great line after another that evokes both a laugh and an uncomfortable feeling of recognition is masterful.
Call it "Garden Province."
For fans of Potter's work, "Miss Potter" is indispensable. But even viewers with the haziest memories of those unique little books will enjoy spending 90 minutes inside her idyllic world.

A great film because of the way it moves beyond social commentary to show how each character, rich and poor, is isolated and at the same time unified by his fears and needs. We're all in a class by ourselves.
movie_title: The Rules of the Game (La règle du jeu) (1939)

movie_review_blurb: Born to be reviled.
Like a bite-sized film festival, these shorts collections give viewers a quick and satisfying tour through a range of films, and hopefully will become an annual tradition.
"Inland Empire" represents Lynch at his unfettered best as well as his undisciplined worst.
It packs an emotional kick that we don't expect from a movie where a giant iguana is running around with human legs dangling out of his mouth like stray pieces of linguini.
It's that willingness, even eagerness, to put in such passionate contrary viewpoints that distinguishes "An Unreasonable Man" from the usual political documentary.
Perhaps those futuristic folks could send another Mimzy back in time to a better filmmaker like Joe Dante, who can do a better film adaptation of Padgett's story and beat Shaye to the punch.
Beneath the suspenseful pleasures of seeing Irving evade one trap after another, the film has a deeply cynical view of even the most righteous person's capacity for self-delusion and corruption.
There's just one hysterical scene after another, ideal for an acting class but off-putting over the course of even a relatively short film like this one.
While the film is ostensibly a "49 Up" style look at how Sean the child grew into the man, what it really is is a penetrating look at how Arlyck the young man grew into an old one.

While the film has its share of exciting battle scenes, Loach captures them with an almost detached, documentary-like feeling, as if not wanting the thrills to overwhelm the essential tragedy he sees in the story.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What really makes this potentially melodramatic story so powerful is the incredibly intense and focused presence of little Kolya Spiridonov, who makes you believe Vanya's determination and grit every step of the way.
"Away From Her" is one of the great love stories of recent movies, striking because it takes place near the end of a love affair's long journey, rather than at the beginning as so many romances do.
"The TV Set" feels a little underdone and half-realized, as if it were the pilot episode for a show that never got picked up for the fall season.
There are certainly some big emotional moments here that vibrate with emotional intensity, but they always stop short of sheer theatrics, and it doesn't feel like any of them are unearned.

"Air Guitar Nation" does deliver the goods, with some extremely funny scenes and some honest-to-goodness rocking concert footage. Although I fear that the existence of "Nation" has nudged us that much closer to a karaoke documentary.
One is struck by how both filmmaker and subject had their lives changed and improved by such a chance encounter, the kind we hope for when we live in a city.

There are French movies that are clearly made with a French audience in mind, and there are other French movies that have a non-French audience in mind. Daniele Thompson's "Avenue Montaigne" seems to be aimed at a third, highly-specialized audience; peopl
It often undercuts its nobler goals by resorting to hammy dialogue and unnecessarily melodramatic contrivances.
That the ending doesn't play fair with the audience is a misdemeanor; the felony is that the filmmakers don't seem to realize what an ugly moral statement they're making with it.

I can certainly recommend the experience of having seen "Lady Chatterley." The experience of actually seeing it, however -- all 168 leisurely paced minutes of it -- doesn't generate quite as much enthusiasm.
You feel like you've stumbled across a lost treasure from some studio's vaults that was meant to be buried forever.
These are two unique and unforgettable family films -- one an essential part of world cinema, the other an underseen gem -- that a new generation deserves the chance to get acquainted with
There's something about the 1979 Stephen Sondheim musical that awakened something audacious and inspired in Burton, sparking him to make his best film since "Ed Wood."
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A completely captivating and powerful moviegoing experience, a heartwrenching but redemptive story that deftly intertwines the personal and the political.

Documentary filmmaker Amir Bar-Lev's "My Kid Could Paint That" is an impressive feat in that it revels in its own ambiguity while still giving us a very entertaining, ripped-from-the-headlines mystery story.
Much of "Juno" crackles with great lines that nobody would ever actually say, but everyone wishes they would think of.
In the end, Langella lays his character bare before us but leaves his dignity intact.
"Citizen Kane" drenched in oil and blood and left to bake in the hot California sun.

Watching "27 Dresses" is like going to a wedding that's kind of lame -- the chicken marsala is stringy, the DJ only knows show tunes, and the best man's toast almost triggers an annulment -- but you end up having a decent time anyway.

Temple gets at the heart of Strummer's character, at the unbridled joy that existed within his righteous anger, the satisfaction of knowing he was on the right side of history and hadn't had to sell any part of himself to get there.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that "Savages" looks at an ordinary and often inevitable part of life shouldn't obscure the fact that this is a beautifully written and wonderfully played film, capturing the nuances of family dynamics as assuredly as any film I've seen in quite
Did Woody Allen kill somebody once? Could somebody check and make sure Tony Roberts is OK?
We never sympathize with Bauby, because, for much of the film, we are him.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: If making "Youth Without Youth" helped to clean out the pipes for Francis Ford Coppola and spurs him on to do better films, then that's great. The film has served a purpose.
Page is a great character in search of a movie, and "The Walker" doesn't provide it.
Writer-director Martin McDonagh revels in splattering his profane, bloody film all across Bruges' lovely cobblestones, and the result is a spectacular, hilariously transgressive debut.

Much of "Counterfeiters" is actually pretty thrilling, as Sorowitsch, a classic taciturn anti-hero in the Humphrey Bogart or William Holden mold, struggles with whether to go along with the Nazi plan or figure out some way of undoing it from within.
"Young@Heart" plays like a 100-minute version of one of those "on the lighter side" news feature segments that end a local newscast.
"Ira & Abby" doesn't throw out the romantic comedy rule book, but it occasionally shuffles the pages a little for comic effect.

Every character in The Golden Compass has a 'daemon', a talking animal sidekick who follows them everywhere. It's a neat idea -- I wished I had one sitting in the theater with me to explain what the heck was going on.
You can't fool all of the people all the time, but maybe the Yes Men can trick enough of them into doing what's right.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In a strange way, "What Would Jesus Buy?" might actually be the most heartwarming holiday movie out there this year.
It's when the investigation sorts out the knowable (what happened?) and then moves into the unknowable (why?) that "Elah" moves beyond genre and becomes one of the year's best films.

"Promises" is a solid, involving crime thriller elevated by some quintessentially Cronenbergian touches, but it's not a truly disturbing Cronenberg experience like "A History of Violence" or "Spider."
If "Before Sunset" gave us Paris in all its Bohemian romance, Delpy almost gleefully shows us the dingy, crabby flip side of the city here.
One senses that zombie film kingpin George A. Romero, who satirized consumerism in "Dawn of the Dead," would smile like a proud papa if he saw it.

You sense that Seeger may feel his greatest legacy is not what he accomplished, but what his presence gave others the courage to accomplish. Even if it was just singing along with a roomful of strangers.
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Add in a terrific soundtrack of original songs by singer-songwriter Sondre Lerche, and "Dan in Real Life" is an unexpected and very welcome treat, a crowd-pleasing mainstream comedy with the soul of an indie.
The most bizarre thing about "Lars and the Real Girl" is how it takes such an outlandish premise and rescues it from John Waters-esque camp.

"The Jane Austen Book Club" is far from a failure, especially if it sends curious fans of the movie back to Austen's original six books. I just wish Swicord had gone back to Fowler's original novel once or twice more to see why it works so well.
"Moliere" actually tells a funny, involving story that really does seem inspired by its subject, rather than just lazily cribbing from his work.
In a way, "Devil" is two horror stories, the first is what Steidle saw in Darfur, the second what he saw when he left.
It's more like an action movie, a very well-made one, that has a subscription to Newsweek.

I expected that "Gangster" would pay homage to films like "The French Connection," "Superfly," "Serpico" and even "The Godfather." What I didn't expect was that the spirit of those films was deeply imbedded in its bones.

About the only audience that might get something out of "Love in the Time of Cholera" are lazy college students who want to learn the plot points for class without having to sit down and read the book.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Gavras maintains a light touch throughout that allows us a rare chance to emphasize with both the radical and conservative elements at the family dinner table.
movie_title: Blame It on Fidel (La Faute a Fidel) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Not satisfied with just being one of the best thrillers I've ever seen, "No Country of Old Men" goes beyond that in its third act to becoming a haunting and unforgettable American classic.
It's frustrating, brilliant, beautiful, maddening, hilarious and tragic, and may ruin me for conventional rock 'n' roll biopics that provide easy motivations and facile answers.
One of the pleasures of "Devil" is watching what a classic, old-school director Lumet is, focusing intensely on character and staging rather than relying on fast edits or visual trickery.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie could use a little more juice in the scare department, but overall it's a pretty clever way to repackage the global warming threat for the average audience.

Director James McTeigue finds moments of pure brilliance amid a story that stumbles from one questionable choice to another.

movie_review_blurb: Oh come on. Like you couldn't smell this turkey rotting from miles away.
For an hour or so, it really achieves something memorable. The rest of the time, it contents itself with merely being a solid, entertaining ride.
... it launches Shakespeare into the 21st century without sacrificing his timeless appeal.
It's a bit disappointing that it only manages to be decent instead of dead brilliant.
Without something more stirring to finish things off, The Count of Monte Cristo wastes 100 minutes of decent buildup.
A neo-noir thriller as compelling as it is repugnant, it holds images and themes of such haunting power that you're willing to overlook the unpleasant stench surrounding it.
It isn't so much a yarn as an immersive experience, an attempt to convey the foot soldier's viewpoint in the most primal and immediate manner possible.
It espouses simplistic solutions, phony platitudes, and dripping schmaltz in the place of genuine humanity, making a lie out of all the emotions it wants so badly to champion.
So eager is this film to grapple with its demons, that it doesn't realize how much like them it has become.
It's frustrating to watch the filmmakers unable to make the pulse-pounding leaps that their title character would complete with ease.
This wicked diversion continues the trend against bloodless Masterpiece Theater adaptations, and reminds us that there's life in British filmmaking yet.
A surprisingly decent bit of fun to close out summer's dog days.
With a top-notch lead and a talented director, it delivers some smart summer chills that serve as a nice tonic from CGI-laden banality.
A good filmmaker can make grim material watchable, but it takes a great one (or two) to make it fun.
For those looking for a little scary fun, in the spirit of a man who once attached joy buzzers to theater seats, Thirteen Ghosts makes a tasty Halloween treat.
...a sort of Cuckoo's-Nest-meets-My-Favorite-Martian that probably sounded good on paper...
A few weak points appear... but the only reason they stand out is because we're so used to Pixar knocking the ball out of the park.
As a caper movie, Heist is as good as any you'll see. As a David Mamet movie, it leaves something to be desired.
[It] isn't so much a noir movie as a movie deeply in love with noir, a valentine to that seamy world of hard lives, deadly women, and luckless shmoes in trouble...
Rarely has a movie seemed more beholden to its roots, or required so much outside help to give it its spark.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: No one can fault Soderbergh for restoring a little dignity to the Hollywood event film. Ideally, every big budget extravaganza should be this good.
The important question isn't "What's going on?" but "Why should we care?" Vanilla Sky, unfortunately, can't come up with an answer.
Like The Others, it presents a taut, scary tale of hauntings and madness, while going its predecessor one further with a sobering meditation on the horrors of war.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Though technically polished... it feels curiously ordinary, a word one never associates with Muhammad Ali.
...its solemn pretension prevents us from sharing the awe in which it holds itself.
If Attack of the Clones struggles harder than its predecessors, its triumphs still shine through.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Its near brilliance comes in the way it makes use of its material, creating a picture that's anything but run-of-the-mill.
There isn't a movie out there that feels quite like Near Dark; it seems to personify its subject matter even as it transcends it.
It never quite escapes the stereotypes, but it also never contents itself with business as usual.
You'll have more fun setting fire to yourself in the parking lot. You'll be more entertained getting hit by a bus.
Strong filmmaking requires a clear sense of purpose, and in that oh-so-important category, The Four Feathers comes up short.
Not only does it squander most of [Jackie Chan's] assets, but it provides very little to distract us from the waste.
Imperfect? Yes, but also intriguing and honorable, a worthwhile addition to a distinguished film legacy.
Turning a great movie into a pretty good one is still a step in the wrong direction... and The Ring will never be more than a pretty good movie.
Even if the world doesn't see things the way [Michael Moore] does, his questions are worth asking.... and Bowling for Columbine benefits from his iconoclastic zeal.
Spirited Away conjures up a beautiful, diverse, richly envisioned tale that constantly delights... even when it verges on the limits of coherence.
...an angry, raw, shockingly beautiful romantic comedy that tests the limits of our every expectation.
[It turns] another Behind the Music sob story into a unique parable of life in front of the camera.
After struggling interminably to bring the first of the obscenely popular Harry Potter novels to the screen, director Chris Columbus finally cracks the code with his second effort.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: While Soderbergh succeeds in recapturing the themes and mood of Tarkovsky's version, he also brings with them a cold, emotionless sheen, a detached air that defeats his efforts to truly engage us.

Die Another Day never escapes the urge to play with everything that's come before it -- so much so that it forgets to give us something of its own. This isn't a Bond film so much as an amalgamation of Bond's greatest hits...
There's no power fantasies here, no ego trips or fairy tale stories about a loser made good. In this case, the persona serves the story, not the other way around.
It can't properly manage its wonderful conceit, and proves ultimately too timid to make the impression it really should.
[It] sounds a death knell for this overhyped marketing phenomenon, and not a moment too soon.
Never mind that it's often crude, gauche, and obnoxious. It never pretends to be otherwise, and in its flagrant honesty, it earns a strange sort of respect.
This is a movie on autopilot, too tired and broken down even to find an appropriate place to crash.
A little more intensity and a little less charm would have saved this film a world of hurt.
The effort is less surprising than the impressive and often spectacular way in which it succeeds.
Sometimes, fond memories should stay in the past: a lesson this film teaches all too well.
At times, it waxes a little saccharine, but it believes fervently in its characters and story, and makes us believe in them too.
You'll probably see worse films than Men in Black II this year, but won't see many as disappointing.
...a movie that wants to be great, tries to be great, and on a certain level is great... though perhaps a tad too slick for its own good.
...flop sweat is never shagadelic, baby.
Though not as brilliant as Eve's Bayou, The Caveman's Valentine represents an admirable sophomore effort, and a terrific showcase for Samuel L. Jackson.
...an eerily suspenseful, deeply absorbing piece that works as a treatise on spirituality as well as a solid sci-fi thriller.
X-Men delivers the goods.
Panic is the kind of movie that reminds you of other movies, then turns that familiarity into an asset.
[It] may be another Alien rip-off, but it's a rip-off with class, style and a lot of heart.

[The] skillful execution is enough to overcome some of the film's weaker aspects.
The turgid soap opera of a plot reveals little of the human truths [it] presumably wants to uncover.
Certainly, [it] has a passive watchability but it never does anything new or different with its material

[Director Peter] Jackson and his crew have so steeped themselves in the majesty of Tolkien's writing that every frame produces new joys, whether you're a fan of the books or not.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Like its seductive protagonists, it wants to show us everything it can... but never reveals what we really want to see.
Its efforts to walk on air are consistently undermined by the solemn-yet-gutless lecturing it feels compelled to inflict upon us.
Smart, funny, technically proficient... and taking no prisoners. Bless its twisted little heart.
the sort of film that junior high school students will adore... and then rent ten years from now and wonder what they were thinking.
The Mummy Returns has everything a sugar-addled twelve-year-old could possibly want. I'll leave it to you to decide if that's a good or a bad thing.
...a lazy, unfocused, long summer afternoon of a film, full of good ideas that never get properly developed.
[Denzel Washington] towers above the film's petty failings, overwhelming them with his sheer presence and defying us to tear our eyes away.
Bandits can't hope for any real originality, but hard work and intelligence can sometimes make an adequate substitute.
Like its protagonist, Hedwig succeeds on its own terms, brazenly asserting itself with no regrets or apologies.

...a longer, slower, more bloated version of [the] incendiary masterpiece which retains much of its power but suffers from some seriously unnecessary revisions.
It's hard to believe that an embarrassment like this will be remembered for anything other than its own mediocrity.

movie_title: Ghost Dog - The Way of the Samurai (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Everything about it evokes comparisons to other animated features, and while it more or less holds its own, nothing comes across as new or even interesting.

After ninety minutes of one-note foreshadowing and Beautiful People acting carefree and idealistic, you're actively rooting for the Japs to bomb the snot out of them.
Two decades ago, this would have been a great movie. Now, it's just another round of leftovers.
For starters, it's just plain goofy.
Though High Fidelity is hysterically funny, it never descends into slapstick or parody; the story remains grounded enough to let the central ideas develop beautifully.
The Phantom Menace opened to the exact same complaints as its now canonical predecessor. Only this time, its very real assets have been almost completely dismissed.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The filmmakers knew the type of movie they wanted to make, [but] their puckish spirit is no match for such messy and directionless material.
The movie lives on borrowed time, and for all the gorgeous scenery, the devilish wit, and the fine performances, the true power of its story has already come and gone.

...a meandering shaggy dog that never really goes anywhere but has a marvelous time trying.

Walking out of Memento, we can be glad that we don't share Leonard's amnesiac condition; it's the kind of film you don't want to forget.
despite some wonderful moments, this Planet of the Apes isn't going to make anyone forget Charlton Heston sinking to his knees in the surf.
The fissures lurk throughout the film, but A.I. works around them quite admirably... until the unfortunate concluding sequence.
It's easy to dislike what Swordfish is selling... but it makes a compelling pitch.

Silly, turgid and devoid of even the hints of original thinking, Mission to Mars is a testament to shameless creative theft.
A little more action and a little less talk would have taken things much further.
All the snickering about Francis's little girl can't hide the genuine talent at the heart of this film, talent that has only begun to find a voice.

...while it doesn't entirely capitalize on its homogenized premise, it avoids embarrassing itself by reaching too far.
Is it better for the additional material? That's debatable. Is it still the scariest film of all time? Watch it for yourself and try to disagree.
movie_title: Exorcist: The Version You've Never Seen (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Cameron Crowe has made a heartfelt piece of work that stands among his best: a love song to anyone who ever wanted to be cool...and never quite found their way.

We should probably be grateful that The Grinch is merely flawed and mediocre, not the flat-out disaster it could have been.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: In a choice of lesser evils, you could do a whole lot worse... While it never climbs very high, it survives because we know how much further it could fall.

As a crime story, it would be engaging enough on its own, but it gains it true strength in the measured and disciplined study of its protagonist.
Thoughtful and gripping without wallowing in dramatics, it marks another high point in Sam Raimi's strange, but increasingly accomplished film career.
Watching it stumble about reminds one how difficult this sort of material can be, and how Satan needs more than some bad CGIs to be truly scary.
...it reminds one of the works of Clive Barker: strange, horrible and utterly unnerving.
[John] Waters skewers every aspect of mainstream Hollywood, using the truly demented Demented... as a proxy howl of rage.
Sun Tzu believed that becoming predictable would lead to disaster. Apparently, the creators of The Art of War couldn't be bothered to take him to heart.

...its status as an event picture and insistence upon live action mar what should have been a delightful romp.

Even with a pro like Samuel L. Jackson in the title role, it has a hard time keeping the balls in the air.
As a movie in general, Gone in 60 Seconds is garbage. As a joy buzzer, it's suffering from permanent brownout
movie_title: Gone in 60 Seconds (Gone in Sixty Seconds) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: It churns out moderately solid summer fun with enough flourishes to gloss over its disposable nature.

Football here serves as the fulcrum of an entire society, in which everything... is distilled into the pressure cooker of fourth and long at the 35.

Thrilling and sublime, delivering a beautiful message while scarcely making a ripple in the film's near-perfect dramatic arc.

Dark, but not scary; whimsical but not saccharine; pessimistic but believing quite firmly in the power of self-reliance.

movie_review_blurb: A summer film for grown-ups, delivering verve and intelligence along with its pulsing visuals.

Less a proper story in itself than a reminder to enjoy the wonders [J.K. Rowling] has conjured.

movie_review_blurb: Pleasant, mushy, and utterly, utterly soulless.

Oh yeah. That's the sweet spot.
Over the top and completely humorless, but also fiercely effective.

movie_review_blurb: Both thorough and supremely entertaining.
movie_title: Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A modest film to be sure, but that modesty still packs a satisfying punch.

Wan, thin, and surprisingly boring, even for the simple needs of a genre picture.

...a big, baggy, sprawling carnival of a movie, stretching out before us with little rhyme or reason.

A one-of-a-kind wake-up call that begins and ends with Harvey Pekar. Without him, there is no movie; with him, there's a movie you can't resist.

movie_review_blurb: Retains a real sense of power. Its message never wavers, always visible beneath the gore.

The lack of cynicism may be Eddie the Eagle's biggest weapon.
