Movie 43 deserves at least some of the bad press it's getting, but don't be surprised if it sticks around a little longer than its detractors believe.
Ask it no questions and it will tell you no lies: a fair bargain that too many other films on this level resolutely refuse to grant.
It sets a standard that few can beat.
movie_title: Batman: The Dark Knight Returns, Part 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Bullet to the Head definitely qualifies as a guilty pleasure, but if you can't enjoy the guilty ones, you've missed the whole point of Stallone's career.
Once you get past Urban's magnificent performance, it doesn't feel much like the Mega-City One we expect.
An undeniably cheesy yet strangely appealing time capsule, with a little something for everyone provided we understand that it's all bubblegum.
It ain't perfect, but it sure finds a way to get the job done.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It coasts to a stop too often for comfort, searching in vain for a reason to keep moving forward.
Dark Skies shows us glimpses of the movie it could have been before squandering it all on silly misfires and a lack of overall thrust.
Snitch isn't anyone's idea of a great film, but it aspires to be a good one.
Fee. Fi. Fo. Meh.
The best film of 2013 so far.
Leave your preconceptions at the door and enjoy it for what it is. In this case, the man behind the curtain knows what he's doing.
We've seen this movie before, in better clothes and with a much higher IQ.
movie_title: Bai she chuan shuo (The Sorcerer and the White Snake) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Resident Evil: Retribution can't even pass muster for the simple standards of this series.
Burton wraps it all in his singular vision, devoid of bells and whistles and all the more potent for its comparative subtlety.
It stands in sharp contrast to anything we've seen from American filmmakers of late: equal parts creepy, whimsical and political.
It retains an eerie elegance in the last few minutes: not as arbitrary as the traditional horror twist, but duly earned by the slow development that precedes it.
Concepts appear and are abandoned with ruthless efficiency; threats rise and are dispatched with the glum drudgery of a janitor cleaning up puke in the toilet.
How sad that such efforts rarely find the audience they deserve.
This film sucks on a level I can scarcely describe.
The battle in Blue Thunder is less between Scheider's edgy police pilot Frank Murphy and his ultimate nemesis (Malcom McDowell), as it is between Murphy and the high-tech beast he's asked to pilot.
The character in the book never came down from that hole in the sky; one look at the movie and I'm ready to follow him.
John Carter is an absolute romp.
Its central purpose hinges completely on the ending, and... suffers so horrendously from its ninth-inning swoon that it's hard not to feel the sting.
It earns its laughs and never takes our affection for granted.
[Overcomes] the occasional rough spot to deliver a faithful and interesting sci-fi adventure.
"A" for effort, O noble warrior, but Harry Hamlin still eats your lunch.
It's bright, it's beautiful and it hasn't aged a day. So why, then, do we need to see it in 3-D?
Anyone who presumes to love horror movies needs to see The Cabin in the Woods.
Since it makes no apologies for what it is, neither should the viewer regret the utterly disposable entertainment on display.
If you shoot for the moon and miss, it's a long way down. The Raven gives us a front-row seat to the plummet.
I can't say the found-footage format of Chronicle was particularly impressive, but the rest of the film is a minor revelation.
It follows a time-honored pattern not out of laziness or studio-dictated formula, but because that pattern can still terrify us in the right hands.
While the cast includes Ed "I'm Here to Save the Film" Harris, Kyra "I'm Here to Save the Film" Sedgwick and William "I'm Here to Save the Film" Sadler, none of them actually save the film.
As the flabby self-importance of the latest Oscar nominees oozes all over us, The Grey offers a surprising and most welcome respite.
Immortals' beauty is undeniable - rendered with the stunning prowess of a true artist - but it sits atop an incoherent hash of pretense and bloodletting.
It can't match the original, but it's not the first sequel to fail on that front, and it still offers plenty of fun and enjoyment in compensation.
A torturous slog through endless pages of Bridal Wet Dream magazine.
The Muppets are evergreen; it just took an effort like this to remind us of the fact.
While the easily bored may find it hard going, those attuned to more cerebral entertainment will likely be hypnotized.
The most disappointing film of the year: not dreadful, but falling so far from the brilliant initial film that its good points hardly matter.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This fifteen-year-old franchise - with more downs than ups in the balance - is a long way from done.
It sets the stage for the best cop drama since Heat... and ultimately proves unable to meet those expectations.
Dragon Tattoo offers a handsome package built on rickety foundations, hoping to pass inspection on good looks alone.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Its handful of inspired moments arrive amid oceans of wasted opportunities: never awful, but utterly forgettable in their familiarity.
It must be January. The s****y exorcist movies are in bloom.
"Unpleasant" isn't the same thing as "incompetent" and I have to give props for The Divide's sheer unflinching nerve.
The apex of an art form, a justly celebrated classic, and the best animated movie of any sort ever put on screen at any time.
Don't think too much and you'll be fine.
A wafer-thin pro-feminist spy thriller that thrives solely because we haven't seen its like before.
At least they don't sparkle.
In many cases, the artifice of motion capture gets in the way of the story. Here, it actively compliments it.
A whimsical confection that effortlessly puts a smile on the lips of the harshest cynic.
The film is a delight... and it doesn't need to be anything else.
[Burton] fails on levels I wouldn't have imagined possible.
Barbarella couldn't exist in any era but the 1960s and its delightful over-the-top qualities find an ideal expression in the ridiculous excesses of the time.
It actually leaves us very interested in possible sequels. Considering how things could have gone, that's pretty... well... amazing.
The sight of so many name performers lining up to score a quick buck is positively depressing.
Mines the collective goodwill of the Marvel nation to impressive effect,
A bad comedy is one thing, but a bad comedy starring funny people is unconscionable.
A sad carbon copy, devoid of any flair and existing mainly to get people to see the first one again.
Without more of an emotional stake, the film can't convince us to pay closer attention.
I laughed a lot during The Campaign and that's all that really matters.
Noble failures are still failures... no matter how hard they try.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Damn you goofy bastards; how can we stay mad at you?
It celebrates the gothic outsider in familiar fashion, though it does so with a wisdom and gentleness that Burton seems to have lost.
The bare-bones framework of an utterly generic horror story, devoid of thrills, jolts or even an interesting hook.
It finds joy in the little details: the sharp dialogue, the crackerjack chases, the constant yellow CG lines covering Wilee's routes away from (or all too often straight into) danger.
An interesting failure...
Beyond the basic idea and the few clever gems that spawn from it, [REC] 3 doesn't improve on the formula much.
Great story or bad art? You can't get one without the other in Superman vs. The Elite and that's a crying shame...
The film maintains an actual "plot," but views it more as a nuisance than a necessity, probably because it would detract from the scorching homoeroticism of Bostwick in his spandex unitard.
1) It isn't as good as the first two. 2) It's still pretty good. 3) Don't beat me.
A motion picture masterpiece on the short list of Reasons Why This Medium is Worthwhile.
Its magnificence stems from the very properties we should be condemning with all our might.
As alien invasions go, this ranks as one of the most inept in movie history.
I'll say it: the single greatest horror movie ever made.
I wouldn't recommend taking MIB3's tortured path to success; I'm just really glad it got there.
A gloriously entertaining ride, provided you have a taste for dark material and don't mind the occasional poke in the ribs.
Watching the protagonists fall one by one, it becomes clear that this isn't a cautionary example: it's sweet Darwinism in action.
A movie that plays like its own art book: lovely to browse through, but excruciating to actually experience.
It lacks the visceral anarchy to which it clearly aspires: that sense that Cohen is playing with lit dynamite that could explode at any moment.
Not only is it the best of the series so far, but it actually makes us look forward to the prospect of a Part Four.
A carnival hustle that even The Hoff should be ashamed of.
"To boldly go" never went quite so boldly as it did here.
movie_title: Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan (1982)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to Poltergeist, more than a few of us still sleep with the lights on: the world has changed, but our closets haven't.
Perfection is a harsh mistress and as a film from the studio that practically embodies the term, Brave can't help but suffer.
It makes us believe in magic again even as grizzled, cynical adults.
The summer's most fantastic guilty pleasure.
Regardless of its box office performance, Prometheus has a long life ahead of it.
Richly mythopoeic and sophisticated.
How many blockbusters deal with that kind of grief?
The physical creakiness only adds to the sense of mental dilapidation suffered by the anti-hero.
movie_title: Morgan! (Morgan: A Suitable Case for Treatment) (1966)

movie_review_blurb: If this is to be Shrek's last outing, it's good to see him bow out in style.

Central Intelligence is a big cartoon caper that is a heck of a lot of fun, and for fans of the buddy picture genre, Dwayne Johnson or Kevin Hart, or any combination of the above, it will likely hit most of the right notes.

It's definitely a film made by women, about women, for women -- and a special one at that. But for filmgoers who stick with Minnie and witness her difficult journey, it is also a superb portrayal of a young girl's inner strength.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Loving is a deceptively simple movie about the complexities often hidden deep beneath the calm surface of simple appearances.

The 33 reminds us that all those faraway global news stories we click by every day are actually about real people -- fathers, mothers, sisters, brothers, sons, daughters, families. Loved ones. Humanity. I can't think of a better reason to go to the movies
The Boss has its moments and a first-rate cast, but considering the level of talent involved, just doesn't quite get the job done.
Like roadside diner baklava, if it's a little dry in places, there's enough honey to make it sweet.
In spite of a slightly awkward ending, the film is a deeply serious, tender examination of emotional devastation.
This off-shoot is a heck of a fun science-fiction film, and the last third of the movie is a wild, epic battle.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Those who truly appreciate a great chick flick may find it enjoyable, but somewhat disappointing.
Will it go down as one of the greatest films of all time? No, but it's not supposed to. This movie does exactly what it sets out to do - elbow you in the ribs, make you laugh, and not leave a mark.
Land of Mine is a gut-punch of a remarkable film, but anyone with even a little sensitivity may not actually enjoy sitting through it.
After the screening was over, someone asked me what the name of the film was that I had just seen. As God as my witness, for a moment, I forgot.
Nothing really happens, and the ending, when finally something actually happens, has no satisfying resolution so all we end up with is, well, nothing.
It is a colorful, delightful children's film that young girls may find inspiring, too.

For we losers who may have an old dream or two buried behind the wood shed, Patti's journey shows us that growing up doesn't mean giving up. It just means reality is going to punch you in the face now and then, but you have to shake it off.
This is an emotional movie about the oldest and best thrill in the book -- love, and for Alex and Ben that's a lot scarier than some silly old mountain.

This is a small film, but what a beautifully heartfelt one. It's one that deserves to be seen, if for no other reason than to remind us that there are still corners of the world where the vulnerable are watched over by the compassionate.

The film's nowhere near as clever as it thinks it is. Gallo starts as an extremist nutjob, killing for his beliefs - but turns into a hungry maniac, killing to stay on the run. Does the film draw a fascinating comparison between the two? No.
95-odd minutes of full-blown, big-screen bliss.
Mars Needs To Work Out How To Animate Humans So They Don't Look Like Possessed Shop Window Dummies.
Bunk.

The Red Riding Hood trailer was roundly mocked by some sceptics, who said it looked like Twilight in a puce cloak. A disgustingly cynical notion...that's turned out to be one hundred per cent correct.
Monsters, sword-fights, boobs AND laughter? Giveth this a ruddy Bafta.
Slow and spurious.
The only real problem with Scream 4 - which won't be an issue for series fans - is that it's a bit too Screamy for its own good.
A thuper Thoraway thuctheth.
A charming tale of a trouserless binge-eater who lives under a tree stump.
You'd have to be a right helmet to miss it.
The young cast are a game bunch - especially when it comes to the being dumped in the Highlands in their undies bit.
Beauty And The Beast except with the lusty, gothic menace that makes that story interesting replaced by moany teenagers and crap acoustic guitar music. Or, in short, Dawson's Freak.
Toby Kebbell's war hero Robert Miller is a troubled soul. He's a handsome fella with a bit of swagger but he looks in the mirror with pure hatred and ties his tie like he's garotting himself.
Effectively a coming-of-age comedy set 25-odd years later than normal. Tim Lippe's a 40-year-old in the body of a 15-year-old with the haircut of a four-year-old.

There's always some chump happy to claim that any given horror film was so scary they were "whimpering in sheer terror". Difference with Insidious is, the damn thing's so scary I actually WAS whimpering in sheer terror.

What would Ray Winstone sound like if he did a South African accent? Answer: Exactly the same as he would if he was doing a London, Italian or Kathmandu accent. Like either a homicidal tuba or Muttley with a hangover.
Enjoyably sweet, and the third act kicks you square in the emotion-goolies.
The film rightly draws attention to a horrible event in history. But unfortunately that's all it does - and a decent documentary could have done exactly the same, much more nimbly.
Looks a lot like either a very stupid person has tried to make a very clever film, or a very clever person has tried to make a very stupid one.
I've not been this disappointed by a movie's title since that Penelope Cruz film Blow turned out to be about a drug dealer.
It's never clear whether Sean Penn is aware just how annoying his character is - or if he genuinely thinks his finger-wagging smug- sack act is sympathetic.
The Resident clocks in at a lean 91 minutes, yet I'd rather have had a longer film if it meant the bizarre gaps in the plot were plugged.
You know me: I'm flamin' ALWAYS in the mood for 2 1/4 hard-going hours of sex and crying. And if it's in Japanese, so much the better.
Das Beaut.
Exactly the kind of funny, sunshiny, teen-skewed romcom that Britain normally struggles to make.
Feels less like a movie than the action scenes clipped out of one.
You will dislike this rubbish movie.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Hall fail.

SINCE the early days of cinema, great actors have found immortality by playing heroes of the Roman Empire. Charlton Heston, Richard Burton...and now the dormouse-eyed, muscly fella from a couple of dance films and that cack GI Joe thing.
An instant folk horror classic.
Haller's a twerp, he's a twonk, he's a slick-haired smoothie who plays by the "doesn't play by the rules" rules to the letter.

This enjoyably OTT drama-with-songs-in-it was monstered in January by American reviewers, who were maybe expecting a highbrow, subtle and meditative drama in which Gwyneth Paltrow is an alcoholic banjo player.
Anuvahood's so funny, I even laughed at Richard Blackwood's bit.
"Are we truly the crocodiles who look back into the abyss of time?" asks Herzog. Good question. And after thinking about the answer for a while, I'm gonna have to go with my gut instinct. "Eh?"
Looks suspiciously like a cack Santa flick in which the fat red guy's been switched with a talking rabbit.
Everywhere & Nowhere's director Menhaj Huda says that getting the film made felt like "a long journey". Try watching it, son.
You almost feel yourself getting smarter as you watch. Remember how you felt sitting through Transformers 2? Kind of the opposite of that.

The original book was praised for nailing the way teenagers think and speak. Unfortunately, that's not been carried over to the screen version - unless the teenagers you know think and speak like saucer-eyed chumps reading their emotions off an autocue.
The two halves of 13 Assassins are as finely balanced as one of the samurai swords from its grand, limb-lopping LOL-fest of a finale.
Paul Bettany in a cassock with a cross biroed on to his forehead, potholing with vampires. In 3D.
"I just missed your heart," Hanna says at one point, as she spears an enemy to death. Not mine, she didn't.
An hour and a half of pan-American todger-teasing.

Take heed, The Hangover: Part II. When a studio asks for "more of the same", it's possible to come up with a film that hits all the same high notes as its predecessor - without just photocopying the script and adding "... but abroad" after every gag.
The film's main stock-in-trade is the kind of faintly bizarre, offbeat gags that you might find in a decent US sitcom - which is no bad thing and also makes sense given the writers' Office pedigree.

You wouldn't wish the supporting cast on a film made by your worst enemy. They include the dad from the sixth Beethoven movie (yeah - somehow they got him), Angus Deayton with his bum hanging out, the mummified remains of Jerry Stiller.
Shame nobody told writer-director Oren Moverman not to shoot The Messenger... before giving the script a good rewrite first.
I can't say I'm too comfortable with the hero kid in a holocaust drama (Hugo Leverdez) being a blond-haired, blue-eyed Master-race Child.
I'm still hoping for a sequel in which Jodie gives Mel a puppet cockerel.
Two finger-drumming hours of puffed-up, prancing tripe, that couldn't have been any more irritating if the lead role was played by that bellowing Go Compare fatso.
Completely and utterly honk-like-a-goose hilarious.
Gordon Ramsay must be the first man I've ever seen to be out-acted by his own hair transplant.
As is standard in reviews of prison movies, the Film Reviewers' Code obliges me to tell you "it's nowhere near as good as A Prophet". But even so, Ghosted's a top piece of work.
Viva Riva! is exploitation cinema done right - it's got both feet planted in the here and now but its heart's bursting with the same lurid, filthy values that B-movies have embraced for decades.
Normally I'm against decent original stories being dumbed down and squashed into bog-standard thriller shapes. But Incendies is in dire need of some dumbing down.

Plenty of superb recent blockbusters, including The Matrix, The Dark Knight, Minority Report, Dark City and Inception, are all in its debt - not to mention a fair number of shockers, like Star Wars Episode II and the most recent Resident Evil atrocity.
Cleverly, as new details emerge about what REALLY happened, your sympathy lurches from side to side like Amy Winehouse doing Back To Black at the Belgrade Alhambra.
You don't watch The Tree Of Life so much as loll in front of it. It's part puzzle, part coming-of-age tale, part wildlife documentary, and all mind-blowing.
If you're prepared to sit through two and a half hours of noisy cack to see a grand total of three decent special effects sequences, then I can heartily recommend it.
The soundtrack's ace, the dance routines are great, and the eye candy's Wonka-standard.
I've often thought that I'd like to see a bit more of Juno Temple. After seeing Kaboom, I don't think it'd be possible to see more of Juno Temple.
Only a twisted, seriously sad individual could have a problem with this sunny tween comedy, which I hated.
Goes like the clappers for all of its elastic-snappingly tight 84-minute running time.
Lost for a***holes.
Utter blocks.
Overlong, at times boring, but in the end it seems worth it - although you've no idea why. Which, for a film about a pilgrimage, is pretty apt.
How much of a Western is Red Hill? The fact that at one point the bad guy shoots someone off a roof and he somersaults face-first into the street should answer that.
By Jig's end, director Sue Bourne seems to have lost interest in all but two of her young subjects. In fairness, that's two more than I managed.
Yo ho ho and a bottle of sleeping tablets.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: So much fun to watch, I almost feel guilty about not rating it higher.
Takes an enlightening look at the life of a Jewish lad from Hammersmith who became a fashion world superstar by cutting women's hair in a style that became known as "the Justin Bieber".
Here's a film in which Twilight's Robert Pattinson runs away to join the circus - but, amazingly, not as the Incredible Giant-Faced Man.
Trundles along for the most part in sitcom fashion, even down to the plinky-plonky background music.
Basically a child-friendly Superbad.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If you allow it to, it'll break your heart.

The opening act in particular - with its gunfights, bank heists, sex, parties and grimly violent cutaways to Vallanzasca in prison - is punchier than Mr Punch using a hole punch to punch a punch bowl.
This X is on fire.
A film that seems to have been written mainly with the find and replace function on Microsoft Word.
It's what some parents might call "good clean fun". Just without the "good" and "fun" bits.
Its grimy authenticity clicks like a rusty mortice lock.
Formula One fans should love it. More tellingly, so should everyone else.
This 1980s-set comedy was shot in 2007 and has been sitting on the shelf ever since. The damn thing's so old it's almost retro twice over.
Liam Neeson deserves a huge pat on the back for reinventing himself as the most violent middle-aged man in Hollywood. I'm just not gonna be the man to do it. As I'd probably pull back a stump.
Spoofs such kiddie favourites as Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas, the mystical writings of Carlos Castaneda, and Sergio Leone's Dollars trilogy.
Ekes some gentle yuks out of culture clashes and father-son strife.
Two thirds of a fantastic film, bolted onto the final third of a rubbish one.
Should get the whole family laughing, albeit for different reasons.
Only distinguishable from a Hollywood alien invasion movie, like Skyline, in one way. It's actually REALLY good.
The Dawn Treader will henceforth be known as the Yawn Spreader...for its magical ability to bring boredom to cinemas between here and the outermost reaches of Aslan's Country.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I'm sick of the simpering American morons who lap up this rubbish.
Amalric nails Zand's well-meaning but hapless nature, even if he does look like a pimp Oompa Loompa.
Freasonable.
Perfectly skewers the Hollywood airhead lifestyle.
A showcase of the most astonishing computer- graphics' work Hollywood can muster... all wrapped round one of the most lunk-headed scripts that was ever parped out of an ink-jet.
You have to see this new film called Catfish. Only problem is, I can't tell you why. Which, admittedly, makes this review useless.
The damn thing's been soundtracked within an inch of its life. Whenever Ange glides into a room it sounds like a concert harpist's having a coronary.
Camper than Lady Gaga riding a unicorn down Brighton seafront.
Yeah. I know what you're thinking. If I were you, I wouldn't believe this review either.
There are only so many ways you can frame a bunch of hairy men and a token girl stumbling over the prow of a hill while moaning about being thirsty, before it gets boring.
Badagascar.
The film's a 12A because it contains "behaviour that would be dangerous if copied". Quite right, too. If I ever see anyone acting like Fred, I'll probably loose off a shotgun at them.
Not just bad. Planet-smashingly bad.
Chin up, Freida love. At least it's not The Last Airbender.
A film that no sane movie exec would ever commission. Fortunately for us, though, there are no sane movie execs.
I'm blaming the staggeringly cack script, which leaves more loose ends untied than a short-sighted vasectomy doctor.
Effectively an old samurai movie crossed with a Visit Italy brochure.
Lacks pretty much everything that made the first film such a masterstroke.
The ad campaign has stressed that Saw 3D is the last Saw movie ever. Strange, cos the film ends with a twist that sets up yet ANOTHER flamin' sequel.
I'm no Mike Leigh superfan. But when he's on form he's fantastic, and Another Year is as good as anything he's ever done.
A clunking great chunk of monkey junk, that smells a good few decades past its sell-by date.
Has the emotional depth to break your heart as well as stop it.
Just a case of 'same s***, different day'. Literally, in some cases.
The film pretends Tom and Julia are just two regular, down-to-earth, middle-aged people - even though their faces couldn't be any tighter if they pulled washing-up gloves over their heads.
Due Date ain't The Hangover. But it is a decent Leftover.
ALL hail Kristen Bell - a woman whose screen presence is so grindingly tame, she makes Hello Kitty look like Daniel Day Lewis.
A towering achievement. Or rather, half of a towering achievement.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Should win fans from the horror and arthouse crowds alike.
Less a Palme D'Or than a Dalme Sn'Or.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Behold: it's Indepen-dunce Day.
Less a proper coming-of-age movie than a posh version of Home And Away.
The Matrix: Revolutions of the Millennium Trilogy.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Machite.
Jazz fans would be be well-advised to check it out, cos this film gives you some serious horn. As it will if you're a fan of sexy cartoon ladies. Ahem.
Denzel is on the right track (oh yes) with this one. In fact, he definitely delivers the goods (wahey). You might even say he's chuffing brilliant (make the nightmare cease).
Colin Firth's made an amazing film by being a stuttering, upper-class English gent? Hugh Grant must be bloody kicking himself.
At least we now know why Anne Hathaway's co-presenting this year's Oscars. She's not gonna make it to that stage any other way.
It kind of isn't.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An hour and a half of what bears do in the woods.

Imagine you heard the Coen brothers had gone and made a straight-up Western. Now imagine Jeff Bridges, Josh Brolin and Matt Damon were in it. As movie news goes, that's on a par with Christina Hendricks signing up for the Piranha 3D sequel.

Why the hell is this film not on the awards shortlists? Were voters THAT turned off when the cast turned up bongoed on Moet on Film 2010? Or did they just need to make sure there was room on the best actress roster for Annette Ruddy Bening?
Rest assured I'm not going to give the game away as to whether Marley beats the disease. But given the movie's set in New Orleans - a place famous for its funerals - I wouldn't hold your breath.

Gnomeo & Juliet is Romeo & Juliet...but with gnomes? That's TERRIBLE. It's like doing Moth-ello, a kids' film about a Moorish general who hatches from a cocoon, flies towards lightbulbs and eats jerseys.
Get a load of this: Paul smokes marijuana cigarettes, has jumbo-sized naughty bits and keeps making jokes about probing bums! Goodness gracious me. Pass the smelling salts, Aunt Jemima.
Isn't so much scraping the bottom of the barrel as hurtling through the bottom of the barrel at Mach five, straight towards the planet's molten core.
It's amazing really, when you look back at the Big Momma's House film series, how many major crimes can be solved by dressing up as a fat woman.
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Praise be for Inside Job, which crunches the credit crunch into 1hr 45mins of easily digestible fact biscuits, fed to you one by one by narrator Matt Damon.
While it might turn off awards voters, its strange, icy beauty will win it a fair few fans among the black-nail-polish mob.
Before seeing Justin Bieber: Never Say Never 3D, I honestly couldn't have cared whether Justin Bieber lived or got mown down by a lorry. But now, I'm unapologetically sold on the guy.
I Am Number Four is a film about a teenage boy who discovers his hands wield a very special power. (Aye. We've all been there, son.)
They say what you see in Nicolas Cage's hair is a reflection of your own soul. To me, it looks a bit like a giant, microwaved wombat slipping off the top of St Paul's Cathedral.

Problems range from howlingly obvious flaws like the foul, Knocked Up-wannabe script, to almost undetectable nuisances like the way Kutcher never signals when he's turning into a side street or driveway.
Everyone flapping their traps about the "Oscar-calibre performances" in The Fighter - simmer down for a minute, will ya? Cos THIS is how you do a dirtball family.
You've got to admire the way it reins in the action sequences and concentrates on character development instead - something that's about as common in Hollywood as a bum bag made out of unicorn fur.

THERE comes a time in every great movie-watching experience where a special little moment in the film makes you smile with purest joy. For me, in Ironclad, it was the bit where a guy tears another guy's arm off then beats him to death with it.

The flaw at The Fighter's heart is the fact that Bale's all over the place. It's a frog-faced, flailing-armed, look at meeee performance that, had it come from Nicolas Cage, would have drawn scorn across the board.

Contains the line: "I'm gonna put a price on your head so big, when you look in the mirror your reflection's gonna want to shoot you in the face." That's pure action-movie dialogue poetry. No way am I not giving a film with that in it a thumbs up.

This electrifying thriller about a US Army bomb disposal squad working in Baghdad isn't just one of the best films of 2009. It is the first film that tackles the Iraq War head on, and does justice to the incredible bravery of the troops serving there.
Sparklingly funny, beautifully heartfelt, wonderfully uplifting and brilliantly performed. In short, it's the best romantic film since . . . well, what exactly?
JMD may be technically superb but it is brutal and sick-making. As such, it's hard to fault . . . but I wouldn't watch the blasted thing again if you paid me.

Destined to be remembered as "the first film you saw Carey Mulligan in". Cos she's ruddy wonderful. And delivers one of those rare performances that can't really be faulted. Bafta glory, in some shape or form, is all but guaranteed.
The plot's a total shambles. The message (rob, pillage and snort your way to a no-consequences happy ending) stinks.
A crime thriller with the crime and thrills taken out.
Spectacular? Exciting? Beautiful? Unique? Yes, yes, yes and oh HELL yes. It's like nothing else you've ever seen. And believe me - you need to see it.
We've had romcoms - now here's the first of the homcoms. And I've gotta admit it made me feel both happy and gay.

Director Rob Marshall has come up with something close to an ideal modern screen musical. It is every inch a toe-tapping, show- stopping tour de force that has a big chance of snagging some gold come awards season.

Spread is sleazier than Tiger Woods in a zebra-print tuxedo but amid the flailing boobs and six-packs there's a fair bit of polish, probably thanks to talented young Scottish director David Mackenzie.
This jaw-droppingly hopeless sequel deserves to be packed off for a one-way exchange trip to Columbine.
movie_title: St Trinian's II: The Legend of Fritton's Gold (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Everyone in this entire production does brilliantly.
Nigh-on unforgivable. An all-fumbling, all-bumbling, all-trundling crock of crud, that's not so much Snatch in a Deerstalker as bum on a flagpole.
It's almost-but-not-quite as good as the 2006 classic post-disaster film Children Of Men - and that's good enough for me.

This biopic of legendary London-born rock 'n' roller Ian Dury marks the rise of a serious talent. In fact, you'll be wowed by Serkis's performance as Dury - even if, like me, you don't know the first thing about the bloke he's playing.
This is escapist fluff, pure and simple, but it's given a huge boost by some deliciously funny scripting from writer-director Nancy Meyers and a trio of ace lead performances.
You're left with the nagging suspicion that, with just one more script polish, it could have been something very special.
A fun if forgettable romp, with some great ideas and a few gruesome shock shots. Which is enough. Just.
If terrible movies were car crashes, this 101-minute horror-show is a coachload of orphans slamming headlong into the Hoover Dam - and 2010 is unlikely to serve up anything worse.

Writer-director Jason Reitman again shows he can mix comedy with the deeper emotional stuff. The soundtrack's peppered with great choices. Small but perfectly formed scenes abound. And the ending is totally unexpected - but totally apt.
Despite a set-up dripping with more menace than Shere Khan in the shower, this is not the ultra-violent gangster romp it looks like. What unfolds is a riveting character piece.
What follows is a string of reasonably interesting ups and downs, with no clear overall plot to thread them together. It's kind of pretty good, ish.
From that belting opening shot to the emotional gut- punch of an ending, I was bewitched by it. In fact, Wild Things... I think I love you.
It's a zombie movie without any zombies, which works about as well as a martial arts film where nobody gets punched in the teeth.
If you've watched The Descent already, you won't get anything new out of this. And if you've not watched The Descent already, just watch The Descent.
Nowhere near as bad as the hype suggests - although if you're in the mood for something straightforward, this is not for you.
Inspired daftness. And well worth a stare for fans of Clooney and inventive comedy alike.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As a movie to get you in the Christmas spirit, A Christmas Carol does its job nicely.
The performances are quality and the rapping, written and performed by the cast, is SUPERB - if anything, the film could have done with a lot more of it.
Despite being visually stunning, it's as dry as hell.
Despite a few good ideas and flashes of genius in the script, the whole film is a total bore.
Disaster movies can't get any bigger than this (until Emmerich makes a film about Earth crashing into Mars or something). But it's fair to say they can get a whole lot better.

A blazingly confident movie from first-time director Daniel Barber, which is packed with strong performances. And the lawless mood is evoked so well, at times it feels like a Western. It's a disturbing, downbeat but vital British film.
One hell of a film, made by one of the most brutally clever directors out there. [But] One to be admired, more than loved.
The best thriller I've seen all year.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Last time Swankatron went a-courting awards, she did so with the amazing Million Dollar Baby. But this biopic of legendary pilot Amelia Earhart is a hundred times blander.
While the plot might not have the epic sweep of No Country For Old Men or be the comedy bloodbath of Fargo, this film is every bit their equal.
After 1 1/2 hours of ker-azee chuckles, you get one big clunker of a climax tossed in your lap.
Not quite glorious... but fans of good old-fashioned wartime mysteries will find it really rather spiffing. Pip pip!
If you want a crazy mix of Saw and Shawshank, where a lot of people get killed in nasty ways and Gerard Butler gets his bum out, then this is a decent bet.
So boring it made me want to slap my own face off with a tea tray.
Nativity! is sweet and it gets what makes children laugh. Plus there are some fantastic performances from the kids.
Shamelessly old-fashioned, hugely unfashionable and absolutely brilliant.

It's no shock to see Shrek co- writer Joe Stillman on the credits, because Planet 51 follows the exact same formula - slapstick for the kids, sly gags for the parents and a rubbish romantic subplot for nobody.
It's an amuse-bouche, for exactly the kind of twerp who uses words like "amuse-bouche". If that's you, you'll love it. You big ponce.

This blistering French crime epic isn't just the natural successor to City Of God, with its sweeping plot, jawbone-shattering violence and trouser-troubling tension. It's within spitting distance of the classics. The Untouchables. Scarface. Goodfellas.
Antichrist, by turns brilliant, by turns boring, is the most average horror film of the year.
This is that rarest of beasts - an indie thriller that tries to win over viewers not with crowbarred-in whimsy but with a gripping plot and two brilliant lead characters.
The International would love to be the new Michael Clayton but it's nowhere near smart enough. It also fancies its chances as the new Taken but it just doesn't have the guts.
An impressive, if flawed, one-off.
In the end, of course, it comes down to the chemistry, and this relationship really does feel like one worth fighting for.
Jen's tale is nowhere near as complex or subtle as the psycho-trickery regularly peddled by her old man. Still, even if the destination's a disappointment, the journey makes up for it.

Know1ng is a terrible movie. But for sheer "you can't do that. You CAN'T do that. Did they just do that?" slack-jawed, drop- yer-popcorn astonishment, it's hard to see how this will be beaten in 2009.
It's a little beauty of a film, made with immense skill, good humour and no small amount of affection.
It's an absorbing piece of work, and the entire production's got talent stamped through it like a stick of rock.
An intelligent, action-packed thriller, made on a modest budget with no mega stars? Phew! Didn't see that coming.
The Boat That Rocked? Not quite. It's more of a mildly exciting wobble.

Kids will adore the flash 3D visuals, brilliant action sequences and ace sight gags. Mums, dads and others will relish the quickfire dialogue-some of the best we've heard for a while in any film-and the affectionate nods to sci-fi of times past.
There are a few laughs but anyone with half a brain will be able to tell this is a pretty shoddy fit-up job.
A very enjoyable, and often fantastically funny, teen movie.
Fifty Dead Men Walking is gripping, tense, nicely shot-and much more watchable than the "other" IRA movie Hunger.
A return to gloriously idiotic form for the street racing series.
A real hidden gem of a film-if you only see one Swedish, gender-bending teen vampire love story this year, this has got to be it.
Set in that weird film version of Nazi Germany full of RADA-trained Home Counties poshos, Good is, in a sense, an amazing achievement- it makes the Holocaust boring.
Watch I Love You, Man with your friends, and you'll see one film-a bawdy chucklefest about male bonding with puke and fart gags.
Just another disappointment to add to the 'too good to be true' pile.

A bile-spitting, side-splitting little beauty of a film, this is to the smug, Oxbridge-ridden world of political satire what a prostate exam by Mike Tyson in a Burmese outhouse is to standard medical procedure.
A movie so bland, it might as well have been filmed in Hounslow.

Cruising into cinemas with worse timing than a Taiwanese Rolex, this chick flick about one woman racking up five figures of credit card debt seems less like a comedy than an epic 104-minute finger-wagging session.
Frost/Nixon is no crowd-pleaser or jaw-dropper. But it IS two actors at their peak talking beautiful words, in front of a camera.
This is a warm, beautifully detailed, if slightly long-winded biopic from Good Will Hunting director Gus Van Sant.
A slick, starry thriller that entertains for the full two-hour running time without threatening to do much more than that.
Basically it's Frost/Nixon to Dross/Vixen. And there's plenty to be ashamed of.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: French viewers flocked to see Paris 36 like they were giving away neon cagoules and bumbags. Brits will probably be less impressed. But it won me over-sucker for cheap European whimsy that I am.
The Broken isn't a bad horror film. It's just not a film-it's scary footage that serves no purpose.

NANIP is a film that feeds on the giddy high of life's potential, and the first tingling flush of romance. So if you're a 65-year-old grave-digger who lives alone in a caravan, this is probably not the film for you.

I don't know anyone who'd want to watch, in these miserable times, a marriage swirling down life's khazi. But that doesn't stop it being a fine piece of work. And while I didn't enjoy it at all, I can definitely recommend it.
It's a lovely, often hilarious piece of work.
TCCOBB is monumentally impressive. Three hours of pure screen magic.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's more heavily staged than a fourth judge walk-out in the second week of a Simon Cowell talent show.
It's been adapted from a kids' book called The Little White Horse, and the plot's been totally mangled. But to be fair, the costumes are great.
A sparklingly funny, meltingly sexy romcom.

feel free to sing along here: "It's a stinker, Pink Panther, your heart'll sinky-dink panther. And it's as plain as your noooose . . .You couldn't make a weaker, truly aby-si-mal, ranker Pink Panther from heeead-to-toooooes."
It's bang-average biopic fodder but fans will enjoy the attention to detail and hearing Biggie tracks on a cinema soundsystem.
One thing this latest rehash - No 11, by my count - does achieve, is make the original look like a frickin' masterpiece.
This is a join-the-dots yawn-fest of the laziest kind, ditching any serious attempt to get its teeth into the characters.
It's a monumentally great film and keeps you spellbound till the lights come back up again.
State Of Play is that rarest of movie happenings-a case of the PERFECT line-up of cast and behind-the-lens talent lining up in a great big cosmic doodah thingy of brilliance.

It's sharp, smart and incredibly funny. But most importantly it's real, with none of the macho gangsta posturing that often makes tough, yoof-centric drama look like a lazy British retread of Grand Theft Auto.
To nobody's surprise, it's a rubbish but loveably camp shambles.
Doghouse looks as if it was knocked out in a day by amateurs, as the afternoon activity on a not-very-good stag do.
In turning the dirt-cheap original into a glossy slice of gore-nography, Wes and director Dennis Iliadis have lost one important thing. The entire ruddy point of the exercise.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's bigger. Badder. Boobier. And many other words beginning with B, including boneheadedly brilliant.

It took Nick Moran the best part of 12 years to get this made. And the end result's screamingly energetic, wildly uneven, gay as a goose and at times, utter genius. As a Joe Meek biopic, it's perfect.
This is some of the worst writing of the year, from the meaningless title down. Oh yeah, and a tramp keeps showing up to beat up Dano throughout. Not quite sure why, but I applaud the effort.
If Polish, German and Russian sound roughly the same to you (and I can't tell them apart from Klingon) then you're in for two long and confusing hours, friendo.
The highlights are too few, and come far too late in the hefty 140-minute running time. This film is an attempt at great art that fails.
An hour-and-a-half feast of laughs and slapstick action that only the most jaded film snob could resist.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: You've seen this all before, and you've seen it done better.
There's no reason to see Year One, at all. Consign this cack to the history books. Pronto.
This movie cheapens the experience of a family struggling to come to terms with the impending loss of a loved one. Cry? I very nearly did. Just not in the way Cameron probably hoped.
Borat remains Sacha Baron Cohen's masterpiece. But gag for gag, Brüno is every bit its equal. So is it the best comedy of the year? Without a doubt.
It doesn't disappoint. The line-up reads like a Who's Who of 70s soul and R&B. And the sound quality's shockingly good.
At times it's so slow-moving, it's more like 35 Spoonfuls of Treacle. But writer-director Claire Denis has a knack for picking out special moments of closeness.
A film that's a damn sight more enjoyable than it probably deserves to be.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: To say that HP6 is light on incident is like saying that the new Transformers film occasionally gets a wee bit noisy. Understatement of the frickin' Quidditch season.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's one of the best original film ideas in ages - it'll leave your mind whirring for days.
If it's an eyeball-searing historical epic you're after, then Woo's your daddy.
Like all great football films, Looking For Eric isn't really about football. Instead, it uses the Beautiful Game as a way to tell a beautiful story, about loyalty, trust, and friendship.

This is top stuff. There's all the carnage, baps and humiliation you could want from a 15-rated comedy but it's pegged around a smart plot that actually holds up. Take out the laughs, and The Hangover would still work as a gripping, if barmy thriller.
It can be hard putting the boot into low-budget films that have clearly been a labour of love- but it's a lot easier when they're as cr*p as this.
Sub-Hitchhikers Guide To The Galaxy rubbish.
movie_title: Frequently Asked Questions About Time Travel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's both a solid addition to the superhero list and a perfectly enjoyable watch that leaves the door pleasingly open for another X-Men prequel.
Thanks to the superb turns from Michael and young Bill, plus a witty, well-observed script, this is a real slow burner of a film-incredibly moving but brightened by some top comic moments.
Hannah Montana: The Movie is completely worthless to anyone older than their early teens.
Star Trek is the most enjoyable, spectacular, smart and yet brilliantly simple summer movie for an absolute age.

This deliciously creepy fairy- tale-penned by Neil Gaiman and adapted by Nightmare Before Christmas director Henry Selick-might just be the best 3D film ever made. It is, without doubt, the best I've seen.
Does God exist? And if so, why would He ever allow this great big jibbering guffmuffin of a movie to get off the drawing board?
Watching it, I felt like a cow gazing at a Rubik's Cube. In fact, it's the first movie since Mulholland Dr. to leave me flummoxed.
Dear Hollywood, from this day forward, for better for worse, for richer for poorer, in sickness and in health . . . please stop parping out meritless tripe like this.
The audience are left with something in the middle-not enough brains, not enough brawn, and, most importantly, NOT ENOUGH RUDDY FIGHTING.
Take all the late-70s miserablism you can stomach, mix with the usual blend of bleakness and punching, then serve lukewarm on a limp bed of can't-be-bothered.

Tormented deserves a thumbs- up for its top young cast, its willingness to try something different, and for delivering a slew of fun, if hugely unfrightening, moments. So well done for, er, having a stab.
It's either one of the dumbest films in world history, or a sly work of ironic genius. Either way, it's damn entertaining.
The 99-minute, eye-popping, bowel-twingeing, possessed-talking-goat extravaganza that follows must be one of the scariest things I've ever seen in the cinema.
It's a big old pile of baboon cack.

Is Salvation worse than Terminator 3? Well, T3 stank but at least it felt like a Terminator movie. This is more like The Matrix: Revolutions-effects-heavy background sketching and no relevance to the two brilliant originals.
A brilliant French thriller that doesn't need to be changed in any way.
Originality's thin on the ground...But realism isn't the target here -warm and fuzzy feelings are.
This is a solid, if unspectacular, second effort, that retreads the material from the first film with a slightly bigger budget.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A mish-mash of great performances that don't quite add up to a great movie.
The Book Of Eli is directed by the Hughes Brothers. On this evidence, they've got about as much movie-making talent as the Chuckle Brothers. Their last film was From Hell. Guess what? So is this one.
The most intense, intimate and inspirational film since Slumdog Millionaire.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Some of the best street dancing ever committed to the big screen.
Both leads are strong and the tension between Coco and Mrs Stravinsky plays out nicely.
A low-rent cobble-job of the very slackest order.
movie_title: Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore (2010)

movie_review_blurb: On balance, this new version is probably a bit better than the original.
Sfar first wrote it as a comic book, and that's obvious from the get-go -- the film's full of snazzy visual ideas and flourishes.
The mix of downbeat laffs and Mike Leigh-style grimness is nicely balanced, and is boosted by a really well-chosen folky soundtrack.
The deranged fantasy of some demented social outcast.
Dung fu.
It's a gripping tale -- although there's not much to it beyond the intriguing plot -- and the ending's just as smart as you'd hope.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A perfectly decent family romp boosted by the occasional flash of something braver and better.
A pin-sharp send-up of 1970s blaxploitation.
She's a very good character trapped in a quite good movie.
Piranha 3D is not for everyone. But if you're thinking about seeing a film called Piranha 3D, chances are you'll be delighted with it. Watch this sick filth now.
A film so unashamedly manly, it makes Fight Club look like the time they did Single Ladies on Glee.
If you're a fan of foreign cinema, keen to catch one of this year's best imports...Mum's the word.
However rank the idea might be, the execution'll barely make you flinch.
With his eyes goggling and his gob smudging all over the place, he looks like a haunted painting.
Seven or eight years ago, maybe, this team-up might have been worth getting excited about.
It is, literally, no laughing matter.

There are massive crowd scenes, bombing raids, mafia dramas and nostalgia by the skipload. A film about one or two of these things might have been decent. This film touches on all of them, and ends up being about nothing.
ven slap-bang in the middle of the worst year for romcoms in living memory, The Rebound deserves a special boot up the backside for its raging incompetence.

When Wild Target works it's a lot of fun. There's some decent comic chemistry between the three leads - and this is Grint's first film since Harry Potter 3 that didn't make me want to lob him out the window.
Great news! Woody Allen has extended his run of decent films! To two!
The Collector must be the laziest horror film of the year - the camerawork stinks, the action's boring and the plot holes are so glaring they wouldn't get past a lobotomised goose.
It's impossible to get a handle on Isabelle's reasons for standing up to the rebels. And no matter how smoothly shot the film might be, that's a problem.
Number of record-scratch jokes? Three. Number of walk-into-a-lamppost gags? Two. Number of laughs? Take a wild guess.
Heartbreaker is stylish, funny, woozily romantic and effortlessly sexy, in a way that Hollywood or British films cannot match.
It's not a 'reboot', or a 'reimagining', of the 1980s, Arnie-starring, cult classic, man-versus-monster pic. It's more like the ultimate work of fan-fiction.
There's only been one 7/7 film before this -- the shrill nonsense-fest that was Incendiary. Thankfully, this is much better.
The film pays its dues to the classics. Not only does it lovingly rip off a truck heist from Heat, but Lucky and his gang actually sit down and watch Heat for tips.
More pouting, mumbling and gazing into the distance, mainly. But hey. NOBODY does it better than these guys.
The visuals, with their sweeping grey-blue Gotham-like cityscapes and preference for real-life stunts over computer trickery, are jaw-past-yer-knees outstanding.
The relationship might not be believable but you believe Kristin believes in it. And as far as the film's concerned, that's enough to rescue it.
Although it's low on action, it's high on intrigue - with writer-director Lucas Belvaux concentrating on the mechanics of the kidnap and the police's rescue plan.
There's about half an hour of watchable film in here. The other hour is looping stock footage and endless scenes of people gawping at monitors.
What a hopeless stinker we've got here. Unfunny, crushingly stupid, borderline racist -- and yet I still didn't go for it.
The perfect film does not, and cannot, exist. But if it did, it would probably look a lot like this.
It's refreshing to see a genre movie that credits its audience with a bit of intelligence, and Splice has got a lot going on under the bonnet.

The script, by dyed-in-the-wool New York indie filmmaker Raymond De Felitta, is like someone's homework for a screenwriting course. The secrets aren't interesting and you know a big showdown at the end is a given.
Noomi Rapace returns as our hero Lisbeth Salander, and is just as great as she was last time.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's a string of scenes, it's a blur of faces, it's a heaving great two-hour maelstrom of noise and punching. But it's not a proper movie.
Chapiron couldn't be telegraphing this stuff more obviously if he was standing down the end of Stansted runway with a pair of glow sticks.
Casy Affleck is trying to claim that I'm Still Here is 'gonzo film-making'. And I'm right with him on that point. It DOES look like it was made by a muppet.
Scarier than any of this year's 18-rated horror crop.
A brilliantly-crafted thriller that's been tailor-made for 'mature' audiences - in the very best sense of the word.
Director Stephen Frears made a nice job of The Queen but this is 'King awful.
Interest rates may vary.
If you liked Happy Zac in High School Musical, why not try Sad Zac? All the chiselled sex appeal of the original, but now with a gloomy face on top!
You could write ten thousand words about the outlandish cack-handedness of Takers, but I'll limit myself to just seven. Crap, crap, crap, crap, crap, crap, rubbish.
A bit weedy.
Stupid, throwaway nonsense - and that's the whole idea.
The Social Network is one of the movies for which 2010 will be remembered.
A very small amount of this would be funny. But here, there's 77 minutes of it. And that's about 76 minutes and 30 seconds too much to stomach in one sitting.
movie_title: A Town Called Panic (Panique au village) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It bravely explores untapped comedy wells such as how kids are expensive, how men hate changing nappies, and how single women fancy single men with babies.
Talent borrows, genius steals. Rank idiocy, on the other hand, spoofs.
Despicable Me, the first 3D 'toon from Illumination Entertainment, doesn't just rip off a Pixar film, oh no. It rips off three of them.
The film goes for character-based comedy rather than spiky one-liners, so it's the cast's warmth that cements it as a five-star movie.
The fact this is out in the same week as the fluffy owl movie beggars belief. It doesn't even belong in the same ruddy century.
As part of a school project, I can see it being valuable. As a fun family trip to the cinema, not so much.
Beware that poster, with its jolly red writing and Mork from Ork's face thereon. This is not the Robin Williams of Old Dogs and License To Wed.
This film is WASTED on kids.
However much fun it is to watch, it's a lot more fun to pull it apart afterwards.
The movie equivalent of Kim Kardashian - delightful to look at in motion, but after a while you realise there's not a lot going on.
Laugh? Reader, I barely flexed a tonsil.
What follows is a masterclass in merciless, gut-twisting terror. But The Last Exorcism also knows when to hold back.
It's gone way past film bad -- all the way to crime bad, and personally I'd put the act of making Why Did I Get Married Too? on a level with seven burglaries.
movie_title: Why Did I Get Married Too (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is exactly the kind of role that suits Jen down to the ground. As Kassie, she's dead funny, deeply watchable and hugely likeable. It's just a shame there's not more of her.
Combining top-notch craft and strong performances across the board, particularly from the younger cast members, Cherry Tree Lane is indie filmmaking done very, very right.
While it's unlikely to be anyone's long-term love, if you're up for a fun, quick fling, it does the trick.
Jonah Kex, Jonah Wrex, Jonah Hax, Jonah Kax, Jonah Thix, Jonah Crox, Jonah Sux.
While it may not sound like a romcom, it's a textbook example of how to do one properly, given that it's painfully funny and surprisingly heartfelt.
It's just about sharp and funny enough to make you wish it was a bit sharper and funnier.
The film follows the band down the bog- standard rock 'n' roll madness route, and the shallow script doesn't offer much of an insight into Joan or Cherie's personalities along the way.

From the film's tough opening all the way to the credits, director Nick Moran ladles everything on thick. Some viewers might complain that makes the film a shameless heartstring-tugger. Others, including me, won't see why that's a problem.
So what's the secret ingredient that makes Ferrell funny? The Other Guys finally confirms of what many of us long suspected. It's writer-director Adam McKay.
If film titles get any lazier than this, I'm flying to Hollywood and setting fire to the Writers' Guild HQ building.
It's a tight, gripping mystery with a well-chosen supporting cast and countless great little moments, such as a supremely spooky sing-song at a birthday party.
This franchise has sailed far past rhyme and reason, and planted a flag in a whole new continent of crapness.
Ultimately, the fact it's all down to the, um, Devil, means all the other characters' dark secrets that come to light are a bit pointless.
Buried is completely and utterly, 100 percent dedicated to bringing you all the Ryan-Reynolds-nailed-in-a-coffin action you could ever ask for.
I'm not saying Made In Dagenham is a shallow piece of nostalgic fluff. But within five minutes, Bob Hoskins is singing My Old Man Said Follow The Van during a power cut.
A bra-popping, trouser-dropping, sex-in-the-sticks romp that plays out like Hugh Hefner jack-knifed a Viagra lorry into the Archers' water supply.
Aaron and Aldous are a flat-out pleasure to watch bouncing off each other - their chemistry is much richer than the one-note geek/freak odd couple you might expect.
Lance's family are black. America's family are Mexican. And hilarity ensues! Supposedly.
The script's bowel-rupturingly bland - you can almost sense the bits where they wrote [INSERT JOKE HERE] and never got round to it.
It's hypnotically watchable and tense as a drum.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a great insight into how Banksy and his ilk operate.
This is the film equivalent of Nice biscuits, or snow globes, or N-Dubz. You're vaguely aware that they exist but you don't know anyone who actually likes them.
It's actually pretty watchable thanks to a demented turn from Huston, a terrifyingly tense final act and, shall we say, a 'committed' performance from Liz.
It's well worth a look.
Just normal, common- or-garden, ready-salted bad.
Like a British beach sunset, it starts all romantic and retro but quickly gets dark and starts smelling a bit fishy.
This is one of those rare romantic comedies that's both romantic and comic.
It's about as exciting as a two-part, coconut-flavoured snack chased down with a mouthful of mineral water.

The movie's obsessed with the Tuohy clan's constant kindness towards Mike, and the social knock-on effects for them. But it barely gives a second thought to the poor sod's own struggle with suddenly finding himself a charity case.
There's so little chemistry between the two, they might as well have cast Mick Fleetwood and Samantha Fox and had done with it.

There are a fair few good ideas in Shank -- a nicely-staged market scene featuring Colin Salmon and an animated fight scene being two -- but they don't come together into anything that even looks halfway like a movie.
This is smart, witty and beautifully crafted -- exactly what you want from a family film.
Some movies are great art. Plenty more are trash. But every so often, the stars align, the skies rain fish and you get a heaven-sent mix of the two.
Tough, uncompromising and truthful, yet funny and heartwarming when it needs to be -- this is highly recommended.
Ah well. At least we know Paul Bettany's mortgage is covered.
A fun piece of disposable nonsense.
So jump on that ferry and prepare for a stomach-churning crossing. Just don't blame me if you end up marooned.
Case 39 is basically a poor man's Orphan - which wasn't that good anyway.
It's one of those films that keeps sinking lower than you ever thought possible.
A bona fide, bums-in-the-air fiasco that needs to be burned and the ashes hurtled off in the direction of the nearest black hole as soon as you can, NASA.
The Princess And The Frog is old-school Disney - the first animation of theirs for a good 12 years to recapture the magic of their early 90s output.
What's left still holds up nicely, thanks to firm plotting, Campbell's neat direction and a brace of decent performances.
Peaches Geldof would probably love it. And film reviews don't get any more depressing than that.
Astro Boy is no awards contender.
One of the most cack-handedly amateur films I've ever ground my teeth through.

It's still a great film though - expertly mixing a political biopic and an underdog sports movie together, which under a less sure hand could have turned out like The Mighty Ducks coached by George W.
Where's Al Capone and the North Side Gang when you need them? Cos if the time was right for another Valentine's Day Massacre, it has to be now.
Like Wuthering Heights meets Chewbacca with a migraine.
A teen-pleasing, low-key indie romance with one of the most demented final twists ever.
It's fantastic - stunning to look at, with a career best performance from Firth, and a genuinely affecting story.
It's fantastic fun, it knows its Greek mythology, and it's a very promising start to a franchise. More of the same, please.
movie_title: Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief (2010)

movie_review_blurb: With its suspiciously similar plot and cheapo production values, a name change to Chav-atar is all but a formality.
You wanna know what purgatory feels like? Sit through all two-plus hours of this lurid mush and you'll have a fair idea.
This remake of a 1973 chiller is unlike almost every horror remake on the planet in one key way -- it's really good.

Mushier than a half-chewed rusk. And while that doesn't necessarily make it a bad movie, it DOES make it a syrupy one - with enough hugging and learning to triple your cholesterol during the 100-minute run-time.
If you've only seen one dumb city girl fish-out-of-water romcom, you've seen them all. And you will have definitely seen everything that this miserable 100-minute trudge of a film has to offer.
An uproarious late-night action blast, and it's going to get trashed by virtually every other reviewer on the planet. Ignore them. It's brilliant.
The film is visually impressive and I'd be lying if I said I didn't laugh a few times. But too often, the gags aren't so much quirky as just plain jarring.
If you want to see something suitable for all ages that will dazzle you sideways and remind you of the awesome power of animation done right, you should see this.
I can forgive Guardians all of its shortcomings thanks to the 3D visuals, which had my jaw open wider than a python chowing down on an antelope.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I am bored.
There's the seed of a good idea here. But good geh-RIEF, has it been turned into an all-clucking, all-squawking turkey twizzler of Foghorn Leghorn dimensions.
Viewers will fall into two camps -- those who think it's a mentally unstable mess, and those who think it's a work of insane genius. Can't it be both?
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The script reeks, the characters are charmless toons and the special effects look like they've time-warped into a film from a decade ago.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Seldom do you see a film title that doubles as a likely box office prediction. But that's precisely what we've got with The Losers.
You know how horror sequels tend to be a load of old guff? Not this one. In fact, 2's about as good as they get.
Truth is, Tooth Fairy is a very decent family film -- cute but never sickly, funny but never smug -- that's an ideal half-term afternoon-killer.
Even if you've seen it all before, chances are it's been a while since you've seen it done this well. And if you saw the 2007 version, you've seen it done a lot worse.
The violence isn't the problem. It's the rest of the film that's not quite right.
4.3.2.1 is a totally untested mash-up of slick, Hollywood-style action and edgy British teen drama. And not only does it work -- it works brilliantly.
The film disappoints because, just like Lee's young kidnappers, once the set-up's out of the way, it has no idea what to do next.

It takes everything that was bad about the first Sex And The City movie, and nothing that was good about the Sex And The City TV series, and mixes it together with a bit of racism to create something even worse.
If Wes Anderson and Terry Gilliam ever had a child, science would be amazed and appalled. But also, it would probably end up making a film like this.
Old Ben Stiller has returned.

A boozy Irish-American cop, a sweary African-American cop and a bent Italian-American cop walk into a brothel. What do you get? The climax of the least original cop movie in the world. And that's exactly what we've got here.
A totally acceptable, completely forgettable romcom that will make you laugh a fair few times, before floating harmlessly out of your life.
This is an all-fudging, all-sludging Cheesepocalypse Now of a movie.
Unexpectedly, this feature-length cash-in on a mildly popular American comedy sketch is more fun than most of this year's bum-awful blockbuster crop put together.
Trifles, trivialities, frippery and froth. We've got plenty of words to describe things that don't matter. And now, we also have a film. Please Give.
Cop Out's the most walk-out-able film I've seen in ages.
It's a British horror film full of good ideas, that in another life could have been a subtle, clever and gripping watch.

Director Haim Tabakman conjures up the sad mood very skilfully, with natural lighting, measured pace and an unexpected electronic soundtrack. In fact, it's probably my favourite film about the romantic love between two Jewish guys since Superbad.
Jennifer Lopez is famous for one reason only. And odds are, that's where she found the script for The Back-up Plan.

The pair have got real chemistry and the long-distance love angle works nicely. Then a rubbish subplot involving illness, needy children and horses comes along, and the film spoils faster than a fish finger behind a radiator.
It's far from Gervais's big-screen masterpiece but it gives you hope he's got one in him.
The Infidel's got some great gags -- most of which have a stand-up routine kind of feel -- but a hopelessly contrived climax saps it of any real satirical bite.
The best thing I've seen so far this year.
With raw material this strong, it's odd more of it didn't end up on screen.
Tina and Steve have taken an uninspired concept and uninspiring colleagues, and whipped up a film that works better than you'd dare hope.
The film doesn't just have its cake and eat it. It makes you want to upgrade that cake to a chic Ladurée macaroon.
The story unfolds like a plastic picnic table, with a string of not-very-exciting events standing in for a plot.
It's absolutely freaking fantastic.
The film slumps into the doldrums early on, and truth is, it never recovers. For a film so heavy on characters, it's shamefully light on plot.
The Last Song, from Miley Cyrus. If only we lived in a world where movie titles were legally binding.
They don't make 'em like this any more. And with good reason.
Alice Creed is no classic, but it's not trying to be one -- it's just a well-acted, nicely made, low-key thriller.
This film is flat-out, choke-on-your-popcorn comedy genius.
When Four Lions premiered at a festival in January, some reviewers complained that the mix of laughs and atrocities made them feel uneasy. Way to miss the point, chumpos.
The animals steal Brendan's clothes, wee and guff in his face and roll him downhill in a locked Portaloo. And it's all pretty funny.
This is all style and all substance. Refn crams in all the disembowellings you could want but also serves up some spine-tinglingly rich character work.
To tell a tale, of epic scale, with Ridley Scott again. And if you should moan, he'll beat you with a phone. Russell Crowe. Russell Crowe. Russell Crooowe.
If you're unfamiliar with the delights of anime, I wouldn't start with this one. But fans will adore it.
Farhadi's films are like moral whodunits, and as Sepideh and her friends gradually unearth the truth, he expertly buffets our sympathies in all directions until the very last shot.
Great-looking-but-actually-a-bit-rubbish Irish drama.
A few twiddly Google Maps inserts aside, David Koepp's film is low on kinetic energy.
Jennifer Lawrence hasn't won an Oscar for reading aloud from the phone book just yet, but she may be about to be nominated for selling a mop.
Grandma may not always know best, but it's nearly always funny and absorbing, and there are moments of emotional perspicacity to make you gulp.
The new heroes of The Force Awakens are brightly drawn, occasionally surprising, and an endless pleasure to spend time with.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Hateful Eight is a parlour-room epic, an entire nation in a single room, a film steeped in its own filminess but at the same time vital, riveting and real. Only Tarantino can do this, and he's done it again.
For the most part, the film just seems to waft along, and though Charlie Brown's life is low-key by nature, the stories are mostly flimsily low-impact.
It wants you to leave the cinema not just fired up, but clued in, and goes to knowingly preposterous lengths to ensure it.
I left the cinema convinced it could work - but whatever it was I'd just seen hadn't.
This is the most engaged De Niro performance in at least five years: his dialogue is both apocalyptically unfunny and clearly enunciated, which somehow makes it all the more galling.

This adaptation of R.L. Stine's million-selling series of horror novels for younger readers comes within a hair's breadth of Lego Movie-level ingenious, and occasionally touches Gremlins-level sinister into the bargain.
This isn't the future of superhero movies, but it's an enjoyably obnoxious detour.

Mountains May Depart offers a more ambitious and correspondingly messier treatment of those themes -- but its generation-spanning story has serious power, and, in its masterful opening chapter and final sequence, brushes against greatness.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing that even dimly approximates real life is anywhere to be seen, unless your idea of real life is a half-hearted Sex and the City remake set in an enormous, open-air branch of Anthropologie.

Affleck enlivens it with an unexpected, film-elevating performance that's almost like a pastiche of On The Waterfront-era Marlon Brando - all mumbles, smouldering stares, private smiles, and attention-grabbing fiddles.

It's an accomplished disappointment: the zealous cast, surplus of attitude and sinewy set pieces never quite compensate for the thinly sketched characters, unfocused plot and general gnawing sense of potential not being met.
It does all the feeling on your behalf, and doesn't seem particularly bothered if you join in or not.
A vital, lavish, venomously profane two fingers up at Benefits Street pity porn and the social division it fosters. I laughed, winced, gagged, then laughed even more.

Unearned jump-scares abound - handily, Japan is full of toothless OAPs who randomly leap at young women during the night - as do the kind of obviously digitally augmented ghouls that dispel a creepy atmosphere on contact.

In Alejandro González Iñárritu's astounding new film, DiCaprio puts himself through the wringer. In fact, scratch that: what he goes through in The Revenant makes the wringer look like an Ayurvedic shea butter rubdown.
This is the same wondrous journey on which Apichatpong sends his audience: inwards and downwards, to a place where the simplest rhythms of everyday life become hallowed and mythic.
Blunders at random between leaden Hollywood cliché-ese and florid Russell Brand-style methinksery without landing on a single memorable line or interaction.
It radiates a candour, immediacy and tongue-scalding sex appeal that a bigger budget would have only smothered.
Enough gags are splattered around to ensure a decent rate of stickage ...
Kwapis's film is so un-Brysonishly leaden-footed that Redford and Nolte might as well have walked the trail in diving boots.
Jubilantly uncool...perhaps one of the best compliments you could pay it is that it could have been written 100 years ago.
A reminder that beauty, fun and the irresistible human impulse to create are the stuff that dissolves terror on contact.
This is a handsome and mature entertainment, rich with novelistic intrigue.

Written, shot and acted with a hot-blooded urgency that reminds you the struggle it depicts is an ongoing one - and which shakes up this most well-behaved of genres with a surge of civil disobedience.
The demented brilliance of Miike's film lies in the director's ability to craft ideas that are simultaneously sublime and ridiculous.
Ethan Hawke is one of the most naturally plausible screen actors working today, but Regression is the film that has finally defeated him.
That's what Ghibli's films have always done - they sweep over you like summer showers, and leave the world seeming brighter and refreshed.
Its sombre sincerity and hypnotic, treasure-box beauty make Crimson Peak feel like a film out of time - but Del Toro, his cast and his crew carry it off without a single postmodern prod or smirk.
Boyle's film makes technology warm-blooded, and reminds us that every machine has its ghost.
No film series has been better at raiding its own mausoleum, and throughout Spectre, ghosts of Bond films past come gliding through the film, trailing shivers of pleasure in their wake.
You're left with the sense that Brand might yet be the subject of a great documentary, but he'd probably have to be on the other side of the planet while it was being made.
It just blithely clumps from one plot point to the next.

The screenplay was adapted by John Niven from his own 2008 novel, and he makes the classic novelist's mistake of assuming that the best way to preserve the voice of his original work is by transplanting as many words as possible from it into the script.
It's sad to see this deservedly successful franchise reach the end of its run: but here's hoping its dissident spirit will survive in young-adult blockbusters to come.
An hour-long love story, told twice - but with tiny variations that send each version on a dramatically different emotional course.
The Good Dinosaur may not have much in common with the Pixar films that came before it, but the family resemblance is there wherever it counts.
Najafi ... transfers Escape From New York across the Atlantic, turning London into the terrorist safari park of Donald Trump's most fevered imaginings.

Moverman's screenplay boldly rejects conventional plot structure, instead showing us George's life in breaths and snatches. It's all soundtracked by the city itself: a great clamour of engines and voices, disembodied and indistinct.
Like the earlier Divergent films, Allegiant is studded with enticing science-fiction ideas, but it keeps such a poker-straight face while presenting them, you often can't help but crack up.

The film's determination not to overcook any single scene means the tears it eventually draws feel honestly come by - and the wind-rustled beauty of Adam Stone's cinematography make us realise this world shouldn't be simply written off as a bad job.
It's less a scary movie than a film about fear - the way it finds our weak spots then gnaws away at them, until a rational worry decomposes into formless dread.

Though there isn't a single word of dialogue in the film's 80-minute running time, the big questions it asks, about ambition, acceptance and the beauty of companionship, ring loud in every heart-melting frame.

The film's lucid sense of place and space, helped along by the camera's eye for sensual visual detail and sound design to make your eardrums groan in delight, is one of the film's most generous pleasures.
Even long-standing fans of the Japanese filmmaker might be taken aback by the supreme subtlety of his latest, achingly beautiful ode to the quiet complexities of family life.
