movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Risk doesn't burnish the Assange myth - it injects you into the bloodstream of the Assange story.
A glittering, etherised nightmare, drenched in cold sweat, with a dark, coiled-panther energy that springs at you in fitful, snarling bursts.
Huppert's long-standing genius for expressing complex cocktails of emotions with casual precision is vital to this role.
A great, seething pot of delicious emotional noodles.
Garry Marshall's latest ensemble comedy once again charts the build-up to the annual special occasion of its title in the lives of a variety of blithering idiots.
Poses no direct questions, but leaves your head and heart overflowing with them.
The gas remains largely unstepped on, the brake cables tragically uncut.

Navigates tricky emotional territory with a perceptiveness and tact that isn't just great storytelling, but could be a real comfort to parents and children alike who unexpectedly see themselves in Dory's plight.
Wan's film runs for an absurdly overextended two and a quarter hours, and an entire hour and five minutes have passed before the Warrens actually set foot on English soil.
This isn't just lazy, it's borderline nonsensical.
It's an amiable time-passer, and hopefully a promise of even better things to come.
Perhaps this meeting of suspicious minds really was an unsung crux of modern American history, but Elvis & Nixon feels like a trifle about a trifle.
The BFG feels very much like Spielberg's Powell and Pressburger film - it's a picture that could have only been made now, but feels rooted in the past.

While the note-perfect script, written by the late Melissa Matheson (who also scripted E.T.), treats Dahl's words with radiant respect, it also subtly reworks them to make the story cinematic to its soul.
If you feel there's no space in your life for a 162-minute German comedy, make room.

The look of the film - hair, costumes, even sunlight - is exactly right. The sound of it is even better. Music constantly plays from ubiquitous car stereos and turntables, and every scene has its own groove.
The film zips between claustrophobic tension and nervous laughs with hoverfly agility.
Even in its apparently throwaway opening gag, Anomalisa has human existence covered.

One of the scariest horror movies in years - and not the creep-up-and-prod-you kind of scary either, but a profound, unsettling dread that gnaws at your bones, and which comes back to find you in the dark.
No major blockbuster in years has been this incoherently structured, this seemingly uninterested in telling a story with clarity and purpose.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One of the film's great strengths is the trust it puts in its young audience to decode its complex, nuanced message about the value of difference.

Fletcher has a brilliantly attuned sixth sense for what his audience wants to see at any given millisecond, and Eddie's final flight, from the 90-foot ramp at Calgary, is a mini-masterpiece of intuitive cutting.

The mood's often as fun as it is funereal, and though the film occasionally feels clever in a way that isn't necessarily a compliment, Sokurov's ideas have a philosophical depth and richness that are found almost nowhere else in cinema.
The film could have easily passed muster as a dry technical showcase, but Favreau gives it real analogue earth-under-the-fingernails charm.
There are lightning-flashes of pure, ornamental brilliance throughout Paolo Sorrentino's Youth, although there's not much happening on the landscape they illuminate.
A welcome surprise: sharper and funnier than its doom-laden predecessor, with a fantasy setting immersive enough to distract from the narrative's various chips and cracks.
A delicious, finger-tingling comedy about the creative instinct that makes your heart want to squawk with joy.
This is the cinematic superhero showdown you've dreamt of since childhood, precisely because that's everything - and all - it wants to be.
The film leaves you crying out for more bombs, more noise - and more Huppert.
This is a tumultuous and messy film that leaves you craving all the Miles Davis it doesn't give you, and I wouldn't have wanted it to be any other way.
In a golden period for both animation and children's filmmaking, here is a head-splitting reminder of just how bad those two things can get.
The genre's most egregious clichés aren't just put to work, but paraded around like prize sheep.

There's lots of glossy fun to be had. Clooney attacks the role of a journalist who rediscovers his conscience in real time with sticky-fingered glee, while Roberts is beguilingly composed as... his conscience, superego and puppeteer.
Café Society isn't Vonnie's story, but it's Stewart's film.
A mostly dreadful piece of would-be #viral #content disguised as an action film.
While you can't imagine the film ever making it to Cannes under anything other than its own steam, the jaunt proves to be a surprisingly worthwhile one.
As Zev closes in on his target you can almost hear the film's clockwork clicking and whirring, until the story finally snaps shut on itself like a trap.
There's an awful lot in here, and drawing it out takes a little time and thought.
"The whole thing looks like heightened news footage; raw, visceral and urgent."
The problem with Focus is that it never really does - and in its fuzzy-edged attempts to pull off the long con, the film ends up picking its own pocket.
A brawny, inventive action romp that's as happy firing rockets at helicopters as it is contemplating the Cartesian model of mind-body dualism.
Unfinished Business certainly lives up to the promise of its title: the film looks as though it needs another six months' work.
Is this a coming-of-age story or a whodunit? This heightened, luxurious melodrama...makes you wonder if the two genres are quite as different as you first thought.

"I know this doesn't make any sense," breathes Tris Prior during Insurgent's flamboyantly muddled finale, "but you have to trust me." You could hardly ask for a more honest line of dialogue than that.
While this particular bandwagon is fast running out of road, Run All Night shows there's mileage in it yet.
I found myself unexpectedly shedding a tear at the film's perfectly judged, sunbathed, final fade to white.

The film moves like a pyjama case full of angry weasels, and finds ingenious ways to cram every scene with just one more loopy, disposable gag or slapstick thwack. It may not be the year's best animated film, but it's almost certainly the most.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You leave the cinema wishing you'd understood even less of it than you did.
A shaded, slow-burning crime drama from the Italian director Francesco Munzi.
A sophisticated, provocative and thoroughly modern war film that makes Clint Eastwood's recent American Sniper look slow to find its target.

The film's belated sequel has the same director, three-quarters of its lead cast and one-third of its writing team, but in the intervening five years, all seem to have forgotten why the original worked and what it meant.

It's not that the film is particularly loathsome, or that Blart is an overweeningly horrible character. What rankles is that he's barely anything at all; a stereotype of a stereotype; a half-remembered punchline; a stomach with a moustache and wheels.
When it finally gets going, it becomes gloweringly compelling ...
A film that bounds towards the cult appeal of those self-reflexive horror classics, but agonisingly doesn't quite stick the landing.

The result is a lot of everything, but the film never feels overcrowded: in fact, it's the interplay between the film's many different characters, rather than the blow-up-the-world crisis they're trying to defuse, that keeps you on the edge of your seat.
In the first film, India was effectively a brightly coloured obstacle course for the characters to blunder through. This time, we get to see it as the prize.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The spirit of Éric Rohmer blows like a head-clearing breeze through every frame of this latest film from the Japanese director Koji Fukada - a little-known talent in this country, although this is the best reason yet to discover him.
The Artist is drunk on the history of cinema and art, and culture buffs will get giddy on it.
The wonder of stop-motion is the mountain of effort required to achieve even the smallest movement. The charm of Shaun the Sheep is that you don't notice it for a moment.
It's couture misery: dress by Valentino, watch by Breitling, lingering sexual regrets model's own.
As soon as I left the cinema, I went looking for a donkey to kick me in the head.
A total delight, as warm and welcome as a hot pair of socks on a winter morning.
There can be great pleasure in seeing egos pricked and lessons learned in this kind of tightly wound chamber piece, but only when there's a sense things could have turned out otherwise.
"Everyone is looking all the time; you just have to train yourself to look harder," Hockney explains. This warm, affectionate, perceptive film makes looking harder look easy.
This is bold and uncompromising stuff from Scott; a Biblical epic to shake your faith in the order of things, not reaffirm it.
This is not high art, but it is highly entertaining.
The script is so banal, it often plays like a spoof ...
It's all vigorous fun, a wonderful, wintry entertainment, but its branches catch at your heart.
Moments ... come close to realising the franchise's much-grasped-at potential as timeless children's entertainment.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Often, the comedy's just spiteful, sour or sloppily executed - or, in the case of a running joke about the hideous middle-agedness of Kathleen Turner's character, the mother of Harry's daughter, all three at once.
The whole cast is hamstrung by a script that only runs Wikipedia-deep.
No obvious connection to Takens passim other than its focus on a middle-aged man who'll punch or shoot anyone with a Slavic accent.
A welcome comeback for Eastwood.
This is bewitchingly smart science fiction of a type that's all too rare. Its intelligence is anything but artificial.

It's hard to think of a way in which the experience of watching the new Johnny Depp film could be any worse, unless you returned home afterwards to discover that Depp himself had popped round while you were out and set fire to your house.
It's hard to know what to make of Mark Wahlberg's character in The Gambler - but at least that puts you on an equal footing with Wahlberg himself.
It's the best thing both Franco and his co-star Seth Rogen have done in what feels like years: a raucous, abrasive, snort-out-loud satire with mischief in its heart and methane in its gut.
If the idea is to show that war makes monsters of us all, then writer-director Tom Green can't quite seem to bring his film to say it.
It's a wholly respectable adaptation, though perhaps a flash or two more of wildness wouldn't have gone amiss.
Genuinely warm-spirited, with three lovable central performances from Gadon, Powley and Reynor.
Its fuse fizzes dutifully from A to B, but the dynamite never ignites.
What makes The Cobbler particularly wounding is that for once, the premise needn't have necessarily resulted in such a washout.
The film is too wrapped up in its own dogma to entertain, and the deadly game of hide-and-seek that ensues becomes as monotonous as the baking desert landscape.

The film is almost all build-up, though any mounting sense of excitement is dispelled by the monotonously downbeat tone and the cast's conspicuous lack of chemistry. Nobody looks like they're having fun, and the gloom is infectious.
One of the greatest movies to be released this year and perhaps any other, though it's hard to feel entirely at peace with the fact that it exists.
The Gift is categorically not the film you first think it's going to be, but it has fun teasing you with the prospect.

Pixels are infinitesimally small points of light - and there are, astonishingly, a scattering of them to be found in this otherwise typically abominable project from Adam Sandler's Happy Madison Productions.
It's often been said that Simon Pegg would agree to star in absolutely anything: now at least it's official.
Gray's camera bobs and weaves around the action like a wary boxer, giving the story an athletic urgency.
If the heroes of Max Joseph's club-hopping drama were so much as casual acquaintances, you'd probably throw your mobile phone down a ravine and make for the nearest cave.
Once in a while, the film does flash some unexpected wit ...
The hardship of the trek is vividly and stomach-lurchingly portrayed, particularly when the storm sets in, but it never makes the crucial leap from the screen into your bones.
The mood is one of spiralling panic, but the editing has a methodical chop-chop-chop that makes a crisp narrative sense of the chaos.
Your skin's left prickling by its deft deconstruction of the business of secret-keeping, and its perceptive setting out of the courage and diligence it takes to overturn it.
"This is just business," Bulger constantly points out as he goes about his macabre activities. It feels like it.
The film has so little to say about forbidden love, and gives its stars so little dramatic sinew to flex, that it already feels like a footnote in the genre.
Beautiful, humane and moving ...
What makes this so thrilling as drama isn't simply the fact of Dennis's corruption but the speed with which it happens.
The film ladles on the melancholy so thickly that there's no space for you to feel it for yourself.
This is pulp with the seeds left in, and you'll be picking them from between your teeth for weeks.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film has a scrappy optimism about it that's often very winning, but it never draws itself up to its full height.
I was somehow watching my own teenage struggles and triumphs play out on the screen. The fact I'm not - nor have ever been - French, female or black didn't seem to come into it.
"Light on plot" would be a fair description. But so would "streamlined" - a rare property in a summer movie, and by no means one to hold against it.

Tale of Tales dances on a razor's edge between funny and unnerving, with sequences of shadow-spun horror rubbing up against moments of searing baroque beauty. The result is a fabulously sexy, defiantly unfashionable readymade cult item.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film frames [Johnson] like a saviour, and bathes him in so much morning sunlight you have to squint, but as he insists to the news crew on board: "I'm just doing my job, ma'am." That's about the strength of it.

Kurzel's chilling debut feature, the 2011 true-crime thriller Snowtown, suggested the then-37-year-old Australian filmmaker was a talent to watch. But this towering, consistently ingenious film establishes him as a director to cherish.
The first film in seven years from the Taiwanese master Hou Hsiao-Hsien is an immaculate treasure box of light, texture and movement.

The problem with Love isn't its purpose, which I find wholly laudable, nor the sex itself, which is beautiful and also -- to use a taboo critical term -- sexy. It's that both these things deserved a far richer and more intelligent film to support them.

It's a perceptive examination of the singer's need for love -- from her friends, family, colleagues, husband and public -- and the ways in which that need went unmet, or was exploited, at the times it ached in her the most.
You come in expecting portraiture, but Ferrara gives you Cubist still life.
It's an encouraging premise, and one which is squandered in every way imaginable by this weedy and entirely second-guessable comic drama.

Even more than its intensely likeable central performances and convincingly solid visual effects, it's ... supple self-reflexiveness that makes Colin Trevorrow's film a worthy sequel to Spielberg's industry-changing original.
When the end credits roll, and you notice most of the crew's names are listed as "anonymous", the threat seems fresh and immediate.
[A] smoking crater of a film ... the end result has vital scenes missing, no ending, and performances that often don't make sense.
This is a humane and heart-wrenchingly beautiful film from Docter; even measured alongside Pixar's numerous great pictures, it stands out as one of the studio's very best.
You sense a shuddering apprehension in every creative choice - as if one false move, or even an overly brazen one, would destabilise the formula.
The target audience seems to be people who know the first two Terminator films back to front and also hate them. The other 99.9999+ percent of us are in for a bumpy ride.
Brisk humour, keenly felt dramatic stakes, and invention over scale. You know: small pleasures.
The colours, forms and emotions are individually familiar, but they're combined in ways that aren't quite like anything you've seen before.
The film doesn't have a single remotely sympathetic character, and its sense of humour is so lip-chappingly dry every ticket should come with a complimentary jar of Vaseline.
This comedy from Rebecca Miller says more about the human condition through its cardigans than most films this summer have managed in their scripts.
The 2016 vintage of Ghostbusters speaks to its time with the same withering comic accuracy and hot-air-balloon-sized sense of fun as the 1984 original.
The occasional lows only serve to illustrate what a minefield the genius biopic can be - and how Born to be Blue skips through the genre more nimbly than most.
Around nine tenths product placement, at least 15 tenths abysmal, and pulsates with molten cynicism on every imaginable level.
Valerian is a film to wallow in, not follow, and if you're tuned to its extra-terrestrial wavelength, you wouldn't cut a second.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Maud Lewis left the world a brighter place than she found it. This drably earnest rendering of her life story doesn't follow suit.
Completely unlike anything else you'll see this year.
The computer graphics are ugly and dated, the plot a clump of clichés, and with one notable exception, you can almost hear the voice cast scrolling through their phones in the recording booth.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An interesting film rather than an engrossing one ... it's hard not to wish it was a little more energised by its subject's enduringly transgressive spirit.
A cut-rate, no-fun, corrosively unlikeable Midnight Run re-do, with Ryan Reynolds and Samuel L Jackson both locked on their respective autopilots.
It's a delightful, nimble miniature, as thought-provoking in the long term as it is wryly entertaining in the moment.
Gore. (Hoo! Yeah!) What is he good for? Making an impassioned, morally urgent case for action on climate change, say it again, y'all.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Each actor inhabits their role with a precision and mettle that means even in the depths of confusion, the complex group dynamics are easy to read.
Contrary to the teachings of another famous childhood ditty, Payne's film thrills to the idea that it may not be such a small world after all.
Unquestionably a curio for converts rather than the meatier exploration it will leave many sceptics (including this one) hankering after, but it leaves you with plenty to chew on ...

It offers what must be cinema's uneasiest probing of the postwar American psyche since Paul Thomas Anderson's The Master - and is unquestionably del Toro's best, richest film since his 2006 Spanish-language masterpiece Pan's Labyrinth.
As DeMillean in scope as it is radical in its call to compassion, it's basically The Ten Commandments of dissident art.

Schrader and his cast commit to the project with sharpened and unblinking seriousness, even when the going gets mesmerically weird, with violence, visions, levitations and Neil Young protest songs chanted sombrely by toxic swamps.
If this story of a lonely young life lived on the hoof leaves us craving stillness and closeness, then surely that's mission accomplished.
The film equivalent of a loveable old hound that fetches your favourite slippers, rolls over for a tickle, curls up on your feet, contentedly passes wind, then nods off.
Feels like the result of some kind of diabolical, chimpanzee-fingered pact.
It's a hectic, sour and muddled film - a flailing counterfeit of satire that keeps slipping on its own banana skin supply, and never remotely gets to grips with what it thinks it's sending up.
Despite the aches and creaks in its extremities, The Big Sick is in rude health where it counts.

Christopher Nolan's astonishing new film, a retelling of the Allied evacuation of occupied France in 1940, is a work of heart-hammering intensity and grandeur that demands to be seen on the best and biggest screen within reach.

In a genre where fanboy entitlement regularly calls the tune, Wonder Woman's feminism feels like a rarity. Time will tell whether Hollywood [will be] in the thrall of a heroine addiction. But as the credits rolled, I was already craving another hit.
It's like the wildest Frasier episode they never made, and hits all the parts - sometimes literally - the Fifty Shades of Grey films couldn't hope to reach.
Neither the social realism nor the stoner antics feel sufficiently thought-through, making Dough the definition of half-baked.

This isn't just good writing, it's humane and honourable. Every child here feels like a real human being, and as such is accorded a dignity the world invariably hasn't extended to them in their lives to date.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Cedar might have built up a broader satirical thesis from all this wheeling and dealing, but he's happy to let the film rest gently on Gere's shoulders - these days, a pretty safe foundation.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You don't get [this] kind of thing on the NHS - but you do, with reasonable frequency, on Sunday evening television, which is where this very harmlessly tempestuous tale might feel most at home.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: When Cox finally announces "This is the Prime Minister speaking" as he delivers his D-Day address to a waiting nation, you understand the significance of those six words exactly - both what they mean, and what they need to mean in order to mean anything.
We're just supposed to accept that Diane Keaton - Diane Keaton! - would happily settle for a man she literally finds in a bush.
In the obliter-tainment game, Bay's simply better than that -- and on this form, he may be better than anyone.
The film has a cumulative power that sneaks up on you even as you think you're keeping track of it, and a twilit afterglow that hasn't faded yet.
Reeves marshals more than his fair share of battle scenes and sweeping set-pieces, but never forgets the flicker of a face can provide all the spectacle that cinema requires.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Consistently funny, with the kind of well-orchestrated slapstick moments where you can actually feel the stick slap.

The Italian director Bernardo Bertolucci was once credited with making "intravenous cinema", but there's no better imaginable description of Baby Driver, which seems to shoot directly from the screen into your arteries.
A little of the new Spider-Man went an exhilaratingly long way in Captain America: Civil War last year. But a lot of him goes almost nowhere in this slack and spiritless solo escapade.
Think of Shults's film ... as the end of the world by lantern light: intimate and flickering up close, with unfathomable blackness beyond.
Its plot ... blossoms into something more profound than the Rocky sequel-esque comeback yarn you initially expect.

This is a fascinating and outrageous next step for Escalante, with a strong central concept and some oozily plausible special effects. It's just a pity that its human side doesn't measure up to its inhuman one.
Throughout the film, there's a sharp specificity to the women's various emotional travails that cuts across its occasionally baggy construction.
Just 71 minutes long, but so toenail-tweakingly pleased with itself, and so replete with pseud-ish posturing, that by the end it feels as if the whole thing must have been playing at quarter-speed.
movie_title: The Private Life of a Modern Woman (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's bluntly honest ... and finds a rough-edged humour in that frankness.
Frears' film is all nostalgia and inertia - a tale ablaze with historical import and contemporary resonance, reduced to commemorative biscuit tin proportions.
Tremendous ...
Prickly, sly, entirely exquisite.
The Last Jedi mounts some genuinely startling narrative twists and feints, while charting an onward course for the franchise that has you itching to discover what comes next.

As ever with Scott, the film unfolds in a richly realised world and moves with an addictive, free-wheeling swagger. And his four main actors -- Williams, Wahlberg and the Plummers old and young -- have all been astutely cast.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The main problem with this idea - apart from it being completely and utterly bibbly bibbly quack-quack insane - is that once you airbrush exploitation out of the PT Barnum story, there's not much story left.
Laughs flow fast thanks to all four actors committing gamely to the bit, and the four-strong writing team doing their damnedest to winkle out every last gag from the mismatches.
The film passes the time with breezy good cheer and the odd well-wrangled cringe, but fades from memory in much the same way.
Reconcile yourself to the fact that the thematic loose ends are never going to be sensibly tied up ... and it's possible to coast through the entire film on its unflagging visual bravado alone.
Who wouldn't want to see the Nazis taken to task by George Smiley, Count Dracula and Jean-Baptiste Emanuel Zorg?
The miracle of great stop-motion has always been that the films look loved. As you watch Early Man, you can feel it.
For all its seeming modesty, this is a mature, contemplative and mostly rewarding experiment: no awards-season bruiser, but a worthwhile B-side for Ashby's venerable American classic.

You can see [Michael B.] Jordan offhandedly weighing the line in his mind like a rock he's about to lob: it's one of many nicely judged moments of performance here from a wildly appealing ensemble cast without a weak link.
This is a film in which one of the more emotionally detailed performances is given by a product-placement Audi.
It has the soul of a washing machine instruction manual. I can't recall when I last saw a film that works so hard to stop you enjoying it.
It has a power that makes the cinema shake.
It is all so relentlessly toe-curling that at the end I found myself walking out of the cinema like Mr Tumnus, gingerly picking his way through the Narnian snowpack.
Tweens, rather than children, will savour its snarky bite, although like the shambling on-screen cadavers, the story needed a bit more meat on its bones.

Delivers ... a preachy, bland and fastidiously inoffensive kind of ersatz fun - a little like those knock-off Christian video games from the early 1990s that mimicked existing hits, but which made you pray for people instead of shoot them.
It's here to burnish one performer's legend while laying the foundations of another's. But there's still lots of fun to be had in its twisting, telescoping hall of mirrors.
movie_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's consistently embarrassing to watch, and features plot holes so yawningly vast they have a kind of Grand Canyon-like splendour: part of you wants to hang around to see what they look like at sunset.
All three ... leads are sensational, although their performances are so supply intertwined, it's hard to put a finger on exactly what each one is individually up to that's so good.
[Three Billboards] makes for soaringly satisfying viewing, yet the satisfaction comes from blistering performances and virtuosic screenwriting.
A sick joke, an urgent warning and a roar into the abyss, Mother! earns its exclamation mark three times over and more.
Let's put it this way: American Assassin seems to have a certain target audience in mind, and it's probably not one you'd want to be considered a part of.
Midnight slickness is The Villainess's signature look, and one it rocks with mesmeric panache.
A film on its toes - nimble, vivid and lyrical, with its guard down and its blood up.

This crazily overlong and tiresome follow-up doesn't seem to have the first idea what to do with itself - not least when it comes to its much-vaunted all-star cast, the majority of whom are barely even in it.
One of the most spectacular, provocative, profound and spiritually staggering blockbusters of our time.
A punishingly twee instructional biopic, in which a testing human life is boiled down into the screen equivalent of a non-prescription pick-me-up.
Seldom this year have I felt quite so delighted, refreshed and nourished by a film as Kuro, an impish reverie bathed in milky colours and even light.
A sad turn-up for a franchise which has already proven dazzlingly adept at staging Michael Bay-style madcap spectacle on a toy-box scale.
It's funny, charming, dazzling, gorgeously designed, and full of actors you already like.

Watching Gerard Butler solve a whodunit is like watching ... chimpanzees move a piano downstairs: a kind of teeth-baring, flea-picking burlesque of recognisable human behaviour that's funny for a while until you start to worry about the ethics of it.
It's an incomparably lovely period romance, as warm and therapeutic as the sunlight that suffuses every frame.

Conservative fans might appreciate its craven faithfulness, but adaptation isn't much fun when it's just approximation, and Fullmetal Alchemist behaves less like cinema than cosplay on a cinema budget.
Even with its myriad confusions and frustrations, there's nothing else quite like Hanagatami around.
A coldly mesmerising investigative thriller from Kei Ishikawa in which the cosy, middle-class family unit is revealed to be less nuclear than toxic.
This is a documentary that rejects every behind-the-scenes cliché around, and stands as an immensely moving and inspiring piece of cinema in its own right.

Branagh has mapped out his film as scrupulously as his screen alter ego does the investigation, and fights the tendency for starchy period stories to wilt into camp. But a shade more playfulness would have gone a long way.
Vaughn's performance is hard, dark, and mercilessly committed, and the film gives you nowhere to hide from it - no twangs of irony or conspiratorial winks to take the edge off what ensues.
Nothing in this feeble psychological thriller rings true for a moment, though its unhinged machinations feel as pedestrian as soap opera in execution.
movie_title: Based on a True Story (D'après une histoire vraie) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Loznitsa's construction of this world apart - which is, of course, a grotesque allegory for Russia itself - is as immersive as it is unnerving.
A fantastically dreary and flatulent anti-war satire, adapted from a nonfiction book by Michael Hastings.
As a multi-faceted character study - of a couple, a nation, a racial identity - there are surprises around every corner.
A nuclear-fission-strength heartbreaker. It's made up of moments so slight and incidental they're sub-molecular - but they release enough heat and light to swallow whole cities at a stroke.

The one thing that can't be said about Howard's film is that it doesn't do justice to Brown's book: it absolutely does, which is the entire problem, and arguably one that any halfway-faithful adaptation could never avoid.

After softening you up with whatever the comedic equivalent of a triple somersault with a half pike and double twist is, it lands on its emotional target - we're talking freely trickling tears - with a persuasive and satisfying thud.
Free Fire is a mad contraption, bristling with bravado and black, sardonic wit.
While it too often sands the complications off what you sense should feel like an uncomfortably splintery issue, in its best moments, it's a quietly fearsome piece of drama.

We already know from his turn as Martin Luther King Jr in Selma that Oyelowo can be stirring in a statesmanlike role, but here he brings a similar kind of moral conviction to a far humbler underdog character.
Confronting the horrors of history head-on can make for cinema that's impossible to shake, but Katabuchi's painterly, introspective film proves a sideways approach can be just as indelible.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Like a landscape shining after heavy rain, it feels like real life with the sharpness, brightness and sensation turned right up.
The one equation it never manages to balance is the one that says making a film about Asperger's Syndrome being more or less a superpower equals a rip-roaring and completely non-problematic jape.
A fantastically moving and bruising war film that hits you like a raw topside of beef in the face - a kind of primary-coloured Guernica that flourishes on a big screen with a crowd.
It's never entirely clear why its three unrelated stories are being told in the first place.
As a feat of world-building and character-shaping, it sets an appealing stage.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You'll need patience for it to work on you, but all effort's repaid tenfold, thanks to Kurosawa's murmur-soft, immaculate craft and a trio of gorgeous central performances ...
movie_title: Daguerrotype (Le secret de la chambre noire) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film's riotous oddness occasionally teeters into a free-for-all, though it retains enough shape for a joke about a parakeet sending a text message to pay off more than an hour after it's set up.

This is a film where couples look like a million bucks in direct sunlight and five times that in shadow, and talk in that heightened movie-speak where every line feels like an airborne shuttlecock: playful, arcing, nimbly swatted.
Brimming over with spectacle and visual inventiveness.
It's another flick through a familiar and by-now bulging scrapbook, but it leaves you craving less - and more.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The phenomenon of their live appearances - not just the concerts themselves, but the cheeky press-conference preludes, and the hysterical, garment-rending fallout - itself defines the era with a spiky precision.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Blair Witch styles itself as a love-letter, but it's pure transcription.
Stirring, heartstring-strumming stuff ... a chapter of history that rewards a close reading.
Despite the plot adjustments, Swallows and Amazons reproduces the potted world Ransome wrote about with diligence and sincerity: it's very English, very interwar, and very, very white.
Feuerzeig's film teasingly, dextrously reminds us that all art - especially the true stuff - is fake.
Occasionally, the film feels like Ayer is trying to fight his way out from underneath an enormous, suffocating parachute.

The film is confident enough in its own weatherbeaten skin to take on no more plot than is strictly necessary, and its most affecting scenes are all character-driven moments with no real bearing on the story.

Byrne's film is concerned with the process and practice of myth-making: the way the right person, or action, or face, can capture a moment, or galvanise a movement - and, for both good and ill, transform politics into something like art.
János Edelényi's The Carer brings nothing to the party apart from the kind of clenched, eyelid-twitching grin of enforced affability that quickly loses any charm it ever had.
Even after all these years, the character still fits Gervais as comfortably as a Sergio Georgini sports jacket.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Collet-Serra's rigorous craftsmanship and Lively's muscular-in-every-sense movie-star performance ... ensure every attack and counterattack convulses and grips.
Stone's fixation on the sheer dang manliness of sticking one to the government, even digitally, feels misguided here from the off.

Nothing here looks like a genuine interaction between real human beings: Spacey may be the first actor to give a comedic performance in which his own smile looks like it had to be green-screened in at a later date.
The satire hits with powder-puff force thanks largely to the film's ruinous lack of moral shading around David and Efraim's exploits.
It has its head in the stars, and for a little over two wonderstruck hours, it lifts you up there too.

Fassbender and Vikander explore their characters' various thorny moral quandaries and shifting states of mind in breath-catching depth, drilling down through the plot's melodramatic crust to the swirling ethical magma underneath.
Beautiful, provocative allegory that can bump your whole worldview off balance.
Everything that works in Nocturnal Animals is intoxicating, provocative, delicious - and happily, so is everything that doesn't.
Call it wholemeal bread and circuses - an odd diet of sincerity and spectacle that nonetheless hits some kind of spot.
It's the type of film that, whatever time of day you watch it, makes it feel like half past two in the morning.
The Journey is an apocryphal drama about the Northern Irish peace process, and makes its subject look like a methodical tootle around the block by comparison.
The result is a roiling casserole of bad-taste jolts - lynching trees, parricidal Lolitas, "murder tourism", gallows gags about racist mobs - but each one pulls its weight and makes its point.
All queue, no roller-coaster.
It's a film full of tight close-ups of hands accepting gifts that comfort, inspire and bring succour to their recipients' souls. That's how we should receive it.
Just when you think the film can't get any more mawkish or fatuous, it always surprises you.

Beatty's casting of Collins and Ehrenreich is inspired: it's easy to imagine both of these beautiful young things thriving in the Hollywood of the 1950s and 60s, in much the same way Beatty himself did.
The film's inability to capture the plights of its human victims in comparably arresting terms leave its priorities feeling, at best, naively jumbled.
That sense of gooey euphoria runs through everything that's good in Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2, which inches even further to the end of the limb the original Guardians film went out on in 2014.
Throughout, Quillévéré keeps asking her cast for the impossible, and gets it.
The film's attempt to combine mainstream action and timely social realism results in the kind of sticky mess that should have been easily avoided.
Visually, narratively, every creative choice forks off down the most obvious route.
So misshapen and inert, your imagination and memory never come close to being sparked by it.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Frantz is the work of a rascal, but a rascal in an unusually reflective frame of mind. Even with its mysteries solved, you can't help but keep turning it over.

Grandiose, exhilarating, vertiginously cynical and symphonically perverse, and around a million miles from the crowd-pleasing Alien retread Twentieth Century Fox have presumably been begging [Ridley Scott] to make.
The cost of the film's shapeshifting is that it's hard to invest in it as anything other than a movie-making game - but for Desplechin's impish purposes, it's a price worth paying.
The small story at hand offers an opaque but pitiless critique on the director's native Russia at large.
Variously lukewarm and lugubrious ...
When absurdism feels this wrong, you know it's being done right.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Okja is plenty of fun, and smart around the edges, but the girl-and-her-pig stuff can drag, and it feels like it's pressing for resonance more than properly achieving it.
Wind River is a film about this landscape's hard indifference towards all who trudge across it - and Sheridan's beady, inquisitive script scrutinises all its characters' credentials in turn.
The film doesn't stint on emotional complexity, but it might be Baumbach's most accessible to date ...
A mostly fun partial reset, but this series needs to slip its moorings and make for new horizons.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's the kind of handsome, rousing, rigorous entertainment you can't help but play along with.
It's an odd sensation to watch a Fast & Furious film and find yourself wishing the special effects lived up to the writing, but - well, here we are.
With Caine, Freeman and Arkin, you know what you're going to get. In Going in Style, it's all you get.
Whether Boss Baby is riffing on corporate retreats or double espressos, the punchline - a baby in a suit is behaving like an adult - never changes.

For everyone who thought Dan Brown's conspiracy novels were just lacking a spot of parkour, Assassin's Creed might be your favourite film of the year. But for the clinically sane 99.9 percent of the rest of us, it's rather less exciting.
Endless Poetry isn't exactly a painless introduction to the world of Alejandro Jodorowsky. But let's be honest: what is?

This is a cinema of no escape, and few if any actors will have to shoulder the same burden of expressive responsibility this year - yet the never-better Portman simply shines beneath it, giving a performance of mesmeric complexity and commitment.
This measured, diligently crafted register feels like Shyamalan back on home turf.
Though the film feeds on its forerunner, it's worthwhile on its own terms.
There are around four (great) films' worth of action and jokes here, crammed into a story so streamlined it might have been assembled in the Lockheed wind tunnel.
Basically, if the leads weren't so clearly just a pair of messy so-and-sos that live for drama, Fifty Shades Darker would be over in three minutes flat.
A film as transporting, profound and staggering in its emotional power as anything I've seen in the cinema in years.
Despite its darker tone, Rogue One feels cosily at home in the Star Wars universe, and is crowded with the kind of imagination-tickling details the franchise thrives on.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One thing The Great Wall gets absolutely right is the walliness, because watching it feels like repeatedly banging your head against one.
It's something no-one could have expected: a creatively risky superhero movie. And it deserves to pay off.
Patriots Day is stirring, well-acted, moving and built with conviction and flair.
Imagine Steven Spielberg's The Lost World if it had been written and directed by Gremlins-era Joe Dante.
The whole enterprise feels like a ten bob knock-off, or a would-be remake that couldn't nab the rights.
Song to Song unfolds in and around the rock scene in Malick's adopted home town of Austin, but you sense it wouldn't be noticeably different if it had been set at a bacon factory or an ice rink.
The premise of A Silent Voice may seem modest. But its approach leads an old story down a little-trod, languidly beautiful path.
Appears to have been shot by the Hunchback of Notre Dame and edited by a monkey wearing oven gloves.
I found myself curling over in such a paralysing cringe, my body had to be rolled out of the cinema afterwards like a dented bicycle wheel.
[A] bright, absorbing biopic ...
Here, success is even scarier than failure: it's a nocturnal fantasy, seductive and ablaze with threat.

It's the kind of mood that brings out the best in Kidman, whose performance is deliciously subtle, but with a lemony edge of camp that allows her to twist an entire scene with the arch of an eyebrow or parting of her lips.
In the age of shopping-centre cinema, Christopher Nolan builds cathedrals.
Has ever a film battled more fruitlessly against the creepiness of its own premise than The Odd Life of Timothy Green?
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: In a supporting role as a CIA bureau chief, Olga Kurylenko looks half-asleep. Who can blame her?
It isn't great art, but it is patterned after great art, and there are worse ways to make a film than that.
This is great American cinema of the type we keep worrying we've already lost. Behind its puppy-dog eyes burns a fierce intelligence.
It rattles along with no little vim, and there is one excellent joke about the difficulty of finding a computer's hash key when time is tight.
Black has an instinctive feel for balancing action set-pieces against the passages of soap-opera that are required to make them matter.
That pioneer spirit? It's gone.
This is too dull to function as a thriller and too silly to qualify as anything else.
"Oh, not the talent show thing again," groans Ashley Jensen's social worker when the youngsters announce their plan. Well, you said it.
This feels like a film Almodóvar had to get out of his system - a kind of cinematic kidney stone - and your gut will twinge in sympathy.
Lindholm ... infuses every frame of his second film with the slow-burn, high-tension pungency of a particularly addictive DVD box set.
You leave the cinema with your teeth clenched, muttering: "at least it meant well".
There is surely no contradiction in praising the Australian director's batty ambitions for this story while admitting that they often work against it.
Everything comes together for the good here: visuals, performances, raucous soundtrack, Coppola's teasing flirtation with, yet ultimate lack of commitment to, some kind of concrete morality.
As fizzy and quenching as a pint of lemonade.
Heli may be the most optimistic film you will ever see in which one young man sets another's genitals on fire.
The horizon-stretching scenery, shimmeringly captured by cinematographer Yu Lik-Wai, will make you draw breath, in awe but also fear.
The world of bare-knuckle Irish boxing feuds between bitterly opposed traveller families makes for depressing and unilluminating dramatic material.
The Selfish Giant is cinema that tells an unsure nation who we are.
Has aged as well as Lee Marvin's brown jacket and tangerine shirt ensemble - that is to say, spectacularly.
This is a vital and important film - just not to watch.
Even though the ride finally stalls, A Good Day To Die Hard has been thrustingly outrageous enough in its earlier moments to coast to the finish line on momentum.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Every scene feels like an airbrushed composite of dozens of rambling takes, and 133 minutes is drainingly long for a story this sitcom-slight.
The film shocks you to the marrow, and every frame burns with a righteous fire, itself religious in its intensity.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Tykwer and the Wachowskis have laboured long and hard to turn Mitchell's very literary material into something cinematic.
Park's film is head-spinningly kinky stuff, even by Korean standards, and the fact it has somehow emerged from the American studio system in all its unhinged glory is itself a marvel.
What elegant pulp this is, and how inelegantly I gobbled it up.

When it comes to long-form tales of political intrigue, television serials are fast encroaching on cinema's patch, and if this very ordinary thriller is the best Hollywood can do, it might as well cede the whole territory.
It may not be wonderful, but it will do for now.

[A] neap tide of mush.
